images.alt_text: Local sales of luxury timepieces are likely to repeat last year's pattern: down in the first half and up in the second - PHOTO: ST

site_title: China factory growth at 3-month low
summary: China's factory growth slowed to a three-month low in August, with the HSBC/Markit Flash China Manufacturing PMI falling to 50.3 from July's 18-month high of 51.7. This marks the lowest reading since May, but still above the 50-point level separating growth from contraction for a third consecutive month. The moderation in output and new orders has reinforced concerns about increasing softness in the Chinese economy.

site_title: Raw, unfiltered theatre
summary: The South African production of August Strindberg's "Mies Julie" has been praised for its raw and unfiltered portrayal of race and colonialism in the country. The play, which relocates the original story to South Africa, has sparked controversy with its depiction of a white woman's affair with a black farm worker. Critics have praised the production for adding depth and nuance to the original story, while some have described it as "pornographic" due to its graphic content. The play's writer-director, Yael Farber, argues that the true issue is the underlying social and historical context of apartheid and colonialism. The production is set to open in Singapore on August 27.

site_title: Celcom boss tipped to become new MAS CEO
summary: Malaysia Airlines is searching for a new CEO, with Celcom boss Shazalli Ramly emerging as a likely candidate due to his marketing expertise and branding savvy. Idris Jala, former MAS CEO, is tipped to become chairman. Ramly's experience in rebranding Celcom has made him a favored choice, but his inexperience in aviation may raise concerns. A former MAS veteran with sound network and revenue management experience may be appointed to fill the gap in airline experience. The airline's financial woes and recent tragedies have made it difficult to find a suitable candidate.

site_title: Iloilo beckons - and the migrants flock back
summary: Iloilo, a Philippine city, is experiencing significant transformation with major developments, including new airports, roads, and ports, attracting property developers, retailers, and business-processing companies. The city's growth is part of President Benigno Aquino's efforts to reverse decades of migration to Manila and promote economic growth in secondary cities. Investments are creating jobs, improving infrastructure, and boosting tourism, with Iloilo set to host the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meetings in 2025. The city's transformation is expected to benefit the national economy, combat poverty, and increase provincial incomes.

site_title: Living inside a graphic novel
summary: Artist Nikhil Chopra's 50-hour performance art piece, Give Me Blood and I Will Give You Freedom, was a visceral experience that transported viewers into a graphic novel-like world. Commissioned by the Singapore International Arts Festival, the performance told the story of the Indian National Army during World War II, with Chopra playing multiple characters and using image projections and animation to bring the narrative to life. The piece, which took place in a white room, began with Chopra painting himself white and gradually transformed into a Mughal-style restaurant, a soldier, and ultimately, a black Hindu Goddess. The performance was a masterclass in storytelling and art-making, with Chopra's restraint and use of monochromatic message making the narrative even stronger.

site_title: Japan exports up 3.9% as overseas demand picks up
summary: Japan's exports rose 3.9% in July, the first increase in three months, driven by increased shipments of cars to Europe, metal processing machinery, and liquid crystal displays. This uptick in exports may help offset a slump in domestic spending and support the government's "Abenomics" plan, potentially easing pressure on policymakers to boost growth. Exports to Asia, particularly China, also rose, but the growth is expected to be moderate, with the US market experiencing declines.

site_title: Domestic wholesale trade falls 6.1% in Q2
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade fell 6.1% in Q2 2014 compared to the same period last year, primarily due to a 14.9% decline in the metals, timber & construction materials sector. Despite this, foreign wholesale trade expanded 3.1%, driven by a 17.3% jump in general wholesale trade and an 11% increase in the metals, timber & construction materials industry. Excluding petroleum, domestic wholesale trade declined 2.4% and 1.6% quarter-on-quarter, while foreign wholesale trade rose 2.4% and 1.8% respectively.

site_title: Buyers abandon homes in China city as prices fall
summary: Falling property prices in China's Wenzhou city have led to 6.4 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) of bad loans as buyers abandoned homes and stopped making mortgage payments. The 34-month price drop has resulted in 56% of homes being abandoned, mostly high-end apartments. Real estate lending accounts for 26% of outstanding bank loans in Wenzhou, contributing to China's slowing economy, which is forecast to expand 7.4% for the full year, the slowest pace since 1990.

site_title: Edgy China works
summary: Chinese artist Ai Weiwei's banned installation, "Untitled", will be showcased in Singapore's Beyond Stuff exhibition at the Mizuma Gallery from August 29 to October 5. The work, originally about the history of Chinese contemporary art, became politicized after government officials forced its removal and Ai's name from the exhibition in April. The exhibition also features works by four other Chinese artists, some of whom are also known for their critical views on the Chinese government. The show aims to introduce these artists to the public, despite some pieces being priced between S$13,000 and S$350,000.

site_title: KrisEnergy prices S$200m 5.75% notes
summary: KrisEnergy successfully priced S$200 million worth of 5.75% fixed rate notes due in 2018, part of its S$500 million multicurrency medium-term notes programme. The notes drew strong demand from institutional funds and private banks, with an order book of S$1.6 billion and an eight-time subscription rate.

site_title: MindChamps to expand to Malaysia, Australia
summary: MindChamps, a Singapore-based early childhood education provider, plans to expand globally with 30 centres in Malaysia and Australia. The company, which has 21 pre-school centres in Singapore, aims to open its first centre in Kuala Lumpur by 2015 and a facility in Australia a year later. MindChamps has partnered with Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and currently operates and franchises curriculum and enrichment programmes in Singapore, with a market share of 32% among premium pre-schools. The company is also considering a listing and has ambitions to go public.

site_title: SMRT pleased with Jokowi's project backing
summary: SMRT, a partner in the Jakarta Eco Transport Monorail project, expressed satisfaction with Indonesian President-elect Joko Widodo's support for the project. During a meeting, Jokowi reiterated his backing for the public transport system, noting its need for Jakarta. SMRT's president and group CEO Desmond Kuek stated that the project has gained new momentum with Jokowi's support, and they look forward to working with consortium partners to bring the project to fruition.

site_title: Craft and design fest that's a Keeper
summary: The Keepers: Singapore Designer Collective festival will run from September 12, 2014 to February 15, 2015, at an 11,000 square foot pop-up retail space in Orchard Road, Singapore. The event will feature around 50 local designers and artisans, with 20 resident designers and artisans showcasing their work, and over 30 guest designers and artisans participating in monthly themes. Admission is free, and the space will also host talks and workshops. Founder Carolyn Kan aims to create a community for designers and artisans, promoting collaborations and idea exchange.

site_title: Tokio retirement product features some firsts
summary: Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore launched the TM Retirement PaycheckLife, a whole life insurance product that pays customers a monthly income for life from age 55, 60, or 65. The product features instalment payments over 5, 10, or 15 years, allowing spouses to be covered, and a survivor can continue to receive payouts if one passes away. This product targets consumers seeking a lifetime income stream, similar to the government-run CPF Life, but with a higher payout potential.

site_title: Better for NOL to list logistics unit than to sell it
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) is considering selling or listing its logistics unit, APL Logistics, as the company explores desperate measures to keep itself afloat due to a second-quarter net loss of US$53.7 million. Despite efforts to improve cost efficiency, NOL's liner shipping business continues to struggle with weak trade volume and overcapacity, leading to a third straight quarter of losses. Listing APL Logistics could provide a strategic advantage, but selling the business may leave the group with a loss-making liner business, making profitability even more challenging.

site_title: Air Namibia seeks ally after stanching loss
summary: Air Namibia, a state-owned carrier, aims to break even on a monthly basis by the end of the year after implementing cost cuts, higher ticket prices, and more efficient planes. The airline is seeking an international ally to avoid shrinking to a regional player, with a focus on strategic partnerships. Air Namibia has already established code share agreements with Kenya Airways and Deutsche Lufthansa, and plans to outsource non-flying costs. The airline's gross profit has surged 51% this fiscal year, driven by a 17% gain in passenger numbers.

site_title: Iceman's record free-dives
summary: Christian Redl, known as "The Iceman," is a professional freediver who holds multiple world records, including freediving under ice to 61 meters and at the highest altitude of 5,160 meters. Redl, 38, spends most of his time conducting freediving courses and traveling the world, rather than actively seeking records. He is also the brand ambassador for Swiss watchmaker Edox and has designed a limited-edition watch to commemorate the company's 130th anniversary. Redl aims to raise awareness about global warming by attempting to freedive at the North Pole, South Magnetic Pole, and Geographic North Pole.

site_title: Cat B premiums post biggest increase
summary: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums rose across categories, with Category B experiencing the biggest increase. The COE for Cat B cars rose from S$68,689 to S$72,990, while Cat A cars saw a S$1,110 increase to S$65,710. Motorcycles also saw a slight increase, while goods vehicles and buses saw a decrease in COE premiums. Analysts expect COE prices to remain stable for the next two months, citing supply and demand factors.

site_title: En bloc sales still the way to go: Colliers
summary: Colliers International says en bloc sales remain a viable option for property owners and developers, despite the current market standstill. Sellers are not adjusting to the new market reality, while developers are seeking higher discounts due to softening market conditions. The success rate of collective sale attempts has fallen to 33% last year, compared to 41% in 2012. The reserve price for Tanglin Shopping Centre has been reduced to S$1 billion, or S$3,190 per square foot per plot ratio, as owners gather consent to launch a collective sale.

site_title: AirAsia X shares fall on the back of higher Q2 loss
summary: AirAsia X shares fell by 6% to 77 sen after the budget carrier reported a wider-than-expected Q2 loss of RM129 million, driven by higher operating expenses and declining yields. This marks a significant increase from the RM32.3 million loss in the same quarter last year. The airline's core net loss for the first six months reached nearly RM211 million, surpassing expectations. The decline in shares is attributed to the airline's inability to meet estimates.

site_title: Prosecution: Kong Hee had the final say
summary: City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee, 49, is alleged to have had the final say in financing the Crossover Project through sham bond subscriptions from 2006 to 2008. The prosecution claims Kong lied to authorities and in court, despite Xtron directors' involvement in decision-making processes. Kong denies the claim, stating he left technicalities to his deputies and maintained the Xtron directors' approval. Kong and five deputies face allegations of misusing millions of church funds and round-tripping monies to cover up the misuse.

site_title: Deutsche Bahn unit sues air cargo carriers
summary: Deutsche Bahn's logistics unit Schenker AG sued several air cargo carriers, including Air France-KLM, alleging a "secret and unlawful global conspiracy" to inflate US air freight shipping costs from 1999 to 2006. Schenker claims the airlines fixed prices with surcharges, purchasing millions of dollars in air freight services during the alleged period. The company is seeking tripled damages under US antitrust law, citing a multibillion-dollar industry facing downward pressure on prices before the alleged conspiracy began.

site_title: Greener pastures lie overseas, says Oxley CEO
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based developer, has reported a quadrupling of net profit to S$286.7 million for the year ended June 30, driven by profit recognition for industrial developments and mixed-residential projects. The company is eyeing overseas markets, including Europe and Myanmar, with talks on a mixed development site in Europe and plans to launch phase two of its Royal Wharf project in London. Oxley has proposed a cash dividend and has pre-sales of S$2.6 billion for its Singapore projects, with a target price of 91 Singapore cents set by analysts.

site_title: Teho's full-year profit up 42.5% at $3.4m
summary: TEHO International has achieved a record high revenue for the second consecutive year, with a 40.5% increase to S$60.4 million. The company's net profit grew 42.5% to S$3.4 million, with an earnings per share of 2.46 cents. Teho plans to expand into real estate development and investment in Cambodia via a joint venture. The company proposes a final dividend of 0.8 cent per share, representing a dividend payout of 32.5%.

site_title: XMH signs MOU for 80% stake in Z-Power
summary: XMH Holdings has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to acquire an 80% stake in Z-Power Automation for S$13.2 million. The acquisition will allow XMH to leverage Z-Power's technical knowledge to expand its product range and gain exposure to a wider customer base. XMH will pay the consideration in two tranches, with the first S$10.56 million upon completion and the second S$2.64 million in the first year. The acquisition is expected to enhance XMH's capabilities and improve its competitiveness in the marine and industrial sectors.

site_title: Case of shrinking US mansion roils brokers
summary: A California court ruled that sellers' agents have a fiduciary duty to protect buyers' interests when only one brokerage is involved in a deal, threatening dual-agency deals in the real estate industry. Millionaire Hiroshi Horiike sued Coldwell Banker and agent Chris Cortazzo after discovering his Malibu mansion had less living space than advertised, potentially leading to disclosure of confidential client information or brokerages dropping out of transactions. The decision could have far-reaching implications for the industry, with the California Supreme Court set to hear the case.

site_title: Himalaya Airlines plans to buy 15 A320 jets
summary: Himalaya Airlines, a joint venture between Tibet Airlines and Nepalese firms, plans to purchase 15 Airbus A320 jets over five years. The airline aims to start operations on October 28, initially using leased aircraft, and will fly to some Asian destinations from Kathmandu. Himalaya Airlines is owned by Tibet Air, a 31% stakeholder of Chinese flag carrier Air China, and two Nepalese investment firms.

site_title: GIC launches retail mall in Melbourne CBD
summary: GIC Real Estate has launched Emporium Melbourne, a 48,000 sq m retail mall in Melbourne's CBD, in partnership with Colonial First State Retail Property Trust Group. The mall features over 200 stores, including international and Australian fashion brands, and a 1,100-seat food court. Emporium Melbourne links to Myer and David Jones via pedestrian bridges and tunnels. This launch comes five years after the initial agreement to redevelop the site for A$1.1 billion.

site_title: BOC Aviation posts US$163m first-half earnings
summary: BOC Aviation reported a net profit of US$163 million for the first half of 2014, exceeding the same period last year. The aircraft leasing firm has a fleet size of over 250 aircraft and total assets of US$10.8 billion. BOC Aviation successfully tapped debt capital markets to raise US$1.2 billion, and paid a dividend of US$139 million to its parent Bank of China. The company delivered 37 new aircraft and sold 12 owned and managed planes during the period, with an average aircraft age under four years.

site_title: Global air traffic growth in June slows to 2.4%
summary: Global air traffic growth slowed to 2.4% in June, primarily due to softening world trade growth and lower business confidence. However, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) suggests a more robust performance in the second half of the year, driven by rising business confidence. Premium traffic grew 1.8% in June, with strengthening yields in longer-haul markets. Emerging markets, such as China and India, are expected to show improvement, while South America and Africa experienced negative growth due to economic crises and political tensions.

site_title: OCBC up again as Moody's confirms ratings
summary: OCBC Bank's stock price surged 7 cents to S$10.38, making it the most actively traded by value, after Moody's confirmed its long-term debt, deposit, and standalone ratings, maintaining a stable outlook. The bank's financial strength rating remains at B, and its long-term bank deposit ratings are Aa1. The ratings boost comes after OCBC launched a discounted rights share issue to pay for Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank.

site_title: Hamburg port adds jobs as cargo handling hits record levels
summary: The Port of Hamburg in Germany has added jobs as cargo handling reached record levels in the first half of 2014. The port handled 4.8 million standard containers and 51.6 million tonnes of general cargo, with more workers employed in handling terminals than in 2008. The surge in sea freight is attributed to the shipping industry's efforts to cope with overcapacity, leading to the worst price slump since containerization became global in the 1970s.

site_title: Midtown Manhattan losing rental shine
summary: Midtown Manhattan's office market is experiencing a decline in rental shine, with 35 blocks of contiguous space available as of June, compared to 31 in 2009. Landlords are facing increased competition from buildings downtown and at Hudson Yards, leading to aggressive marketing, renovations, and lease renewals to retain tenants. Technology and media companies are clustering in midtown south, while financial companies are relocating to lower Manhattan. The shift in demand is driven by tenants seeking value over prestige, with Class A office space making up only 54% of Manhattan's available space as of June.

site_title: Major China coal port set for record deliveries
summary: Qinhuangdao, China's largest coal port, is expected to receive record deliveries of coal and ores over the next three years, driven by urbanization and increasing power demand. Shipments may rise by 20-30 million tonnes by 2017, with the port handling 279 million tonnes in 2011. The port's coal business is expected to continue rising, driven by China's dependence on coal for 66% of its energy. Qinhuangdao Port's growth is seen as a barometer of the nation's economy, with stable contracts of up to 10 years supporting its operations.

site_title: Political instability may cost Selangor dearly
summary: Malaysia's political instability may impact the state of Selangor, where Menteri Besar Abdul Khalid Ibrahim is fighting for time until the state legislative assembly meets in November. With 30 of 56 seats vacant, Ibrahim hopes to secure support through horse-trading, potentially affecting the national economy. The prolonged crisis could have far-reaching consequences, but it is unclear how long the standoff will last.

site_title: SMBC and HK Aviation vying for Awas aircraft
summary: SMBC Aviation Capital and Hong Kong Aviation Capital are among bidders for aircraft assets being sold by Terra Firma Capital Partners' plane lessor Awas Aviation Capital. Awas is selling about 100 newer aircraft for up to $5 billion. The assets, valued at $11 billion, are expected to increase to $17 billion by 2016. SMBC and Hong Kong Aviation are competing with Cheung Kong Holdings, led by Li Ka-shing, for the assets.

site_title: Bitcoin on a downswing, hits lowest since May
summary: Bitcoin's price has dropped nearly 12% to its lowest value since May, trading at US$435.60. Analysts attribute the decline to new regulations, while industry insiders consider wild price swings normal. The price briefly plummeted to US$309 before recovering to US$460. This decline follows a period of relative stability since the collapse of Mt Gox in February. Despite the recent drop, bitcoin's long-term trend remains uncertain.

site_title: ICAP S'pore CEO Warner resigns
summary: ICAP plc's Singapore unit CEO Anthony Warner, who joined in 2010 after 25 years with the company, has resigned and will leave at the end of the month. Danny Cheung, a managing director, will succeed him. The departure is not related to recent staff cuts, which were implemented to cushion a slump in trading. ICAP reported a 19% decline in first-quarter revenue.

site_title: StanChart's US$300 million fine raises heat on board
summary: Standard Chartered has agreed to a US$300 million fine for lapses in anti-money laundering controls, following a series of transgressions and a drop in earnings. The fine, imposed by New York State financial services superintendent Benjamin Lawsky, has piled pressure on the bank's board, particularly CEO Peter Sands and chairman John Peace. The bank will suspend dollar-clearing payments for high-risk business clients, end high-risk relationships, and retain a monitor for another two years. The settlement comes after a series of settlements with US regulators, including a US$667 million payment in 2012.

site_title: US in Iraq: Caution is the watchword
summary: US President Barack Obama has authorized air strikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) amid a humanitarian catastrophe in Iraq. ISIS has committed genocide against minority groups, including Christians and Yazidis, and US President Obama believes this requires military intervention to prevent a horrific humanitarian disaster. However, a full-scale US military intervention is deemed unfeasible due to fiscal constraints and the need to focus on rebuilding the American economy and shifting geo-strategic focus to East Asia.

site_title: Asia-Pac hotel investment hits 5-year high in 2013
summary: Asia-Pacific hotel investment reached a 5-year high in 2013 with a transaction volume of $12.83 billion, driven by China's largest market share. This year's expected slowdown is predicted to be between $9 billion and $10.5 billion, with the first half of 2014 seeing $5.203 billion in investment. Despite a slowdown, some markets, like China, saw high investment totals, and emerging markets like Cambodia, Macau, and the Maldives also saw increased investment.

site_title: Somali pirate kingpin arrested: security sources
summary: Somali pirate kingpin Mohamed Garfanji was arrested by security forces in Mogadishu, along with several bodyguards. He is wanted by the US and Seychelles for his alleged role in kidnapping citizens from both countries. Garfanji, who once commanded a private army, was involved in hijacking giant vessels earning multi-million dollar ransoms. His arrest comes as pirate attacks off Somalia's coast have decreased, with international patrols and armed guards on vessels contributing to the decline. The internationally-backed government has not officially confirmed his detention.

site_title: Action ashore needed to eradicate piracy
summary: Piracy has become a significant issue in the shipping industry, particularly in Southeast Asian waters, where incidents have increased despite efforts to minimize disruption. Unlike West Africa, where piracy was largely eradicated through robust government action, Southeast Asia requires similar measures to tackle the menace. The shipping industry must take proactive steps to address piracy, as it is not a "peril of the sea" issue that can be ignored. Effective action is necessary to prevent piracy from becoming a fact of life in the 21st century.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Singapore Airlines' budget carrier Scoot acquired 43.75% stake in Pete Air Co, renaming the joint venture NokScoot Airlines. SPH acquired a 22% stake in MindChamps Preschool for S$12m. KOP Limited plans to acquire land use rights for a Shanghai resort. Fischer Tech's CEO and chairman are trying to take the firm private with a S$0.16 offer per share. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Stanchart may pay US$300m over deal violation
summary: Standard Chartered is close to agreeing to pay up to $300 million to settle claims with New York's banking regulator over alleged violations of anti-money-laundering controls. The settlement follows a 2012 accord in which the bank agreed to improve its controls and face "remedial actions." The bank's shares are down 10% this year due to the fine, which is expected to be announced this week. The deal also includes a renewal of the independent monitor's contract for two years.

site_title: World's biggest iron ore port faces strike, A$100m daily loss
summary: Australia's largest iron ore port, Port Hedland, is facing a potential strike by tugboat crews, including deckhands paid more than some New York bankers, over wages and working conditions. The strike could result in an estimated A$100 million daily loss and disrupt shipments of half of Australia's iron ore exports. Talks between the unions and the port's operators are ongoing, with engineers seeking changes to working patterns and masters aiming for increased pay. A strike could have a short-term impact on the share market, but the likelihood is considered extremely low.

site_title: HK-based startup raises US$6.5m Series A funding
summary: GoGoVan, a Hong Kong-based startup, has successfully raised US$6.5 million in Series A funding led by Centurion Private Equity. The mobile app connects users with a network of delivery service providers, processing over 1 million transactions with an aggregate value of over HK$120 million since its launch last year. With the funding, GoGoVan plans to expand its operational capacity, hire more programmers, and accelerate expansion into other major cities in the South-east Asian market, aiming to cement its leadership position and validate its unique value proposition.

site_title: Awaiting the first commercial satellite
summary: Singapore's new Satellite Systems Centre, a $60 million facility, has opened to support satellite design and development. The centre will aid in the launch of TeLEOS-1, the country's first commercial Earth observation satellite, in Q4 2015. ST Electronics, a 23-year-old supplier of ground-based satellite communication networks, will utilize the facility to produce satellite components and whole satellites. The satellite's high revisit rate will enable more up-to-date haze monitoring and maritime surveillance, and the Singapore government aims to grow the space industry, creating high-value jobs and driving economic growth.

site_title: From the 'new normal' to a 'secular stagnation'
summary: A new e-book from the Center for Economic Policy Research (CEPR) explores the possibility that the US and Europe are stuck in a prolonged period of sluggish economic growth, dubbed the "new normal." The concept, first proposed in 2009, suggests that economic growth will not bounce back sharply after a crisis-induced downturn, but instead will persist at a slow pace with high unemployment. The notion was initially dismissed as unrealistic, but has since gained traction. The e-book examines the implications of this "new normal" for policymakers, academics, and investors.

site_title: Kong was indifferent to church's losses: Chew
summary: Former City Harvest church fund manager Chew Eng Han questioned Kong Hee about his handling of church funds, alleging he was "not that concerned" about losses. Chew presented evidence, including an unreleased album that cost the church millions, and questioned Kong's decision not to liquidate copyrights to pay back losses. Kong denied any wrongdoing, citing his desire to balance church duties with the trial, and claimed he had tried to minimize losses. Kong also denied using church funds for personal expenses, including a S$3 million purchase of preaching materials and S$2.1 million sent to a Malaysian church.

site_title: MAS postpones release of Q2 earnings
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) has postponed the release of its second-quarter earnings until next Thursday, citing no reason for the delay. The airline is expected to report a large loss due to the impact of the MH370 disappearance and the loss of MH17, leading to a fourth consecutive year of losses. MAS is set to be taken private by its majority shareholder, Khazanah Nasional, as part of a restructuring package expected to be announced by the end of August, which will likely be the carrier's last set of results as a listed company.

site_title: Call made to build world-class SMEs
summary: Singapore's SCCCI president Thomas Chua calls for the development of world-class small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the city-state, emphasizing that their products, services, and technologies must compete globally. He notes that SMEs need to be in a position of strength to attract local talent, and those that are struggling will be less competitive. A survey by the SCCCI found that 83% of companies have been hit by rising business costs, with 46% reporting thinner profit margins. To address these challenges, 90% of companies have stepped up their productivity drives, with 73% applying for government productivity grants.

site_title: Patience needed for Wing Hang to bloom
summary: OCBC Bank successfully closed its exclusive talks to buy Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank, with the rights issue announcement marking the end of the acquisition process. The deal, worth S$3.3 billion, will be completed on October 1, with Wing Hang's assets of S$34.9 billion expanding OCBC's Greater China presence. OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien reaffirmed the bank's capital ratios and dividend policy, while also acknowledging the challenges of integrating the smaller bank into its operations.

site_title: Nikko to base multi-asset team in S'pore
summary: Nikko Asset Management has chosen Singapore as the base for its global multi-asset solutions capability, citing the maturation of the industry here. The firm will transfer and manage $24 billion of assets out of Singapore, led by Al Clark, with a focus on delivering a 3% return above Sibor. Nikko AM's multi-asset approach aims to understand asset price drivers, allocate to "appropriately priced" risk, and focus on downside risk to limit losses. The move is driven by growing demand for multi-asset funds and tailored solutions to navigate volatile markets.

site_title: Citic unit not in bid for Biosensors
summary: A private equity unit of Citic Group has decided not to proceed with its takeover bid of Biosensors International Ltd, a medical equipment-maker. Citic Private Equity Funds Management Co Ltd, which holds an indirect 21.8% stake in the company, informed Biosensors of its decision. This comes after Biosensors' shares fell 10% this year following the withdrawal of the takeover bid.

site_title: China/HK developers lead bids in Potong Pasir tender
summary: A state tender in Singapore's Potong Pasir area saw 15 bids, with China/Hong Kong developers dominating the competition. Top bidder MCC Land offered S$775 psf ppr, beating out Cheung Kong Holdings' S$756.73 psf ppr bid. The site, next to a MRT station, is considered choicer due to its commercial component. Developers are optimistic about the market, with some expecting to sell units at prices above S$1,400 psf and retail units at S$4,000-5,000 psf.

site_title: AirAsia CEO rubbishes Skymark bid report
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes has denied reports that the airline is considering a bid for Japan's Skymark Airlines, saying it is focused on a new budget airline in Japan. Despite the denial, Skymark's shares surged 28% after a report by the Nikkei business daily. AirAsia is planning a low-cost airline with Japanese partners, including Rakuten Inc, but Skymark has not been approached by the airline. Analysts say the airline's financial viability and regulatory issues make a takeover unlikely.

site_title: More smaller firms make it to fastest-growing list
summary: Singapore's Fastest Growing 50 (FG50) Awards has seen 17 smaller firms with sales below S$100 million make the list, up from 6 last year. Homegrown SMEs account for 10 of the winners, including Lionapex International and Imperial Treasure Cantonese Cuisine. The list identifies companies with 10%+ annual growth and profitability over three years. German chemical giant LANXESS topped the list with a 6,246.8% three-year compounded annual growth rate, the highest in the award's 13-year history.

site_title: DBS named best Asia-Pacific bank
summary: DBS Bank has been named the best bank in the Asia-Pacific region by Global Finance magazine's World's Best Banks 2014 Awards. Citi won global awards for best corporate bank, emerging markets, and other categories, while Santander took the global award for best consumer bank. Winners were selected based on performance over the past year and subjective criteria such as reputation and management excellence. This marks DBS Bank's first time receiving the top Asia-Pacific bank award.

site_title: Profiting from troubled housing loans
summary: Private equity firms and institutional investors are profiting from unrated bonds backed by troubled US mortgages, with yields of around 4% and quick payouts. Mutual funds, including those from JPMorgan Chase and Edward Jones, have invested in these bonds, which are often sold by government agencies like the US Department of Housing and Urban Development to avoid losses. The market is expected to grow as there are still billions of dollars in delinquent mortgages in the US, and regulators aim to close the chapter on the housing crisis.

site_title: FAA bars American airlines from flying over Syria
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has barred American airlines from flying over Syria due to the ongoing conflict posing a "serious potential threat" to civil aviation. The ban applies to all US-registered planes, commercial operators, and FAA-licensed pilots, with exceptions for flights operated with US government permission and foreign-registered aircraft. The decision follows a similar ban on US airlines flying over Iraq earlier this month.

site_title: Great disturbance in the banking Force
summary: McKinsey analysis suggests that digital disruption can either destroy or create up to 50% of total profits for Asian banks, with 15% of profits potentially shaved due to margin erosion and 10% lost to overall competition. However, banks can also gain from cost savings and innovation, with the potential for a 30% increase in profits from new product sales. Regulations remain a major hindrance, but around 40% of Asian mass-affluent customers prefer online or mobile banking, and younger customers are increasingly opting for digital banking.

site_title: More payment delays in Q2, especially by construction sector
summary: In Singapore's Q2, local companies showed less promptness with bill payments, with the construction sector experiencing the most delays, falling below 50% for the first time since Q3 2013. The construction sector saw a 4.5 percentage point drop to 47.4%, with payment delays exceeding 40% for the first time. Industry experts attribute the issue to manpower shortages, rising labor and operating costs, and the inability of builders to restructure quickly.

site_title: Maersk raises profit forecast, plans share buyback
summary: Maersk, a Danish shipping and oil group, raised its full-year profit forecast to $4.5 billion, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company attributed the boost to its container shipping segment, Maersk Line, which is expected to earn profits "significantly" above 2013 levels. Maersk also announced a $1 billion share buyback program and plans to evaluate additional buyback opportunities. The company's net profit in the second quarter rose to $2.25 billion, driven by gains from the sale of a majority stake in Dansk Supermarked and impairment of Brazilian oil assets.

site_title: UK's Monarch to be budget carrier, cuts staff
summary: Monarch Group, a UK-based holiday airline operator, plans to cut its workforce by a third and close its charter operations to focus on scheduled European flights as a budget airline. The company aims to reposition itself as a smaller rival to Ryanair and easyJet, with plans to reduce staff numbers by 1,000 and aircraft numbers to 30. Monarch will move to scheduled-only flying from summer 2015, with 85% of its operations currently scheduled flights. The transformation is part of a strategic review initiated by new management, with further announcements expected.

site_title: Marco Polo and Nam Cheong join forces
summary: Marco Polo Marine and Nam Cheong have formed a joint venture to expand their businesses, particularly in chartering. Marco Polo Offshore, a 50-50 JV, has secured a long-term five-year bare-boat contract worth over US$27 million. The joint venture also owns a newly-built accommodation work vessel, which will support a regional offshore and marine services provider. The move aims to combine strengths in ship-chartering and ship-building, offering comprehensive service offerings to chartering clients.

site_title: Global number of container ships peaks
summary: The global number of container ships has peaked, with 5,088 vessels as of August 2014, despite a decline in the number of ships due to over-capacity caused by the economic downturn. The fleet's capacity has increased by 6% annually, primarily from larger ships, not an increase in the number of vessels. Around 230 new ships are scheduled for delivery this year, with deliveries expected to decrease to 180 next year.

site_title: Olam sells 25% of packaged food business to Sanyo
summary: Olam International is selling a 25% stake in its packaged food business to Japanese noodle manufacturer Sanyo Foods for US$187.5 million. The deal aims to capitalize on growth opportunities in sub-Saharan Africa, where the region's growing population and rising income levels are driving demand for packaged food. Olam will retain majority ownership and management control, while Sanyo brings expertise in emerging markets. The deal is expected to be completed by October-December this year and may increase to US$212.5 million if specific performance milestones are met.

site_title: US housing market picks up, inflation pressures muted
summary: US housing starts rebounded 15.7% in July to a 1.09-million unit pace, snapping two months of declines. Consumer prices increased 0.1% in July, edging up inflation. The Federal Reserve's slow approach to exiting monetary accommodation appears to be supported by these data points. Interest rates are expected to remain steady until mid-2015, as inflation remains below the Fed's target of 2%.

site_title: Modi to make 'significant' visit to Tokyo soon
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to visit Japan at the end of this month for a three-day trip, marking a significant economic and strategic move. The visit comes as Japan seeks new alliances to counter China's growing economic might and Modi aims to bolster ties with Japan. The trip is expected to produce new agreements on economic cooperation and reinforce mutual cooperation in areas such as infrastructure development and software production. Analysts see the visit as a key step in elevating Indo-Japanese relations and encircling China.

site_title: Logistics Hldgs bags S$66.5m MOE works
summary: Logistics Holdings secured S$66.5 million in contracts from the Ministry of Education (MOE) for building, turfing, and planting, maintenance works, alteration & addition, and renovation & refurbishment projects at three schools. The four-year contracts start from September 1. This is the latest in a series of successes for the group, which has secured S$180.2 million in contracts since the beginning of the year, with other recent wins including a S$72-million HDB contract and a S$9.95-million Progen Holdings contract.

site_title: Diesel cars in vogue now
summary: Diesel cars are gaining popularity in Singapore due to fuel efficiency, lower pump prices, and improved low-end torque. The number of diesel-powered cars has increased by 40-50 cars per month, reaching over 100 in the last four months, with 2,097 diesel passenger cars as of July 2014. This growth is significant, as diesel cars were once rare on Singapore roads. The rise is partly attributed to the carbon emissions-based vehicle scheme (CEVS) rebates and the COE recategorisation.

images.alt_text: The population of diesel-powered cars has been increasing by a minimum of 40 to 50 cars per month in 2013, but has since advanced to more than 100 in the last four months - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: London leads sharp August drop in UK home prices
summary: UK home prices fell sharply in August, with London leading the decline. Asking prices dropped 2.9% from July, and 5.3% annually, as the market prepares for higher interest rates. The decline was attributed to a surge in properties coming onto the market in London and stricter mortgage lending rules. The Bank of England views the housing market as a significant risk to Britain's economic recovery, and the slowdown may ease the need for interest rate hikes.

site_title: US fastest-growing shale play lacks pipelines, low-cost trucking
summary: The US has allowed exports of ultra-light crude oil from the Eagle Ford Shale, bypassing the Permian basin due to its lack of pipelines and high trucking costs. Producers like Pioneer Natural Resources Co. are shipping condensate from Eagle Ford to the Gulf Coast, rather than Permian, where it would be more expensive to transport. The Permian's rapid growth and increasing light oil production have created opportunities for shale producers to sell their byproduct, condensate, into higher-priced foreign markets.

site_title: Good tutorial on retirement planning
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's Retirement Planning 101 presentation aimed to educate the public on the intricacies of financial planning. The CPF Minimum Sum is a default retirement capital amount meant to generate a steady stream of income, but it may not be enough for many retirees. Individuals need to calculate their personal "Magic Number" to determine how much they need for retirement, taking into account factors such as inflation, savings capacity, and debt management. A systematic process of financial planning is crucial to achieve financial independence, and investors should prioritize saving, investing, and debt management to supplement the CPF Life annuity.

site_title: Savills rebrands property management arm
summary: Savills is rebranding its property management arm to Savills Property Management, following a merger in 2011. The unit, previously named SavillsCKH, aims to leverage the Savills brand for growth. The company expects the name change to reinforce its position as an integrated real estate consultancy in Singapore and the region. CEO Chris Marriott praises the team's excellent service and outstanding reputation, anticipating future growth in office, retail, and asset-management services.

site_title: Kong lied to his followers, says Chew
summary: Former City Harvest Church investment manager Chew Eng Han accuses church founder Kong Hee of lying to followers about a $500,000 deficit in a bank account set up to support Kong and his wife Sun Ho. Chew denies knowing about alleged royalty round-tripping and claims Kong lied to followers about the account's purpose and deficit. Chew faces 10 allegations of criminal breach of trust and falsifying accounts, and his defense questions Kong's credibility.

site_title: Analysts downgrade some STI stocks
summary: Analysts downgraded eight Straits Times Index (STI) component stocks, citing poor profits, slower revenue growth, and stock price run-ups. The affected stocks include ComfortDelGro, Genting Singapore, and SIA Engineering, with some analysts slashing their target prices by up to 27%. Despite this, three local banks - OCBC, DBS, and UOB - remained favored by analysts, with DBS having no "sell" calls and UOB's outperformance potentially reversing in the second half.

site_title: Lump-sum CPF withdrawal, lease buyback change hailed
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that retired citizens can withdraw part of their CPF savings in a lump sum, subject to limits, and expanded the lease buyback scheme for HDB flats to four-room flats. While observers welcomed the flexibility, they cautioned against blowing away retirement savings and urged the government to educate citizens about the implications of lump-sum withdrawals. They also suggested that the government consider withholding certain amounts of top-ups or grants to discourage unnecessary withdrawals.

site_title: GreenOak seeks at least US$500m for 2nd Asia fund
summary: GreenOak Real Estate LP plans to raise at least $500 million for its second Asia fund, targeting Japan, Korea, India, and possibly Hong Kong and Singapore. The company, which already has a Japan-focused fund, aims to capitalize on increasing demand for Asian property. GreenOak has a strong track record, with its US fund now at $850 million and investors including General Motors' pension plan and Franklin Templeton Investments. The fund's potential for diversification and strong returns make it attractive to institutional investors.

site_title: Finnair in the red for Q2, sees significant loss for full year
summary: Finnair, a state-controlled airline, reported a significant loss in its Q2 due to delayed cost cuts and tough market conditions. The company cut its full-year profit forecast, citing stiff competition, high fuel prices, and unfavourable exchange rates. Finnair had previously reached annual cost savings of 176 million euros but faces challenges in implementing further cost cuts due to strong labour union resistance. The airline is committed to reaching its target of 200 million euros by the end of the year and is making progress in negotiations with pilots and staff.

site_title: Windfall for Gol Linhas' bonds investors
summary: Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA, Brazil's largest airline, has seen its bond returns surge 21% this year due to its record-breaking passenger numbers. The airline has narrowed its net losses by more than half and its US$500 million of notes have rallied since beating sales estimates. Moody's has raised its outlook on Gol to positive, predicting a possible rating upgrade. Revenue rose to 2.4 billion reais in the second quarter, beating analysts' estimates, and the airline's costs increased 20% due to fuel price hikes.

site_title: OCBC to raise S$3.3b from rights issue
summary: OCBC Bank announced a S$3.3 billion rights issue to pay for the acquisition of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank, offering up to 440 million new shares at S$7.65 each. The founding family shareholder, the Lee group, will take up 26.7% of the rights issue, while the remaining 73.3% is underwritten by Merrill Lynch, HSBC, and JP Morgan. The issue price represents a 25% discount to the closing price of S$10.20 per share. The acquisition is expected to expand OCBC's funding access in international currencies and enhance its Greater China strategy.

site_title: Singapore's NODX falls at a slower 3.3% in July
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted 3.3% year-on-year in July, marking a slower rate of decline than in previous months. Shipments to the US, EU, and China have shown signs of improvement, providing hope that the manufacturing sector may be bottoming out. This slower decline offers some relief to the sector, which has been experiencing a third consecutive month of contraction. The data suggests a possible turnaround in the manufacturing sector, although the overall trend remains cautious.

site_title: Home prices in July fall in majority of Chinese cities
summary: China's new-home prices fell in July in 64 of the 70 tracked cities, with prices declining in 64 cities, the most since January 2011. Tight mortgage lending deterred buyers despite local governments easing property curbs. Beijing prices dropped 1% for the first time since April 2012, while Shanghai and Guangzhou saw the largest declines, each dropping 1.2% and 1.3% respectively. The slowdown in the housing market is attributed to high mortgage rates and cautious buyers, with developers cutting prices to lure buyers.

images.alt_text: Taking a hit: Prices have dropped in 64 of the 70 Chinese cities last month from June, the most since January 2011. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: PM Lee's call for culture shift lauded by employers, unions
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong called for a culture shift to consider workers' abilities and aptitude beyond university degrees. Employers and unions welcomed the message, citing the need for diverse paths to success. A committee will be formed to help Institute of Technical Education and polytechnic graduates with job placement and career advancement. The committee will implement recommendations to recognize non-graduates' potential and offer in-house training programs.

site_title: Eratat unit forged 577m yuan bank statement: CBRC
summary: China's bank regulator, the CBRC, has found evidence of forgery in a forged bank statement by Eratat Lifestyle, a mainboard-listed fashion company. The statement claimed a cash balance of 577 million yuan, but was actually forged by Eratat's subsidiary. Representatives of the subsidiary may have impersonated ABC bank staff to reassure independent auditors and company directors. The discovery is likely to affect retail investors who own 75% of the company, with a market valuation of nearly S$50 million before trading was suspended in January.

site_title: Chain stores using mapping software to pick locations
summary: Wendy's uses mapping software, developed by Esri, to analyze data on potential restaurant locations nationwide. The data program helps predict annual sales and assess demographic factors such as income and household types. This analysis saves the company around $750,000 annually. Retailers are increasingly using geographic information systems to optimize real estate decisions, focusing on areas with potential employees and business operations.

site_title: Geo Energy wraps up US$55m acquisition of coal mine
summary: Geo Energy Resources has completed the US$55 million acquisition of a 66% stake in Borneo International Resources, increasing its coal reserve bank to over 40 million tonnes. This acquisition, along with its existing 4,570-hectare coal mining concession, expands its presence in the region. The deal will also raise its coal reserve bank from 11 million tonnes to over 40 million tonnes.

site_title: Swiber to fly Mexican flag on five of its vessels
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore construction and support services provider, will fly the Mexican flag on five of its vessels in Mexico, solidifying its position in the rapidly growing oil and gas industry. The move is a reaffirmation of its commitment to clients in the country, following Mexico's energy reforms. The five vessels, deployed three years ago for a 77 km submarine pipeline project, will now operate under the Mexican flag, enabling Swiber to offer integrated solutions to the Mexico market.

site_title: Good performance by shipping stocks
summary: Singapore shipping stocks have seen a 3.1% year-to-date price gain, driven by the performance of companies like Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Industries, and Sembcorp Marine, which are among the top 11 stocks with a market capitalization of at least S$1 billion. Pacific Radiance (+61.1%), Vard Holdings (+31.9%), and Sembcorp Industries (+3.2%) were the top performers, with Pacific Radiance reporting a net profit of US$17.3 million for the first quarter. The strong performance is attributed to the growth of the offshore oil-and-gas industry.

site_title: Hotel Shilla JV picked as preferred bidder for Macau duty free shops
summary: Hotel Shilla's joint venture with Sky Connection Ltd has been picked as the preferred bidder for duty free shops at Macau International Airport for five years starting this November. The move pushed up Hotel Shilla's shares to a record high, with a 5.2% rise to 130,500 won per share. This is a significant opportunity for the company to replicate its success in South Korea's duty free market. The joint venture aims to capitalize on Macau's yearly revenue of around US$160 million, which could further boost Hotel Shilla's shares.

site_title: Help seniors make informed CPF decisions
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that individuals aged 65 and above can withdraw a portion of their Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings in a lump sum. This move aims to provide flexibility, but also warns of reduced retirement savings. The government emphasizes the importance of informed decision-making, suggesting that members receive necessary information and counseling before making withdrawals. Ultimately, the decision rests with the individual, who should use the money wisely and not squander it.

site_title: Skymark shares get AirAsia boost
summary: Skymark Airlines shares surged 28% to 230 yen in Tokyo trading, their largest gain in almost six years, as AirAsia was reportedly considering support, including a stake in the airline. Despite CEO Tony Fernandes' denial of interest, AirAsia is in discussions with financial institutions to help Skymark. The stock maintained its gain even after Fernandes' statement.

site_title: Foreign banks find the going tough in Saudi Arabia
summary: Foreign banks are struggling to compete in Saudi Arabia's banking market, leading to licence cancellations. International banks like Barclays, Goldman Sachs, and Nomura Holdings have shut down their operations, while local lenders dominate the market. Standard Chartered's CEO Boutros Klink attributes the challenge to the kingdom's restrictive activities and the ease of local lenders' ability to offer a full range of services. The opening of Saudi Arabia's stock exchange to foreign investment is expected to attract limited new international banks, and the country's debt market is expected to grow significantly in the coming years.

site_title: Global rubber glut seen tumbling in '15
summary: A global surplus of natural rubber is expected to shrink 46% in 2015 due to increased demand and reduced production, according to the International Rubber Study Group. Production is projected to outpace demand by 202,000 tonnes, while falling rubber prices have led to decreased tapping by farmers. The glut, which had increased output estimates for Thailand, is expected to decrease as the pace of economic expansion slows in China, the largest buyer.

site_title: New spring coming for Jurong Lake's gardens
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to revamp the Jurong Lakeside district, focusing on the Jurong Lake gardens and a new Science Centre. The area will be integrated into residents' living spaces, with new Housing Board flats and potential conversions of industrial land to residences. A new Science Centre is targeted for completion by 2020, and the Jurong Lake District is also proposed as a possible site for the high-speed rail terminus between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Grace Fu heads coordinating office for municipal services
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the creation of a new Municipal Services Office to coordinate inter-agency efforts and focus on service delivery. The office, led by Minister Grace Fu and Minister Khaw Boon Wan, aims to bridge gaps between various agencies and serve the public effectively. This move aims to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of municipal services, enhancing the overall quality of life for Singaporeans.

site_title: Early Aug's downward trend could resume
summary: US stocks may face a stormy week as traders reset odds on the Federal Reserve's interest-rate increase. Despite a strong second-quarter economic growth of 4%, investors are cautious due to the potential for inflation and a rate hike. The Fed is expected to end its quantitative easing program in October, but some analysts believe a stock-market crash is still possible. A 10% correction, which has been absent for 34 months, is a concern, but many experts advise buying dips due to historically low recovery times.

site_title: Halt isolation of Ebola nations: Iata
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) has urged airlines to maintain services to Ebola-hit regions, citing the World Health Organization's advice that aviation is a "low risk" for Ebola transmission. Iata recommends screening passengers, applying rigorous procedures for suspected cases, and fully disinfecting planes. Despite this, several airlines, including Kenya Airways and Korean Air Lines, have suspended flights to affected areas, citing health concerns. Iata hopes that countries fighting the Ebola outbreak will continue to benefit from air connectivity, unless the advice changes.

site_title: Brunei Sultan bids for jailed tycoon's NY, London hotels: WSJ
summary: Brunei's Sultan has made a $2 billion bid for New York's Plaza Hotel, Dream Hotel, and London's Grosvenor House, owned by India's Sahara conglomerate. The bid comes as Sahara's chairman, Subrata Roy, negotiates a sale from a prison cell after failing to appear at a contempt hearing over unpaid investor bonds. The deal could be finalized as early as next month, despite public calls for the company to sell its properties due to Brunei's harsh new laws, including death by stoning for homosexuals and adulterers.

site_title: China aircraft lessor ICBC aims to double jet deliveries
summary: China's largest domestic aircraft lessor, ICBC Financial Leasing Co, aims to deliver more than 300 planes to customers by the end of 2016, nearly doubling current levels. The company, backed by state lenders, is expanding into a market dominated by global players, with nearly 6,000 new commercial jets expected to be delivered over the next 20 years. ICBC Financial's managing director, Mark Jiang, stated that local companies have huge growth potential in the aviation business.

site_title: Out of the box
summary: Subscription retail services have gained popularity in Singapore, with over 10 new services launched in the first eight months of 2014. These services, such as Birchbox, offer monthly deliveries of curated items, including trial-sized samples and full-sized products, to customers' doorsteps. The model works by allowing buyers to commit to a subscription for a set period, with box curators sourcing products from brands and running e-commerce stores for repeat orders. This innovative retail format is becoming increasingly popular, with both local and international companies participating in the market.

site_title: Foreign planters cast wary eye on Indonesian bill
summary: Indonesia is considering a bill that would cap foreign ownership of palm oil estates at 30% if passed, potentially hurting operations and earnings of foreign planters. The draft law aims to maximize land usage, protect local homes and livelihoods, and achieve better environmental controls. If passed, the bill would have a retrospective effect and could lead to mergers between foreign and Indonesian companies, with the Indonesian side holding greater bargaining power. The bill's passage could have significant consequences for foreign investors, with some analysts predicting a negative impact on the investment climate.

site_title: Major CPF policy shift on the way
summary: Singapore is set to introduce a policy shift in its Central Provident Fund (CPF) scheme, allowing individuals aged 65 and above to withdraw a portion of their savings in a lump sum. The exact cap will be revealed later, but Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong suggested limiting it to 20% of total CPF funds. The move aims to provide flexibility for those who need urgent cash, while also ensuring they have enough for retirement. The government will also raise the CPF Minimum Sum to $161,000 for those turning 55 in 2015.

site_title: Further monetary easing seen helping EU nations
summary: The European Central Bank is under pressure to implement quantitative easing to counter a potential recession in Europe due to stagnant economies and business sentiment. Germany's GDP contracted by 0.2% in the second quarter, while France and Italy experienced zero growth. EU sanctions against Russia and counter sanctions against EU agricultural products are also feared to drag economies downwards. Economists and media outlets are calling for full-scale quantitative easing to regenerate contracting economies, with ECB President Mario Draghi having already announced interest rate cuts and attractive loans to banks.

site_title: Thai Airways plans 1,500 job cuts this year
summary: Thai Airways plans to cut 1,500 jobs this year as part of its restructuring plan, aiming to reduce costs by 4 billion baht (S$156 million) and increase revenue by 3 billion baht. The airline expects to return to profit in the fourth quarter and shed over a quarter of its full-time employees by 2018. Thai Airways has faced five consecutive quarters of losses due to high operating costs and a decline in passengers, but expects an increase in tourists during the year-end holidays.

site_title: House of exhibits
summary: David Chua and his fiancée Jeannie Ong's shophouse on East Coast Road is a unique gallery showcasing their antiques, furnishings, and collectibles from around the world. Designed by architect Kee Wei Hui, the space features intricately carved timber screens, antique Chinese cupboards, and Peranakan artifacts. The couple's travels have also inspired unique features, such as a geometric art piece on the floor and a bespoke Mondrian-inspired shelf on the second storey. The home's eclectic mix of old and new items has raised eyebrows among friends, but the couple hopes to pass down their collection to their future children.

site_title: AirPooler, Flytenow not operating legally: FAA
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has determined that AirPooler Inc and Flytenow Inc, which connect pilots with passengers willing to split fuel costs, are not operating legally due to existing regulations. The decision bars the sharing of commercial aviation services, hindering the growth of the sharing economy in air travel. AirPooler plans to study ways to adjust its service to make it legal within existing regulations, while the companies will continue discussions with the FAA to explore possible solutions.

site_title: Jurong Lake area to be new draw for developers
summary: Singapore's Jurong Lake District is expected to gain value with the introduction of leisure elements and a potential high-speed rail terminus. Plans include the realignment of the Ayer Rajah Expressway, waterfront housing, and the development of Jurong Lake Gardens, which will integrate a revitalized park, gardens, and a new Science Centre. Developers are likely to take interest in future state land tenders, with some expecting a minor boost to existing projects and increased interest in the area. The government's efforts aim to enhance the area's liveability and cement Jurong as a unique lakeside destination for business and leisure.

site_title: Singapore shipping - the ports, products and plays
summary: Singapore is a major global trade hub, with over 1,000 vessels in its port at any given time. The city-state's shipping industry is closely linked to the global economy, with commodities such as coal and iron ore derivatives playing a significant role. Freight rates and shipping costs are influenced by factors like vessel size, distance, and cargo type. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) offers a range of freight products, including futures and forward freight agreements (FFAs), to manage freight rate risk and gain exposure to the market. Iron ore and coal are among the most widely traded commodities, with Singapore emerging as a key trading center for both.

site_title: Indonesian economy: The Jokowi boost
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to remain positive under the new Jokowi administration, driven by consumer confidence, low core inflation, and a growing middle class. The government's pragmatic and pro-business approach, coupled with key reforms, is expected to enhance GDP growth and create opportunities for foreign investors and Singapore businesses, particularly in consumer, oil and gas, automotive, and healthcare sectors. The administration's focus on infrastructure improvements, public services, and labour relations is seen as a positive step for businesses, and Singapore companies can contribute to Indonesia's development strategies.

site_title: T-Mobile flop won't deter SoftBank: analysts
summary: SoftBank's failed bid for T-Mobile, a $32 billion offer, won't deter billionaire founder Masayoshi Son from pursuing his goal of building "the world's number one company." Despite regulatory opposition, Son has repeatedly expressed his desire for a stronger number-three carrier to compete with US market leaders Verizon and AT&T. Son, 57, remained tight-lipped about the failed bid, saying only that he is "always exploring various options." The failed T-Mobile acquisition is seen as a rare defeat for Son, but analysts expect him to continue his acquisition strategy.

site_title: Helping ITE, poly grads move up the ladder
summary: Singapore will set up a tripartite committee to help Institute of Technical Education (ITE) and polytechnic graduates find right jobs and advance in careers. The committee, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, aims to develop an "integrated system" of education, training, and career progression for all Singaporeans. The committee will promote industry support and social recognition for individuals to advance based on their skills. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong also emphasized the importance of economic growth and cultural change to create opportunities for workers to advance.

site_title: Boldness grounded in tradition
summary: Gaylin Holdings, a Singapore-based company, is expanding its business with plans to enter new markets, including Europe, despite maintaining traditional business principles. The company, led by CEO Desmond Teo, has achieved significant growth, with a 30.4% increase in revenue and a 15.9% surge in net profit. Gaylin has also completed the acquisition of a 51% stake in Rig Marine Holdings in the Middle East, giving it a foothold in new markets. Teo's bold approach to expansion is built on a strong corporate strategy, with a focus on delivering high-quality products and services to customers.

site_title: Sinarmas Land buys London building
summary: Sinarmas Land has acquired a freehold prime commercial building in London, 10 Great Pulteney Street, for £57.28 million (S$119 million) through a sale and purchase agreement with GE Real Estate. The building, located in Soho, is fully leased to Creston plc on a "triple net lease" agreement, with Sinarmas Land receiving a net rental. The acquisition marks a significant expansion of Sinarmas Land's international presence.

site_title: Parked United B747 punctured in collision with towed plane
summary: A United Airlines Boeing 747 was grounded after being punctured in a collision with a towed plane near an O'Hare Airport hangar on July 28. The accident occurred when the wide-body United jet's wing sliced open the parked jumbo jet's hull. No one was on board the jumbo jet, and no injuries were reported. The incident led to weeks of repairs, but no further details were provided.

site_title: ECB takes tougher line on shipping loans
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is taking a tougher stance on shipping loans, valuing them more conservatively to ensure eurozone banks have enough capital to withstand future crises. This move is crucial for banks in Germany, particularly Commerzbank, HSH Nordbank, and NordLB, which have significant shipping loan portfolios. The ECB is demanding a 12% prudential haircut on shipping loan models, which could lead to larger losses for German banks and potentially force them to raise more capital.

site_title: Amazon adding more art to its programming
summary: Amazon is expanding its original programming to attract new customers to its Prime subscription service. The company has unveiled four new series, including the Emmy-nominated show "Transparent," and plans to invest $100 million in original content. Amazon's approach differs from its initial foray into TV production, which was driven by data analysis, and is now focused on creating artful and nuanced content. The company's goal is to inspire passion and prove meaningful to groups of people, rather than seeking blockbuster hits.

site_title: June retail sales up a tad, thanks to motor sector
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 0.4% year-on-year in June, driven by a 12.4% increase in motor vehicle sales, which would have otherwise resulted in a 2.1% decline. Petrol service stations, medical goods, and food & beverage also saw year-on-year growth. However, recreational goods, telecommunications apparatus, and watches & jewellery experienced contractions. Overall, total sales value for June was S$3.2 billion, marginally up from the previous year.

site_title: Visually exciting cuisine
summary: Corner House offers a carefully scripted fine dining experience with visually exciting cuisine. Located at 1 Cluny Road, Nassim Gate, the restaurant provides a unique dining experience. However, the article does not provide further details about the restaurant's offerings or reviews.

site_title: More players tussling for property dollar here
summary: Australian company Walker Corporation has opened a sales office in Singapore to promote its domestic projects and its Senibong Cove project in Malaysia, which is being developed with Iskandar Waterfront Holdings. Meanwhile, Guangzhou-based R&F Properties has launched Princess Cove, a 3,200-unit project in Iskandar, with prices starting from RM1,100 per square foot. The move is seen as part of the tussle for Singaporeans' property dollar, with more players competing for the market. Walker Corp's chairman, Lang Walker, believes the company will build on natural demand and not oversupply homes in Iskandar.

site_title: One more Chinese developer wants a slice of Iskandar
summary: Chinese property developer Weiye Holdings is expanding into Malaysia's Iskandar and Singapore, with plans to develop homes and commercial projects in the next six months. Group chairman Zhang Wei hopes to capitalize on Malaysia's "My Second Home" program and Singapore's proximity to Shenzhen, which benefited from its proximity to Hong Kong. Weiye is also looking to expand into China's first and second-tier cities, including Shanghai and Shenzhen, with a focus on securing land cheaply and working with local companies. The company's net gearing is 27%, offering room for borrowing and capital expenditure.

site_title: Singapore to honour its first president, Yusof Ishak
summary: Singapore will honor its first president, Yusof Ishak, with three new tributes: a mosque in Woodlands named Masjid Yusof Ishak, a renamed Institute of Southeast Asian Studies (Iseas) think tank, and a Yusof Ishak Professorship in Social Sciences at the National University of Singapore.

site_title: D&O Insurance - Do you need it?
summary: Directors and Officers (D&O) Insurance provides liability coverage for directors and company officers in case of losses resulting from business decisions. Despite misconceptions, D&O Insurance is necessary for directors to protect against potential lawsuits and ensure good governance. In Singapore, 87% of listed companies and 42% of private companies offer D&O Insurance, with coverage amounts ranging from S$10 million to S$30 million. Personal D&O Insurance is also available for individual directors, providing up to S$1 million coverage in three directorships.

site_title: Malaysia's GDP expands 6.4% in Q2
summary: Malaysia's GDP expanded 6.4% in Q2, exceeding expectations and potentially prompting the central bank to raise interest rates for the second time this year. This growth is driven by domestic demand, with private consumption and investment increasing, and exports accelerating. The strong performance may also lead to a reevaluation of the government's budget deficit target and could prompt the central bank to tighten monetary policy.

site_title: Delays hit hospital's opening
summary: The Ng Teng Fong General Hospital in Jurong East, set to open in December 2014, will be delayed by about six months due to construction delays. The Ministry of Health plans to add 150 beds by the end of 2014 and speed up existing efforts to increase capacity. The 280-bed Changi General Hospital-St Andrew's Community Hospital Integrated Building will open in stages between December 2014 and mid-2015.

site_title: Fresh US$60m funding to boost Foodpanda's reach
summary: Foodpanda, a food delivery site owned by Rocket Internet, has secured US$60 million in funding, bringing its total funding to over US$100 million. The company, two years old, is available in 40 countries across Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America. This investment round is part of Foodpanda's efforts to expand globally, further solidifying its position as a leading player in the food delivery market.

site_title: Darts group takes aim at Asian market
summary: The Professional Darts Corporation (PDC) is hosting the inaugural Singapore Darts Masters in Singapore, featuring the world's top eight players competing for a $100,000 cash prize. The event aims to build a global interest in darts, with Asia being a key development region. The PDC, which sells over 500,000 tickets worldwide annually, hopes to capture the imaginations of Singaporean darts followers and potentially make the sport a professional career option. The event is expected to draw a crowd of at least 2,000 people and a television audience of up to 10 million.

site_title: Temasek diversifies China bets into tech, consumer sectors
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean investment firm, has diversified its bets on China by purchasing US-listed stocks in technology and consumer sectors. In the second quarter, it bought 602,139 American depositary receipts of JD.com Inc and 603,764 ADRs of Cheetah Mobile Inc, valued at $17.2 million and $12.8 million, respectively. This move aims to extend its reach in China and ease reliance on the nation's banks. Temasek's investments in China now include consumer-related firms, as it shifts away from bank holdings.

site_title: Sponsor Boustead takes the swing too
summary: Boustead, a B2B infrastructure company, has made its debut in the BT Corporate Golf League as a participating team, fielding a team of 10 players. The team, led by captain Donovan Sia, has accumulated 285 points and is currently in eighth position. Sia believes the team can achieve a mid-table position by the end of the competition, citing the league's networking opportunities and challenging golf courses as key factors in their success.

site_title: Defending champs widen lead
summary: Team SunMoon has widened their lead in the Business Times Corporate Golf League, scoring the highest total of 316 points after three rounds. They are seven points ahead of SPH Sultans of Swing and 18 points ahead of Team Emerio. The team's captain, Tan Teck Lee, and members Gary Loh and Donald Teo have impressed with their scores, including the highest score of 108 in Tuesday's round.

site_title: Albedo in a fix over botched RTO deal, dismal H1 results
summary: Albedo, a Singapore-based steel-maker, has reported dismal half-year results, with a net loss of S$18,000 and revenue falling 24% to S$6.14 million. The company's struggles come after a botched S$1.86 billion reverse takeover deal with Malaysian billionaire Danny Tan, which ended with Albedo agreeing to settle for S$500,000. The company's shares have fallen to 1.5 Singapore cents, and its efforts to find new businesses have so far failed, with a previous attempt to acquire miner Coeur Gold Armenia also failing.

site_title: Market up for the week but volume stays low
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 19.94 points to 3,314.77 on August 14, driven by gains in the Jardine group. Despite a 26-point weekly gain, low trading volume of 1.56 billion units and S$964 million was reported, with brokers expressing cautious views. Geopolitical tensions and a rebound on Wall Street helped support prices. Penny stocks like Mirach Energy and Japfa were among the top performers, while Genting Singapore reported a 21% drop in Ebitda and Citi Research cut its forecast earnings due to a higher bad debt provision.

site_title: Swissco units bag US$94.8m charter deals
summary: Swissco Holdings announced that four subsidiaries have secured US$94.8 million charter deals with an oil major in Latin America, lasting up to two years. The mobile offshore drilling units will support the oil major's activities. This deal is expected to positively impact Swissco's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2014.

site_title: Lui unveils plan for S$6.2b train-bus depot
summary: Singapore is set to build the world's first integrated bus and train depot, estimated to cost S$6.2 billion, to improve the city-state's congested transport system. The depot, located at the end of the new Thomson-East Coast Line, will house 220 trains and 550 buses. The facility will require only 36 hectares of land, compared to four separate depots occupying 80 hectares. The depot's construction is expected to begin in 2016, with the line set to be fully operational by 2024.

site_title: Developers hard-pressed to price projects modestly
summary: Developers in Singapore are facing challenges in pricing their projects modestly amid a soft market. Many developers bought land at high prices to replenish their stock, leaving them with limited room to adjust prices. To attract buyers, developers are adopting strategies such as offering discounts on lower-end units and reducing prices on existing projects.
