This approach has shown success, with some projects experiencing increased sales after price cuts. Experts predict that a 10-12% price cut could draw buyers into the market, but a price war is a possibility if one developer sharply cuts prices relative to others.

site_title: UOB chairman joins ACR Capital
summary: United Overseas Bank's chairman, Hsieh Fu Hua, has been appointed as the independent chairman of risk solutions group, ACR Capital Holdings, replacing Thaddeus Beczak. Hsieh brings 40 years of experience to the role, having previously led UOB and Tiger Airways Holdings. ACR's gross written premiums rose 21% to US$924 million in FY13/14, with gross technical results growing 76% to US$102 million. Hsieh aims to help establish ACR as a leading risk solutions provider in the region, working closely with management to drive growth.

site_title: Double duty for DHL this year
summary: DHL is participating in a golf league for the third time, with team captain Sunny Yap citing the enjoyment of the sport and the great courses chosen by the organisers. The team, which is not in the competitive category, will play at Jurong Country Club in the final round. Yap praised the organisers for bringing the league to new levels each year, allowing the team to interact with customers in a fun and unique way. The event is seen as a way for DHL to give back to the community and enjoy the sport.

site_title: Director buying rises, selling falls
summary: Singapore's director buyback activity rose, with 27 purchases worth S$4.05 million, while sales fell, with only one disposal worth S$0.10 million, according to filings on the Exchange from Aug 11-15. Companies with notable buyback activity include GSH Corporation, Nordic Group, MTQ Corporation, and Manufacturing Integration Technology. Notable purchases were also made by Serial System's chairman, Sam Goi Seng Hui, and Sinjia Land's CEO, Cheong Weixiong. Xyec Holdings' Employee Stock Holding Association also made a significant purchase.

site_title: Linksys repositions itself to cater to SMB market
summary: Linksys, a pioneer in indoor wireless connectivity, has re-entered the small and medium-sized business (SMB) market with a three-pronged strategy under its new parent company Belkin. The company aims to empower SMBs with comprehensive and cutting-edge networking solutions, delivering flexibility and reliability. Linksys, which was founded in 1988 and previously owned by Cisco, plans to launch a range of networking hardware and a smart cloud-based networking management platform, with a focus on automation systems and remote network management. The move is seen as a powerful value-add to Belkin's range of products, with the global SMB market expected to spend US$560 billion this year.

site_title: Regional integration 'key for jobs, growth'
summary: Singapore's Minister of Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang emphasized the importance of regional integration for jobs, growth, and better living standards. He noted that Asian countries' open and connected economies have helped them stay resilient, but more integration is needed to stay relevant. Despite the challenges, Lim supports free and open multilateral trading systems, citing Singapore's success in liberalizing its financial sector. The country is involved in regional free trade agreements such as the Trans Pacific Partnership and Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, aiming to improve economic efficiency and lower trade barriers.

site_title: Pretty gardens by the Bay
summary: The Singapore Garden Festival, held outdoors at Gardens by the Bay, features 50 gardens and flower displays, including a raised garden, vertical garden, and fantasy garden. The festival won several awards, including Gold and Best of Show for "Sacred Grove" and Silver awards for "Vertical", "Full Circle", "Winter Illusion", and "A Garden of Hers". The event showcases the creativity of landscape designers in a natural setting, with some displays using innovative materials and techniques to create unique and dynamic spaces.

site_title: In the driver's seat
summary: KNUD Erik Hansen, 63, is the CEO of Carl Hansen & Son, a Danish furniture maker. He joined the family business in 2002 after his elder brother sold his shares and asked him to take over. Under his leadership, the company expanded from 17 to 250 employees, invested in new machinery, and bought two new factories in Denmark. Hansen aims to double the company's size over the next three years, with sales exceeding S$100 million worldwide. He plans to collaborate with non-Danish designers, including Japanese architect Tadao Ando, to shake up the company's design approach. Hansen's sons, 20 and 21, are interested in taking over the business, and he plans to step down when they do.

site_title: KrisEnergy's Q2 loss falls to US$5.8m
summary: KrisEnergy reported a Q2 loss of US$5.8 million, down from US$8.2 million a year ago, despite revenue rising 33.5% to US$22.3 million due to higher oil output and prices. The company's Ebitdax more than doubled to US$11.1 million. Gross production at its Bangora field in Bangladesh exceeded expectations, with CEO Keith Cameron predicting significant growth in proved plus probable reserves within the next 12 months. KrisEnergy also made progress on its development portfolio, with plans for final investment decisions in Thailand and Indonesia.

site_title: India probes plunge of Jet Airways flight
summary: India's aviation watchdog is investigating a Jet Airways flight that plummeted 5,000 feet over Turkish airspace in August 2014. The incident occurred when the co-pilot was using a flight management device, claiming she didn't realize the aircraft had lost altitude. The pilots have been taken off duty pending inquiry and will be questioned. The investigation will assess if the pilots were adequately trained and if fines should be levied.

site_title: Top hedge funds flock to takeover target Allergan in Q2
summary: Top hedge funds, including billionaire investor William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management, have made new bets on takeover target Allergan Inc during the second quarter, with Ackman's stake increasing to 9.7% and other funds like John Paulson's Paulson & Co and Jamie Dinan's York Capital Management also buying in. The filings show that several mutual funds, including T Rowe Price, doubled their positions in the company, while some investors, like Capital Research Global Investors, cut their stakes by half. The takeover bid, valued at $49 billion, has become increasingly bitter, with proxy advisory firms urging shareholders to support Ackman's call for a special meeting.

site_title: Woody Allen's latest: a dalliance with the unseen
summary: Woody Allen's latest film, Magic in the Moonlight, follows magician Stanley Crawford, played by Colin Firth, as he challenges a female mystic, Sophie, played by Emma Stone. As Stanley's skepticism is slowly eroded, he finds himself falling for Sophie, who possesses "mental vibrations" that defy rational explanation. The film explores themes of mortality, the hereafter, and the power of mystery, suggesting that sometimes, logic is insufficient and a bit of magic is necessary.

site_title: CDL steps up diversification plan
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has outlined its diversification plan in response to challenging headwinds in the Singapore property market. The company aims to expand into new geographies, such as Japan and Australia, and develop fund management products. CDL plans to monetize existing assets and potentially adopt a discretionary fund management model. The company also has plans to establish a real estate investment trust (Reit) and explore opportunities in the US and UK. Despite a 33% drop in Q2 profit, CDL remains optimistic about its long-term prospects.

site_title: Banks expand cash management radar
summary: Banks in Singapore are expanding their cash management and transaction services to smaller companies, a move driven by tighter competition and increasing demand from mid-sized firms. These banks aim to offer services such as liquidity management, interest rate management, and market expansion to help companies limit risk and optimize cash flow. By providing these services, banks can earn fees and increase market share, while also building stronger relationships with smaller firms.

images.alt_text: SELLING POINT Citi tries to differentiate itself by focusing on providing a suite of services to clients, most of which have ambitions to go global, and can benefit from Citi's global network. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Tiffany to a T
summary: Francesca Amfitheatrof, Tiffany & Co's first female design director, has unveiled her debut collection, Tiffany T, featuring versatility and utilitarian glamour. The minimalist, sleek designs strike a balance between being on-trend and timeless, perfect for the contemporary dresser. Amfitheatrof's diverse background, including work at Chanel, Fendi, and Alice Temperley, has equipped her to oversee various aspects of the business, including jewelry, advertising, and store displays. The collection is expected to be a commercial hit, marking a new beginning for the brand.

site_title: S'pore companies deemed ready to tackle Ebola
summary: Singapore companies are considered well-prepared to handle an Ebola outbreak, despite a global survey finding that half of multinational companies worldwide lack pandemic policies. Experts cite Singapore's past experiences with Sars, bird flu, and H1N1 as reasons for its preparedness. However, smaller firms and those with limited risk assessment divisions may still struggle to develop effective business continuity plans. The Singapore government and private sector are taking proactive steps, including an emergency preparedness drill at Changi Airport, to bolster confidence in the country's preparedness.

site_title: Schizophrenic biopic of a flawed Indonesian patriot
summary: The biopic "Soekarno" tells the story of Indonesia's first president Sukarno during the country's Dutch colonial period and Japanese occupation in World War II. The film explores Sukarno's rise to power and his relationships with women, but fails to fully examine his flaws and private life. Despite its flaws, the film offers a glimpse into Sukarno's charismatic leadership and his role in Indonesia's struggle for independence. The film features Ario Bayu as Sukarno, with supporting performances from Maudy Kusnaedi and Tika Bravani.

site_title: Nissan Nouveau
summary: Nissan has unveiled a sportier version of its Qashqai crossover, featuring a new direct injection engine, sportier styling, and improved driving features. The car boasts a more masculine design, with a "3D" clamshell bonnet and full LED lights, and comes with standard 19-inch wheels. The engine now produces 144 hp and 200 Nm, thanks to the new direct injection feature, and the CVT transmission has been improved with Active Lock-Up Control. The Qashqai also features improved handling and braking systems, including Electronic Power Assisted Steering and Active Trace Control.

site_title: Catfights galore in The Women
summary: A Malaysian production of the 1936 play "The Women" by Clare Boothe Luce is set to be staged at the Esplanade Studio, directed by Alin Mosbit. The play, which explores catfights and backstabbing among women over men, has been adapted to fit the 1950s Singapore context, featuring a large all-female cast. Director Alin aims to highlight the importance of female support and kindness, while actress Siti Hajar notes that societal issues, such as infidelity and social media, are the root cause of problems, not technology itself.

site_title: Japfa ends first-day trading on firm note
summary: Japfa, Indonesia's agri-food company, ended its stock trading debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at 84.5 Singapore cents, a 5.6% gain from its IPO price of 80 Singapore cents. The mainboard counter was the third most active stock, with 68.7 million shares traded. Japfa's stock performance was a firm note for its first-day trading, despite being overshadowed by other market news.

site_title: From mothers to mothers
summary: Victoria Beckham teams up with e-tailer The Outnet to sell over 600 clothing items in aid of charity Mothers2Mothers, which works to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV/AIDS. The charity sale, running from August 20-25, features iconic pieces from Beckham's wardrobe, including items from her early days with the Spice Girls and catwalk appearances. The funds raised will help the group reach more HIV-positive mothers and reduce the stigma associated with HIV.

site_title: Tat Hong Q1 profit down
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane supplier, reported a 28% decline in net profit to S$5.96 million in its first quarter, down from S$8.24 million last year. Revenue fell 6% to S$164 million, with the distribution division contributing the majority of the decline. The division saw a 14% drop in revenues due to falling excavator sales in Indonesia.

site_title: Chinese art painter feted - 27 years after his death
summary: A Chinese art painter, Fan Chang Tien, is gaining recognition 27 years after his death, thanks to a private gallery show and a definitive book published by his daughter, Teresa Yao. The book, "Fan Chang Tien - the Literati Artist," features 166 paintings and describes Fan as a master of ink painting, calligraphy, poetry, and seal carving. Fan mentored an entire generation of eminent ink artists in Singapore and was a pioneer of the Shanghai School of Painting. His daughter's book is a labor of love that aims to preserve his legacy and promote Singapore's ink painting tradition.

site_title: The science of protection
summary: L'Oreal expert Dominique Moyal explains that for sun protection, applying SPF15 or higher is recommended, but SPF50 is not necessary. It's also crucial to look for creams or lotions that screen out both UVA and UVB radiation, especially in intense Asian sun conditions. SPF standards were introduced about 30 years ago, but recent years have seen a better understanding of UVA radiation, making protection against it more clear. Moyal emphasizes the importance of using sun protection measures to protect against UVA radiation.

site_title: Japfa's IPO draws strong demand
summary: Japfa's initial public offering (IPO) drew strong demand, with its international offer 5.1 times subscribed and public offer 9.7 times subscribed. The IPO priced at S$0.80 per share, with joint global coordinators fully over-allotting 37.2 million shares to the international offer. Japfa's shares will commence trading today, following a successful subscription.

site_title: Project revenue recognition quadruples UE's revenue in Q2
summary: United Engineers (UE) reported a quadrupling of its quarterly revenue to S$1.22 billion in Q2 2014, driven by revenue recognition from properties Austville Residences and Eight Riversuites. Net profit also increased by 81% to S$42.34 million. The company remains cautious on property sales due to sector cooling measures, but is optimistic about its automotive business. UE expects construction demand in Singapore to remain strong, with a focus on productivity and technology adoption.

site_title: Dubai's top two builders turn to bank borrowings
summary: Dubai's top two builders, Arabtec Holding PJSC and Drake & Scull International, are turning to bank borrowings due to rising late payments from clients. Arabtec's money owed by clients reached 8.8 billion dirhams, while Drake & Scull took 199 million dirhams in term loans. The need for costly interest payments may slow project completion, despite rising orders, and is affecting cash flow and profitability. Delays and cost overruns in Saudi Arabia are also contributing to the financial pressure on the builders.

site_title: Equestrian ecstasy in a big top
summary: Cavalia, a big-top show, has arrived in Singapore, featuring equestrian performances, acrobats, and dancers. The show, which began its 2,500th performance, transports viewers to various environments with multimedia effects, showcasing the bond between riders and their horses. The show's energy and emotion are genuine, with a focus on the horses' character and the riders' interactions with them. Cavalia runs until September 14, with various ticket prices available, including regular seats, Horse Lover seats, and VIP packages.

site_title: Virgin America cabin crew vote to create first union
summary: Virgin America flight attendants voted to create the first union at the airline, ending its status as the largest US carrier without organised labour. The Transport Workers Union (TWU) won 58% of the ballots cast, with 828 employees eligible to vote. The union's establishment raises concerns about higher operating costs for the airline, which is partly owned by UK billionaire Richard Branson and is set to file for an initial public offering. Negotiations for a first contract will begin later this year.

site_title: More than a hatchback
summary: The Mercedes-Benz GLA200 is a compact SUV based on the A-Class hatchback platform, featuring a higher-riding body and wider stance. Despite the same wheelbase, the GLA-Class offers improved headroom and a slightly higher hip point, making it easier to get in and out of the vehicle. With its more imposing design, the GLA-Class appears bigger and more macho than the A-Class, despite not being substantially taller. The vehicle's design and features aim to provide a more premium driving experience.

site_title: It's tough paying tribute to an iconic leader
summary: A biopic about Indonesia's founding president Sukarno, "Soekarno," was released in January despite controversy over its portrayal and casting. The film's producer, Raam Punjabi, disputes claims by Sukarno's daughter that the film was not reverential enough. Despite negative publicity, the film has done reasonably well, but Raam hopes a wider release will help recoup its $2.5 million cost. Director Hanung Bramantyo aimed to show a balanced portrayal of Sukarno as both a hero and a human, with plans for alternative versions of the film.

site_title: MOH: No suspected case of Ebola in S'pore
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) has clarified that there is no suspected case of Ebola in the country. A Nigerian woman in her 50s, who arrived in Singapore with a fever, was isolated and sent to a hospital after initial reports of a possible Ebola case. However, she was later deemed not to fit the case definition and was discharged. The MOH will continue to monitor the situation and assess its measures.

site_title: QT Vascular's Q2 loss widens on expenses
summary: QT Vascular, a Catalist-listed company, reported a wider net loss for the second quarter, increasing to US$13.5 million from US$11.4 million, despite revenue tripling to US$3.23 million. Administrative and R&D expenses also increased. The company expects to ramp up sales of its Chocolate PTA and PTCA in the US and EU, while advancing regulatory approvals in Japan and China. Loss per share was US$0.02, compared to US$8.66 a year ago.

site_title: Danish carrier Norden sees no profit for this year
summary: Danish shipping company Norden reported a loss of $7 million in the second quarter due to low freight rates and falling demand in Asia. The company lowered its 2014 forecast to a loss of $60 million to breaking even, citing an Indonesian export ban and China's reduced transportation needs. Norden reduced its fleet size by 25 vessels and lowered freight rates for small and mid-range ships, which has allowed it to cut costs. The company's loss before interest and tax was $19.3 million, exceeding analyst expectations.

site_title: Around Town
summary: The Aliwal Arts Night Crawl returns tonight at the Aliwal Arts Centre, featuring multi-disciplinary performances and activities from over 20 outfits from the Kampong Glam community. The event includes performances by groups such as NADI Singapura and Ravindran Drama, as well as workshops and interactive activities like the Community Graffiti project. Admission is free, and local makers will also be selling handmade items. The Observatory celebrates the launch of their new album, Oscilla, with two shows at The Substation, while a photography exhibition and an exhibition on Fan Chang Tien - The Literati Artist are also running until August 19 and 18, respectively.

site_title: Mixed picture for POSH, Pacific Radiance, FSL Trust
summary: POSH, Pacific Radiance, and First Ship Lease (FSL) Trust posted mixed quarterly results. POSH saw a 57% drop in net profit to US$11.9 million, while Pacific Radiance surged 52% to US$34.4 million. FSL Trust reported a net profit of US$1 million, up from a net loss of US$7.2 million last year. Despite these variations, both POSH and Pacific Radiance reported revenue decreases, while FSL Trust saw revenue rise 7.8%.

site_title: UOL makes UK debut with £97m purchase in heart of London
summary: UOL Group, a Singaporean developer, has made its UK debut with a £97 million (S$201.6 million) purchase of a prime freehold land in London's Bishopsgate area. The site, which spans 3,200 square meters, will be developed into a 43-storey tower featuring a 190-room hotel and retail components. The acquisition marks Pan Pacific's entry into the UK market, with plans to operate a hotel on the site. The deal is part of a growing trend of Asian investors diversifying their portfolios in Western markets.

site_title: KS Energy's Q2 earnings soar on disposal gain
summary: KS Energy's second-quarter net profit surged to S$46.7 million, up from S$1.5 million a year ago, driven by a disposal gain of S$54.4 million. Revenue rose 44.1% to S$59.8 million, with the drilling segment contributing 93.9% of the group's revenue. The segment saw a 57.4% increase, mainly due to charter contracts in Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: Life becomes art in unique growing-up drama
summary: Boyhood, a 12-year filmmaking project by Richard Linklater, follows the growth of a young boy, Mason, from age 6 to 18, as he navigates adolescence. The film features a cast of child actors, including Ellar Coltrane and Linklater's own daughter, who undergo significant transformations over the years. Shot in 39 days, the film's unconventional approach captures the characters' growth organically, with a natural screenplay and impressive acting. The movie's running time is supplemented by a diverse soundtrack featuring over 50 songs, making it a heartwarming and epic coming-of-age drama.

site_title: Eurozone recovery stalls in Q2 as German, French economies sputter
summary: The Eurozone's economic growth stalled in Q2, with Germany's economy shrinking 0.2% and France's stagnating. Italy slid back into recession for the third time since 2008. Analysts attribute the slowdown to weak foreign trade and investment, despite consumer demand showing slight growth. The European Commission emphasizes the importance of structural reforms, while Germany's economy minister predicts a rebound in the remainder of 2014. Sanctions imposed on Russia over Ukraine are expected to further drag on growth, increasing uncertainty for the Eurozone.

site_title: Old-timers blow up the big screen again
summary: Action star Sylvester Stallone's "The Expendables 3" brings together a new cast of ageing action heroes, including Wesley Snipes, Mel Gibson, and Harrison Ford, to revive the lucrative franchise. The film tones down violence and introduces fresh faces, such as Kellan Lutz and Ronda Rousey, while maintaining its signature shoot-first-talk-later approach. The story follows Ross, who disbands his team and hires a new group to take on a rogue ex-member, Stonebanks, played by Gibson. The film is big and dumb, but its cast, including Arnold Schwarzenegger and Dolph Lundgren, brings back the franchise's signature charm.

site_title: Ensure no one falls through insurance crack
summary: Singapore's insurance industry is plagued by misconceptions and high commissions, leading to overpriced whole life policies and term assurance. A new direct sales channel mandated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore aims to change this by allowing consumers to compare prices and benefits online, without commissions. The channel is expected to lower product costs and enhance cash values, but may not reach the most vulnerable populations, who require low-cost insurance. The portal, launched by Providend, aggregates insurers' offerings and provides a platform for consumers to buy directly.

site_title: He'll paint the history of a turbulent era in 50 hours
summary: Performance artist Nikhil Chopra will paint and narrate a 50-hour performance in Singapore, depicting India's fight for freedom from colonial rule in the 1940s. The piece, titled after the female warrior Jhansi, explores themes of identity, nationality, gender, and class. Chopra's performance, commissioned by the Singapore International Festival of Arts, will blur the boundaries between art and life, and he demands the audience's participation and attention over the three-day-and-night show. The performance starts on August 15 and ends on August 17.

site_title: Shareholders of Goodpack okay KKR's bid
summary: Goodpack Limited shareholders have approved KKR's bid, making the takeover effective and binding. The shares will trade on the Singapore Exchange on August 27, with payment to shareholders expected by September 12. This comes after the court granted an order sanctioning the scheme of arrangement. The books closure date is September 1, marking the end of the approval process.

site_title: Little elbow room for premium airlines in budget-conscious India
summary: India's air travel market is expected to see intense competition in the full-service sector, with stiff competition between Air India, Jet Airways, and Vistara, a new venture between Singapore Airlines and Tata Sons. Analysts predict a "bloodbath" with potential airline consolidation, citing high operating costs and losses. The Indian market's growing population and increasing air travel penetration will limit the number of airlines that can sustain themselves, with only four strong pan-Indian airlines expected to remain.

site_title: Genting S'pore Q2 profit falls 27% to S$102m
summary: Genting Singapore's Q2 net profit fell 27% to S$102.29 million due to a net exchange loss of S$34.9 million from investments. Revenue rose 6% to S$751 million, driven by a 9% increase in gaming revenue. The company's first-half net profit grew 29% to S$330.78 million. Genting Singapore remains confident in its proposed projects, including a South Korea resort and a Japanese integrated resort bid.

site_title: Thai Beverage Q2 gain up 12%
summary: Thai Beverage's Q2 net profit rose 12% to 5.5 billion baht, driven by a 37.2% increase in first-half net profit. Revenue increased 8.7% to 40 billion baht, with gains in spirit, beer, and food businesses. An interim dividend of 0.15 baht per share was declared, payable on September 11. The company's stock price ended unchanged at 62.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Modular home builder in Brooklyn hard-pressed to find new home
summary: A modular home builder in Brooklyn, Capsys, is struggling to find a new location after its lease expires in two years. The company, which has produced over 4,000 modules, is facing high transportation costs and a competitive market. Despite Mayor Michael Bloomberg's recognition of modular construction's potential, Capsys' founder, Nicholas Lembo, is worried about closing down as the technology is gaining popularity. The company has been unable to find a suitable replacement for its current location in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where it has been operating since 2002.

site_title: Golden Agri: operations in Liberia unaffected by Ebola
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, a palm oil plantation company, has stated that its operations in Liberia are unaffected by the Ebola outbreak. Despite a 40% decline in Q2 earnings to US$27.3 million, the company expects to increase planting this year. To mitigate risks, Golden Agri has implemented preventive measures, including screening employees for illnesses. The company will review its business model in China, where the oilseeds industry faces challenges, and considers strategic alternatives.

site_title: Asiasons, Blumont in loss
summary: ASIASONS Capital and Blumont Group reported a loss for their financial second quarter, primarily due to unrealised fair value losses on financial assets. Asiasons posted a net loss of S$5.44 million, with revenue doubling to S$2.1 million, led by improved media sales and fund management fees. The company continues to struggle in raising funds for its fund management business.

site_title: A China-India convergence story
summary: A new book, "The Silk Road Rediscovered," argues that business synergies will drive a strategic rethink on bilateral engagement between China and India, leading to a multi-dimensional economic relationship. The authors, Anil K Gupta, Girija Pande, and Haiyan Wang, focus on the convergence of Indian and Chinese companies in each other's markets, highlighting successful growth experiences of companies like TCS and Lenovo. They predict that China will shift from manufacturing to services and India will expand manufacturing opportunities, making the Sino-India economic relationship significant in the future.

site_title: HK-listed firm plans casino in Saipan
summary: A Hong Kong-listed firm, Imperial Pacific International Holdings Limited, plans to build a US$3 billion casino resort complex in Saipan, a US commonwealth island in the Pacific. The move comes amid sluggish growth in Macau, where the company invests in a junket operator. The casino will be the first large-scale integrated resort on Saipan and has faced opposition from residents. Imperial Pacific has promised to distribute US$10 million in cash vouchers to address concerns.

site_title: Murakami returns with another solitary soul
summary: Haruki Murakami's new novel, "Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage", has been released. The book, published by Vintage, is a 400-page hardcover edition priced at S$29.96. This marks Murakami's return with another story about a solitary soul, following his previous novel.

site_title: Manila port logjam fans inflation concerns
summary: The Philippines is experiencing a severe port logjam six months after a truck ban took effect, causing a supply chain crisis that has fueled inflation and may hurt economic growth. Containers with goods from garlic to microchips are piling up at the main ports, with 12,000 stuck for over two months. The ban has led to a 9.6% decline in imports, increased costs for manufacturers, and layoffs affecting around 20,000 workers. The government has introduced measures to alleviate the congestion, but the situation is expected to continue impacting the country's trade and jobs.

site_title: Behind closed doors
summary: Exclusive events are popping up in Singapore, with password-required gatherings in design, music, and art scenes. The Redundant Shop's Back Door Access events, held monthly, bring designers and industry professionals together for talks and workshops. These events, inspired by similar private gatherings in Shanghai, aim to create an intimate experience for guests. Meanwhile, F**king Fridays, started by Flab Slab founder Jeffrey Koh, are gatherings of doodlers and toy collectors in his studio, with free-flow drinks and art-making activities. Sofar Sounds, a global music platform, has also launched in Singapore, featuring live music performances in private homes, with a focus on original and high-quality music.

site_title: Provision for lawsuit hits Kingsmen
summary: Kingsmen Creatives posted a 1.4% year-on-year dip in second-quarter net profit due to a one-off provision linked to a lawsuit in China. The company reported S$5.31 million in net profit for the quarter, down from S$5.39 million. Revenue rose 3.8% to S$82.9 million, with its retail and corporate interiors division seeing a 5.5% increase. Kingsmen expects to recognize S$278 million in contracts this year, and declared a dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: London leads UK housing slowdown
summary: London's property market is showing signs of cooling, with an index of values in the city dropping to a three-year low. Surveyors have cut their forecast for price growth as stricter lending rules weigh on the market. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a drop in demand and a decline in new-buyer inquiries, with respondents cutting their forecast for annual average home-price growth to 4.7% from 5.9%. The cooling market is attributed to increased borrowing costs and stricter lending rules, which are expected to prevent a return to excessive household borrowing.

site_title: Overhaul ahead for Zell's Equity Commonwealth
summary: Sam Zell and his team are overhauling Equity Commonwealth after an investor-led revolt, selling over $200 million of properties and moving the company's headquarters. The Chicago-based office landlord faces a challenge in remaking the portfolio of over 100 disparate properties in US suburbs with slower rent growth. The new strategy aims to cut costs and boost income, with some properties potentially being sold to take advantage of high demand from investors. Zell, 72, has a track record of maximizing investor value, but the changes are still in flux, and the company's future remains uncertain.

site_title: China's Wanda to launch foray into Australia
summary: China's Dalian Wanda Group will launch Wanda Australia, a billion-dollar arm to invest in Australian property development, including a Gold Coast high-rise complex. The company will hold a 55% stake in the Jewel development, with the remaining 45% held by the Ridong Group. This move could mark a new era of Chinese property investment in Australia, following a surge in investment in residential property over the past year. Chairman Wang Jianlin has already invested in London high-rises and a US movie chain, AMC Entertainment.

site_title: 80s hits, humour bring house down
summary: The musical "Rock of Ages" has been a hit on Broadway and the West End since its 2009 opening, with over 2,000 performances in New York alone. The show features 30 radio-friendly 80s hits and has been adapted into a successful movie starring Tom Cruise. A touring version of the show is currently playing in Singapore, bringing its signature blend of humor and nostalgia to audiences. The musical's lighthearted and irreverent take on 80s rock 'n' roll has earned it a ready audience, with many praising the cast's big voices and comedic performances.

site_title: Absence of fair-value gain hits Centurion Q2 profit
summary: Centurion Corp's Q2 net profit plummeted 86% to S$7.69 million due to the absence of fair-value gain, despite a 41% surge in revenue to S$19.88 million. Gross profit jumped 66% to S$13.01 million, driven by higher revenue from its accommodation business. The company reported a 49% decline in six-month net profit to S$30.31 million. Centurion cited healthy demand for its accommodation business and a diversified portfolio as positives, while the optical disc business remains challenging. The company plans to focus on cost control and restructuring to ensure positive cash flow.

site_title: Japan's machinery orders slide 10.4%
summary: Japan's machinery orders plummeted 10.4% in the second quarter, the steepest decline in five years, amid a surge in demand before a national consumption tax hike in April. The drop in core machinery orders, excluding volatile items, is attributed to pent-up demand and a shortage of industrial equipment. The Bank of Japan's tankan survey suggests a moderate recovery in the current quarter, but the Cabinet Office downgraded its assessment for the third consecutive month, citing a seesawing trend in orders.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q2 profit falls 10% to S$133m
summary: ST Engineering reported a 10% year-on-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$133.16 million, with revenue dipping 0.7% to S$1.59 billion. The aerospace sector, its largest contributor, saw a 9% decline in profit before tax due to higher operating expenses and unfavorable foreign exchange impact. The group's order book stood at S$13.4 billion as of end-June, and it expects revenue and profit before tax for FY2014 to be comparable to the preceding year.

site_title: Goldman in bid for 165b yen Tokyo office deal
summary: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is a final bidder for a Tokyo office tower, Pacific Century Place Marunouchi, valued at about 165 billion yen (S$2.01 billion). Secured Capital, part of Asian private equity firm PAG, is trying to sell the 32-storey building, which was bought for 144 billion yen in 2009. This deal could be the biggest office property deal in six years, driven by investors seeking properties in Tokyo due to expected price rebounds under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's growth policies.

site_title: Facing Goya defies all opera traditions
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) premiered "Facing Goya," a boundary-bashing opera directed by Ong Keng Sen, composed by Michael Nyman, and featuring a libretto by Victoria Hardie. The opera explores the use of Francisco Goya's skull in eugenicist experiments, from Nazi scientists to modern-day biotech companies. It raises questions about social engineering, ethics, and genetic manipulation, sparking a discourse on the ethics of scientific advancements. The opera's radical style and subject matter have sparked debate, solidifying Ong Keng Sen's reputation as an iconoclast.

site_title: Lawyers told us we were negligent: Kong Hee
summary: Singaporean pastor Kong Hee, founder of the City Harvest Church, testified in court, stating he was "shaken to the core" when lawyers told him he and his deputies had been negligent in managing the church's finances. Kong claimed he had consulted professionals on church plans, including bond investments and his wife Sun Ho's US album. The church is accused of misusing the building fund to boost Ho's music career, with plans for a promotional tour and TV appearances ruined due to investigations. Kong acknowledged he had not involved his wife in the planning and budgeting of the US album.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q2 profit rises 9.9% to S$75.7m
summary: ComfortDelGro's Q2 profit rose 9.9% to S$75.7m, driven by broad-based growth in all business segments, with revenue crossing the S$1 billion mark for the first time. Overseas operations accounted for 41.2% of revenue, and earnings per share increased to 3.55 cents. Bus revenue climbed 18.4% and taxi revenue rose 6.7%, but operating profit from taxi businesses only inched up 2%. The company declared an interim dividend of 3.75 cents and its share price closed four cents lower at S$2.56.

site_title: Swiber bottom line more than doubles
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore oil and gas services provider, reported a net profit of US$10.11 million for the second quarter, more than doubling from US$4.16 million in the same period last year. Revenue slipped 9.4% to US$219.33 million due to delayed projects. The company expects an improvement in its order book over the next two quarters, with a half-year net profit of US$58.18 million. CEO Francis Wong emphasized the need to improve operational performance and maximize cost strategies.

site_title: Photography sponsorships bear fruit
summary: Corporate sponsors are investing in photography exhibitions, showcasing the work of emerging and professional photographers. The City Developments Limited (CDL) Singapore Young Photographer Award and the ICON de Martell Cordon Bleu award are two notable examples, offering cash prizes and exhibition opportunities. These initiatives aim to nurture the arts scene in Singapore, promoting creativity and cultural identity. The exhibitions run from August 20 to September 5 at the National Museum of Singapore, with free admission. This trend is expected to continue, with property developer CapitaLand Limited running the annual "Building People" Photography Competition.

site_title: Dubai hotels sink to 18-year low - more than half empty
summary: Dubai's hotel occupancy plummeted to 45.4% in July, its lowest in at least 18 years, due to a surge in supply and declining demand. This marks a 11.8 percentage point decline from the previous year. The emirate plans to nearly double its hotel rooms to 160,000 by 2020, but revenue per available room fell 7.4% to 290.23 dirhams. The low occupancy rate is attributed to the hot summer months and Ramadan, coinciding with growing supply.

site_title: H1 subsales come after long holding periods
summary: A study by Ngee Ann Polytechnic found that most subsales of private apartments and condos in Singapore involved long holding periods, suggesting the seller's stamp duty (SSD) is effective in curbing speculation. In the high-end segment, nearly all subsale caveats were from units bought in 2009-2010, while in the mass-market segment, 73% of subsale transactions involved properties bought in the same period. The study also found that units bought in 2009 made the most profit, with an average gain of 24% in the Outside Central Region.

site_title: Making university learning more enjoyable
summary: Singapore's National University of Singapore (NUS) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have introduced policy changes to ease grade requirements for students, aiming to reduce pressure and shift focus away from grades. NUS allows freshmen to purge poor grades and lower entry criteria for honours courses, while NTU allows students to drop F grades in up to six courses. The changes aim to encourage enjoyment of learning and increase the number of Singaporeans in university, with the goal of having 40% of each cohort in university by 2020.

site_title: Japanese rush into flexi-rate mortgages raises concerns
summary: Japanese homebuyers are flocking to flexible-rate mortgages, with the proportion of such loans reaching 42.8% in February, the highest since December. This surge is attributed to the Bank of Japan's stimulus, which has made it cheaper to finance a home purchase. Borrowers are betting that interest rates won't rise significantly, but economists warn that this complacency could lead to a surprise when rates do increase. The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its stimulus until at least mid-2016, with yields predicted to rise to 0.9% by the end of 2015.

site_title: Most profitable CCR subsale in H1 yields S$3m gain
summary: A subsale transaction in Singapore's Core Central Region (CCR) yielded a S$3 million gain, the most profitable in the first half of 2014. The unit, a low-floor unit at Goodwood Residence, was purchased for S$8.5 million in 2010 and sold for S$11.5 million in May 2014, resulting in a 35% gain. The transaction also marked the highest percentage gain for a subsale deal in the period. In contrast, a quarter of non-landed private homes in CCR that changed hands in H1 resulted in a loss for sellers.

site_title: Results snapshot
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. The US stock market opened lower due to Trump's tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Capitalising Xtron to fund Sun's career 'was Chew's idea'
summary: The founder of the City Harvest Church, Kong Hee, testified that investment manager Chew Eng Han proposed using church funds to capitalize Xtron Productions to help singer Sun Ho launch her US debut album. Xtron issued S$13 million in bonds to the church in 2007, but documents showed concerns of insolvency by mid-2008. Kong claimed Chew suggested paying advance rental to Xtron to purchase a property, which would help Xtron redeem the bonds and be a "win-win situation" for both parties. However, the prosecution alleges the bond investments were "sham" and a cover-up of church fund misuse.

site_title: Fair-value boost for Koh Brothers' Q2
summary: Koh Brothers, a construction group, reported a 138% year-on-year surge in net profit to S$11.53 million for Q2 2014, driven by higher sales from its real estate division and a S$6.1 million fair value gain. Sales rose 7% to S$109.49 million, with gross profit improving 25% to S$17.37 million due to higher margins. Earnings per share more than doubled to 2.61 Singapore cents.

site_title: United Envirotech's Q1 profit surges to S$22.5m
summary: United Envirotech's net profit for Q1 rose to S$22.5m, a 391% increase from S$5.7m last year. Revenue rose 50.5% to S$66.3m, driven by a 58.9% jump in water treatment business to S$20.5m. The group believes growing demand for membrane-based water and wastewater treatment services in China, due to stricter discharge limits and water shortages, will drive future growth.

site_title: Japan's Q2 GDP shrinks 6.8% after tax hike
summary: Japan's Q2 GDP contracted 6.8% at an annual rate, the worst since the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, due to a slump in private consumption following the April national consumption tax hike. Despite this, government officials assert the economy is on track for recovery, with a turnaround expected in Q3. The contraction was narrower than the economists' consensus forecast of a 7% drop.

site_title: AsiaPhos shares up on mine permit extension
summary: AsiaPhos shares rose 3.2% to 16 cents after its wholly-owned subsidiary received an exploration permit for its Cheng Qian Yan mine in China's Sichuan province, expanding the area from 0.55 to 1.54 square kilometers. The permit is valid for two years. The company plans to convert this right to a mining right "as soon as practicable." AsiaPhos' CEO expressed satisfaction with the extension, citing rising rock output and increased exploration opportunities.

site_title: Candy Crush's King buys S'pore firm for up to US$100m
summary: King, the creator of Candy Crush Saga, has acquired Nonstop Games, a Singapore-based gaming startup, for up to US$100 million. The acquisition is part of King's plans to expand beyond casual games and leverage its massive player base. All Nonstop Games founders and employees will remain in the company, and the studio will continue to develop games. King sees Singapore as a hub for gaming talent and is looking to hire more developers as part of its expansion plans. The acquisition was formally sealed on August 6 with an upfront payment of US$6 million and up to US$84 million in contingent consideration.

site_title: Distribution for Q1 falls at Ascendas Hospitality Trust
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posted a Q1 distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.24 Singapore cents, down 3.9% from last year. The decline was partly due to a S$1.8 million cost incurred for unwinding cross-currency swaps. Despite this, the Reit's operational performance was healthy, with gross revenue rising 11.1% to S$53.3 million and net property income increasing 32.6% to S$21.5 million. The Reit plans to continue unwinding the swaps until they expire in June next year to buffer against currency volatility.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Cosco Corporation's subsidiaries, Cosco (Dalian) Shipyard and Cosco (Zhoushan) Shipyard, secured contracts worth over $470 million and $56 million, respectively. Global Logistic Properties signed five new lease agreements totaling 90,000 square meters in China. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Fresh signs of softness in China property market
summary: China's property market showed further signs of weakening in July, with real estate investment slowing and sales falling sharply despite government efforts to shore up the sector. Property investment grew 13.7% in the first seven months, down from an annual rise of 14.1% in the first half. New construction projects dropped 12.8% and property sales fell 16.3% in July, with some analysts predicting further cooling in the coming months. Local governments have eased restrictions on property purchases, but banks remain cautious in lending to developers and borrowers.

site_title: Offshore yuan usage stays on growth path
summary: China's offshore yuan usage continued to rise, reaching 18% of total trade in 2013, up from 3% in 2010. This growth is still relatively small compared to China's status as the world's top trading giant. China surpassed the US as the world's largest goods trader in 2012, with total imports and exports valued at US$4.16 trillion. Despite this, yuan usage remains less than 1% of global trade.

site_title: Trump goes on the prowl in India
summary: US real estate mogul Donald Trump is investing in India's hospitality industry, partnering with Pune-based Panchsil Realty and Lodha Developers Pvt to build luxury residential projects. The move comes after India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party secured a single-party parliamentary majority, loosening restrictions on foreign investment. Trump has licensed his name for projects in Mumbai, Pune, and Rio de Janeiro, with plans for a 7-hectare master-planned neighborhood in Mumbai and 104 mansions in Dubai.

site_title: Airbus A350 could reach Asia by skirting Russia, says Finnair
summary: Finnair, a Finnish airline, says the Airbus A350 could potentially fly from Europe to Asia without going through Russia's airspace if the country imposes sanctions. The airline has ordered 11 A350 XWB planes, set to be the first European airline to operate the aircraft. Finnair aims to double revenue from Asian traffic by 2020 and is cutting costs to stay profitable, including negotiating with staff to lower salaries. The airline plans to feature a unique business class with spacious seats and touch screens on all economy class seats.

site_title: Mori raises 13b yen in 10-year bonds
summary: Mori Building Co., Japan's largest closely-held developer, has sold its longest bond ever, raising 13 billion yen in 10-year bonds. The company aims to develop about 10 projects in Tokyo over the next decade, including the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Mori's long-term credit rating was raised to A by Japan Credit Rating Agency Ltd, citing its competitive edge in urban redevelopment projects and improving market conditions. The company plans to use the funds to repay debt and lock in borrowing costs with longer-maturity bonds.

site_title: Fall in 'other gains' hits Boustead's Q1
summary: Boustead Singapore's net profit for Q1 FY2015 fell 9% to S$16.1 million due to a 57% drop in "other gains". Adjusting for these gains, net profit would have been 29% higher. Revenue declined 2% to S$126.5 million, driven by a 9% increase in the energy division and a 4% rise in the geo-spatial technology division. The real estate solutions division saw a 11% drop in revenue due to a challenging business environment. Boustead shares ended trading down 1.5 cents at S$1.78.

site_title: PM Lee thanks the people as he marks 10 years in office
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong marked his 10-year term in office with a message of gratitude to the people and his predecessor, Goh Chok Tong. Lee expressed appreciation for the support and engagement of Singaporeans, as well as volunteers and grassroots leaders. He also thanked Goh for his guidance and assistance during his tenure, which included navigating the global financial crisis and implementing social policy packages. Lee vowed to continue working for Singapore, saying his team would do their best to address the country's challenges.

site_title: Panama Canal turns 100 tomorrow
summary: The Panama Canal celebrates its 100th anniversary on August 14, 2014, marking a century of maritime trade and engineering achievements. Built by the US after decades of failed attempts, the canal now handles 5% of the world's maritime trade and generates significant revenue for Panama. However, the canal faces competition from rival projects, including the new Suez Canal and Nicaragua's proposed canal, prompting Panama to expand its capacity to handle "Post-Panamax" ships.

site_title: S'pore tops Asia in Q2 office rental gains
summary: Singapore posted the strongest quarterly gains in office rentals in Asia, with a 4.6% increase in local currency terms. The average rental for Grade A office space was US$828 per square meter, making Singapore the third most expensive market after Hong Kong Central and Beijing's Central Business District. The growth is expected to slow down by the end of 2015 due to impending supply, but the e-commerce, IT support, and FMCG sectors are expected to continue growing.

site_title: Kong Hee: I was cautious in budgeting Sun Ho's album
summary: Kong Hee, founder of City Harvest Church, testified in court that he acted cautiously and conservatively when budgeting his wife Sun Ho's US music album due to the church's involvement. He aimed to minimize losses for the church's investment in Xtron Productions. Kong's defense team highlighted his lack of criminal intent and the involvement of his deputies in ensuring the budget was sound. However, the court heard that Kong pushed for worst-case profit and loss projections, and that one of Xtron's directors, Wahju Hanafi, bore the risk of losses if the album failed.

site_title: Q2 growth slows, but is still above forecasts
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.4% in Q2, above forecasts, but slower than Q1's 4.8% expansion. The manufacturing sector, primarily responsible for the slowdown, grew 1.5% year-over-year, while the services and construction sectors moderated. Despite hopes for a better second half, manpower constraints may weigh on labor-intensive segments. The government's revised forecast range of 2.5-3.5% for 2014 reflects expectations of a "modest pick-up" in the global economy.

site_title: Haw Par ointments soothe Q2 earnings
summary: Haw Par Corp reported a 10.2% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$59.5 million, driven by a 23.4% rise in healthcare sales and higher dividends from investments. The company's leisure and property businesses declined, with lower occupancy and intense competition affecting sales. Despite this, Haw Par remains optimistic, citing growing healthcare business and macroeconomic stability, and proposes an interim dividend of six cents per share.

site_title: SeD to take on China social media giants
summary: SeD, a Singapore-based company, is acquiring HotApps, a mobile-app firm, for S$98,000. HotApps will launch an app by the end of the year, offering instant messaging and e-commerce services in 24 countries. This move challenges Chinese giants Alibaba and Tencent, who dominate the messaging and e-commerce spaces. SeD's CEO, Chan Heng Fai, sees an opportunity to capitalize on the Chinese government's censorship of social media, which may affect larger players.

site_title: Ensuring MH17 won't happen again
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has established a task force to identify and close the gaps in the system that led to the 2014 downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17). The investigation has identified two areas for change: providing clear guidance to airlines on threats to passengers, crew, and aircraft, and establishing an international framework to regulate the design, manufacture, and deployment of anti-aircraft weapons. IATA, along with other aviation organizations, is working to ensure that civilian aircraft are never again targeted by military forces, prioritizing safety and the freedom of air travel.

site_title: Business travel seen costing more next year
summary: Business travel is expected to cost more next year due to higher demand and limited growth in supply of services, according to a report by Carlson Wagonlit Travel and the Global Business Travel Association. Global spending on business travel is forecast to grow 6.9% this year and 8.6% next year. Airfares are expected to rise globally by 2.2%, with the largest increases in India (4.4%) and Latin America (7%), while hotel prices will rise globally by 2.6% and in Latin America by 6.3%.

site_title: Tardy disclosures by Xpress Holdings
summary: Xpress Holdings, a printing firm, was queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on July 1 after a sharp spike in its shares traded. The company initially replied that it did not know of any reasons for the unusual volume, but later disclosed that executive chairman KK Fong had sold 29.3 million shares. On July 23, the company announced that several creditors had started legal proceedings against it and proposed a placement of new shares to raise funds to repay its creditors. The company's disclosures raise questions about why the details of the lawsuits were not disclosed earlier and why the market was informed only after a SGX query.

site_title: Lending in China falls to its lowest since 2008
summary: Chinese lending unexpectedly dropped to its lowest level since 2008, totaling $44.3 billion in July, according to the People's Bank of China. Economists had forecast higher levels, but the central bank attributed the slowdown to factors including better supervision and adjustments in the property sector. The lending figures may reflect ongoing weakness in China's residential property market, which drives demand for loans. Despite this, the bank stated that lending levels remain within a "reasonable range" and there has been no change in monetary policy.

site_title: Should you cancel your Integrated Shield Plans?
summary: A 76-year-old man is considering canceling his Integrated Shield Plan (IP) with Aviva due to the upcoming implementation of MediShield Life, which aims to cover everyone regardless of health status. The man's IP, Aviva MyShield Plan 3, has a high premium and limited benefits. With MediShield Life, he may be able to access higher-class hospital wards, but his premium will likely increase. The author advises the man to wait until MediShield Life is fully implemented in 2015 before deciding whether to cancel his IP.

site_title: SingTel to roll out mobile plans with WiFi integration
summary: SingTel has announced the launch of new mobile plans with WiFi integration, offering customers a premium high-speed WiFi network at shopping malls, MRT stations, and other public places. The combo plans, available from August 19, will replace existing plans and come with more talk time and SMS bundles, as well as unlimited WiFi usage until July 31, 2015. The WiFi network will provide connectivity five times faster than typical free public WiFi services and will be fully managed to ensure high-quality performance.

site_title: Pork segment boosts QAF's Q2 earnings
summary: QAF Ltd, the maker of Gardenia bread, reported a 300% increase in Q2 net profit to S$9.32 million, driven by higher profitability from its Rivalea pork business. The company's trading and logistics business also contributed to higher profits. However, revenue dipped 2% to S$253.6 million due to a stronger Singapore currency and lower sales from Rivalea's meat-trading activities. The company's bakery segment saw an increase in sales, but lower profitability due to higher distribution costs. QAF's counter closed at 86 cents, up one cent.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q2 net profit up 57.2%
summary: SBS Transit's second-quarter net profit rose 57.2% to S$4.96 million, driven by revenue growth of 12.3% to S$235.13 million. The bus segment saw a 10.3% increase in revenue, while the rail segment's revenue rose 20.9% due to the start of Downtown Line 1 operations. The company expects bus ridership growth to be maintained and rail ridership to increase, but notes that staff costs and depreciation costs are expected to rise due to the expansion of services.

site_title: Almost half of India billionaires' wealth held by 5 tycoons
summary: Five Indian billionaires, including Mukesh Ambani and Lakshmi Mittal, collectively control US$85.5 billion in personal wealth, accounting for 47.5% of India's total billionaire wealth. The top 103 billionaires in the country control US$180 billion, a 5.5% decrease from 2012. Most billionaires on the list made their fortunes through businesses in sectors such as oil and gas, steel, pharmaceuticals, and IT. The economic slowdown in India has affected even the super wealthy, with a 5.3% decrease in their collective wealth in 2013.

site_title: Credit bureaus to be licensed: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed regulations governing credit bureaus, requiring them to be licensed and maintaining data confidentiality, security, and integrity. Consumers rejected for loans may receive a free copy of their credit report, and licensed credit bureaus will be expected to provide this service. The two existing credit bureaus, Credit Bureau (Singapore) and DP Credit Bureau, will be given six months to meet new requirements, with the MAS able to investigate and impose fines if rules are flouted. This aims to strengthen consumer protection and fair credit reporting in Singapore.

site_title: Petra Foods posts US$12.37m Q2 profit
summary: Petra Foods reported a Q2 net profit of US$12.37 million from continuing and discontinued operations, down 10.6% from the year-ago period. Excluding discontinued operations, the profit attributable to equity-holders was US$13.2 million. Revenue from its branded consumer division grew 5.3% to US$131.8 million. The company's profit was impacted by increased selling and distribution costs.

site_title: Jet Airways to close budget units by year-end
summary: Jet Airways India Ltd plans to close its budget-airline units, Jetlite and JetKonnect, by the end of 2014, and operate under a single full-service brand. The move aims to achieve profitability by 2017. The airline will redesign its cabins to compete with Emirates and Singapore Airlines, and lease Airbus A380s from Etihad. This decision comes as India's aviation market faces significant losses, with carriers losing a combined 594 billion rupees over the past seven years.

site_title: Gaza port launched in 2000 gets a fresh lease at truce talks
summary: A Gaza port project, halted in 2000, is being revived as a key demand in truce talks in Cairo. The port, which could cost $100 million and take three years to build, aims to break the siege of Gaza and reduce its reliance on hostile neighbors. Palestinians view the port as a symbol of independence and a potential economic engine. However, Israel insists that Gaza must be disarmed before a permanent port can be built, and a temporary pier is being considered as a first step. The project could create 2,000 jobs and save millions in security fees, but its impact is uncertain and dependent on a durable truce.

site_title: Private equity firms in Asia need to do more: study
summary: Private equity firms in Asia need to improve their value creation strategies, lagging behind Western counterparts. A survey of 96 regional and international private-equity general partners found that 66% struggle with operational improvements due to cultural, linguistic, and regulatory differences. Minority ownership stakes and talent shortages are also major challenges. To overcome these, firms should build close relationships with company founders and senior management, and adopt a more structured approach to identifying viable operational models. This is crucial for creating value in the region, where economic growth and industry consolidation are increasing pressures.

site_title: Roadshow on new bus model ends next week
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will complete a key step in Singapore's new bus contracting model next week, ending a three-week roadshow with local and international operators. The roadshow aims to reach a "wider spread of potential tenderers" and gather proposals to meet commuters' needs. Many operators, including foreign firms Tower Transit and Veolia Transport RATP Asia, and local player Woodlands Transport Service, have expressed interest in participating in the tender process. The first batch of 24 routes will be launched in end-September, with the remaining nine packages to be released in phases by 2022.

site_title: New revenue source to save Pittsburgh
summary: Pittsburgh International Airport is seeking a new revenue source to save itself from financial struggles. The airport has discovered a significant natural gas reserve under its runways, estimated to be enough to power the state of Pennsylvania for a year and a half. Consol Energy will begin drilling its first well in the area, expected to generate nearly $500 million in revenue over the next 20 years. The airport will receive $20 million annually in natural gas royalties, significantly boosting its operating budget.

site_title: MAS mulls 15-20% job cuts
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) is considering 15-20% job cuts as part of a restructuring plan to revive the airline, which has been struggling with twin tragedies and hefty losses. The cuts would affect around 3,800 employees, including senior positions, and are expected to be done in a fair manner with severance packages. The airline's new business model aims to reduce costs and estimated losses in fiscal 2015. The plan has been proposed by Khazanah Nasional, the major owner of MAS, and has been met with skepticism by some, including former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: Ways to enhance market liquidity
summary: Singapore's local stock market has struggled with low liquidity, with a 33% year-on-year drop in the first half of 2014. A reversal of accommodative monetary policies and geopolitical risks have contributed to the issue. To boost liquidity, experts suggest introducing better quality international listings, reducing board lots to make high-priced stocks more accessible, and implementing market makers with safeguards. Other measures include expanding derivative hedging tools, equalizing access to research, and swift regulatory action. A plan to lower clearing fees is also considered.

site_title: Lithium batteries' explosion risk higher than thought
summary: New research reveals lithium batteries can explode and burn more violently than previously thought, raising concerns about their use on planes. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) conducted tests, finding that a lithium-ion battery cell can fill a cockpit with smoke for up to five minutes. The FAA is adopting ICAO's recommended standard for lithium battery cargo, but regulators face challenges in imposing stricter standards due to Congressional restrictions. The discovery has sparked debate about the safety of lithium batteries on passenger airplanes and the need for additional restrictions.

site_title: New faces in the CBD as global banks exit
summary: Global banks are exiting the central business district (CBD) in Singapore, with many downsizing their offices and handing over space to new tenants such as insurance companies, consumer product firms, and new-media companies. The shift is attributed to banks' focus on costs due to reduced profit margins, and regulatory requirements to hold more capital. Notable new tenants include Google, Twitter, Booking.com, and eBay, while landlords welcome the diversification, which makes their properties less susceptible to market cycles. This trend is also observed in major financial centers like Hong Kong, London, and New York.

site_title: Parkroyal hotel wins int'l building prize
summary: Parkroyal on Pickering won the prestigious FIABCI Prix d'Excellence Gold Award for building excellence. This is the fourth Singapore project to receive the award, with 48 total wins by Singapore projects in the past 18 years. The hotel's developer, UOL, also won three Singapore Property Awards. The awards ceremony, hosted by FIABCI Singapore, recognized projects for merit in design, aesthetics, functionality, and contribution to the community. This achievement showcases Singapore's competitiveness in the international real estate development industry.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Sino Construction issued a profit warning for the second quarter, expecting a "marginal net loss" due to restructuring costs. Dairy Farm acquired a 19.99% stake in Yonghui Superstore for 5.69 billion yuan. SPH appointed Chua Boon Ping as CEO for its SPH New Media Fund. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss in the second half.

site_title: Straco Q2 profit up 7.4%
summary: Straco Corp reported a 7.4% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$8.33 million for the second quarter, driven by a 20.1% increase in revenue. Visitorship at its two aquariums in China grew 22.4% to 840,000, contributing to the revenue growth. Administrative expenses increased 142.4% due to a foreign exchange loss. The company attributed the strong performance to the buoyant Chinese domestic tourism industry and the newly introduced China tourism law.

site_title: Non-oil exports forecast to fall 1-2% this year
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are forecast to dip 1-2% this year, with total trade growth expected to narrow to 1.5-2.5%. The country's trade promotion agency, IE Singapore, revised its growth forecast after a 2.3% decline in NODX in the first half of the year. The electronics sector, particularly, is expected to decline 13.8% in Q2, while non-oil re-exports (NORX) are seen as "resilient" with a 8.1% gain in the first half.

site_title: Services sector flexes its muscle in GDP, exports
summary: The services sector in Singapore has been gaining prominence, capturing a rising share of the country's GDP, from 64% in 2003 to 70% in 2013. Meanwhile, manufacturing's share has moderated from 26% to 19% over the same period. Services exports have grown in size, with their share increasing from 16% in 2003 to 23% last year. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) expects services exports to continue growing due to trends such as the servicisation of manufacturing and increasing demand for services in Asian economies.

site_title: Cathay profit surges but falls short of estimates amid competition
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a 14-fold increase in net income to HK$347 million (S$56 million) in the first half of 2014, surpassing median estimates but falling short of expectations due to increased competition from Middle East carriers. Passenger yields declined, and the airline forecast a better second half, with plans to add new planes and flights to the US and Europe despite a weak cargo market.

site_title: Good and bad news for bulk carrier owners
summary: Freight rates for bulk carriers are expected to rise globally as the economic recovery gains momentum, with growth in seaborne trade in bulk commodities projected to pick up to 9% this year. However, this is tempered by concerns over poor quality construction work on new ships, with insurer North P&I club warning of increased liability risk due to defective welds and other construction issues. Despite this, industry experts believe the market will return to a reasonable supply/demand balance, driven by a slowdown in fleet expansion and an increase in scrapping of older tonnage.

site_title: Foodpanda gets US$60m in fresh funding
summary: Foodpanda, a global food delivery platform, secured US$60 million in fresh funding, bringing its total funds raised to over US$100 million. The funding will be used to continue growth in existing markets, partner with more restaurants, and improve customer service. Foodpanda operates in over 40 countries and is expanding in Russia despite sanctions. The company plans to focus on strengthening its existing markets rather than expanding further, aiming to become the market leader in its current markets.

site_title: India finally opens US$20b door to spin off Reits
summary: India has approved the setting up and listing of real estate investment trusts (Reits) as part of a US$20 billion market. The trusts must own at least 5 billion rupees in assets and have a minimum investor contribution of 200,000 rupees. The introduction of Reits is expected to provide funding for cash-strapped developers, potentially unlocking the market and boosting economic growth. The new funding channel is expected to bring down developers' costs and increase project development. Reit-funded assets are estimated to reach US$20 billion by 2020.

site_title: Rise of a Chinese investment bank
summary: Chinese investment bank China Renaissance has rapidly grown in prominence, surpassing some major Wall Street names in underwriting Chinese companies' US IPOs. Founded by Fan Bao in 2004, the firm has built relationships with top entrepreneurs, including JD.com's Richard Liu, and secured deals for companies like Weibo and BitAuto Holdings. With over $3.5 billion in US listings this year, China Renaissance ranks No. 2, just behind UBS. The firm's focus on technology companies in China's "new economy" has driven its success, with Mr. Bao crediting his relationships and "hustle" for the firm's rapid growth.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: STARBURST Holdings reported a 276% increase in Q2 net profit to S$3 million, driven by revenue growth from S$2.4 million to S$7.9 million. Lindeteves-Jacoberg's net profit fell 9.6% to S$1.2 million, while China Taisan reversed a net loss to post a profit of S$11.3 million. Teckwah's net profit dropped 22.6% to S$1.7 million. IReit Global's IPO received strong support, with its placement tranche fully subscribed and the public offer 7.6 times oversubscribed.

site_title: APTT to pay H1 DPU of 4.12¢, on track to meet full-year forecasts
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported interim earnings, declaring a distribution per unit (DPU) of 4.12 Singapore cents for the half-year ended June 30, 2014. Total revenue for the half-year was S$156.40 million, with earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) at S$98.35 million. APTT is on track to meet its full-year forecasts, with total revenue and asset Ebitda expected to reach S$323.8 million and S$210.8 million, respectively. The trust also announced a change to its distribution policy, with semi-annual distributions to be replaced by quarterly distributions.

site_title: Valuetronics Q1 profit hits HK$33.9m
summary: Valuetronics reported a net profit of HK$33.9 million (S$5.5 million) for Q1 FY15, a 1.8% increase from last year. Revenue rose 2.5% to HK$626.6 million, driven by a 36.4% jump in industrial and commercial electronics revenue. The group aims to expand its customer base and product portfolio to improve profitability, despite challenges in the consumer electronics segment. The outlook for the remaining financial year is positive, with strong demand expected for its industrial and commercial electronics segment.

site_title: Delong back in the black for Q2
summary: Delong Holdings, a Chinese steel manufacturer, returned to profitability in the second quarter, posting a net profit of 71.19 million yuan, despite a 4.6% decline in revenue to 2.52 billion yuan. The company attributed the revenue drop to decreased average selling prices and sales volume. Gross profit margin rose 6.1 percentage points to 9.2% due to lower cost of sales. However, Delong expects a challenging near-term operating outlook due to slow demand and excess capacity.

site_title: Super Group Q2 earnings plunge 58% on lower sales
summary: Super Group, an instant beverage maker, reported a 58% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$15.65 million for the June quarter, due to weaker demand in certain South-east Asian markets and foreign exchange losses. Revenue declined 5% to S$131.68 million, and earnings per share fell to 1.35 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to lower Branded Consumer sales in Thailand, Malaysia, Myanmar, and weaker consumer demand. Despite this, the company remains optimistic about its future growth and expects to stay ahead of the competition.

site_title: Maybank's private bank business bets on customer base
summary: Maybank Singapore is expanding its private bank business, planning to open its first Orchard Road outlet dedicated to high-net-worth clients. The bank aims to attract clients with at least US$1 million in investable assets, targeting affluent individuals and families in Singapore and the region. With US$3 billion in assets under management, Maybank Private Wealth plans to grow to US$4.5-5 billion by year-end, focusing on its existing customer base rather than acquiring new clients from rivals.

site_title: OSIM in talks to add stores in Turkey, Russia
summary: OSIM International Ltd, Asia's largest massage chair maker, is in talks to expand its international franchise with stores in Turkey and Russia. CEO Ron Sim hopes to reach a deal by the end of the year. The expansion complements OSIM's fast-growing economies, particularly China, and will add 20-30 new outlets annually while closing underperforming stores. Despite Russia's economic sanctions, Sim says the company's plans will not be impacted, citing the franchise model.

site_title: HK-Shanghai stock gaps to disappear
summary: A stock market gap between Hong Kong and Shanghai is expected to disappear as an exchange link between the two cities is created, leading to a "one-China" market. Morgan Stanley analyst Jonathan Garner predicts the valuation gap will converge to zero over time. The planned tie-up, set to start in October, will give foreign investors access to the mainland market and allow wealthy Chinese investors to buy Hong Kong stocks. Despite initial concerns, the Shanghai Composite Index has rebounded 11% since mid-March, and several Hong Kong-traded companies, such as HSBC and Cheung Kong Holdings, are attractive to mainland investors.

images.alt_text: Mulling over data: While the Shanghai Composite Index has rebounded 11 per cent since mid-March on speculation that government stimulus will revive growth in the world's second-largest economy, the gauge has lagged behind a 20 per cent surge in the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index of H shares. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Luxury hotels are bucking the trend of declining tourist arrivals, experiencing strong growth. Maybank's private bank plans to open its first Orchard Road outlet. US stocks are expected to continue their rebound. Singapore-listed firms saw a 13.6% increase in combined profits in Q2. Roxy-Pacific Holdings is sitting on pre-sale revenues of S$955.4 million. The Chinese central bank is investing in Italian firms, and US regulators are seeking clarity on leveraged-lending rules.

site_title: Billionaire Kinder revamps oil pipeline empire to target rivals
summary: Houston billionaire Richard Kinder is consolidating his pipeline empire through a series of transactions valued at about US$44 billion. He plans to acquire his three companies, including Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, Kinder Morgan Management, and El Paso Pipeline Partners, to simplify his corporate structure, lower borrowing costs, and unify the company under a single stock. The move aims to make it easier and more profitable for Kinder to pursue expansion and acquisitions in a target-rich environment, amid pressure from investors to cut costs and increase profits.

site_title: Falcon Energy Q1 net dips despite revenue surge
