summary: Falcon Energy Group's Q1 net profit fell 2.4% to US$8.1 million despite a 3.5-fold increase in revenue to US$92.7 million, driven by its oilfield services division. The gross profit margin dropped to 13.8% from 35.5% due to lower margins from contracts secured in the second half of last year. Revenue from the marine division rose 12.4% to US$19.1 million, while the oilfield projects division remained unchanged. The company expects to start producing coal from its East Kalimantan concessions later this year, citing improved coal prices.

site_title: Serial System Q2 profit jumps 36%
summary: Serial System's net profit for Q2 2014 surged 36% year-over-year to US$5.01 million, driven by higher sales and revenue growth of 28% to US$262.92 million. The company expects to hit its revenue target of US$1 billion by end of the year, with a 22% topline growth. Serial System is also focused on its three-pronged strategy to increase revenue, deepen its value proposition, and improve internal efficiencies and margins.

site_title: Mitsui overcomes rating threat with BOJ stimulus
summary: Mitsui OSK Lines has overcome a junk rating threat after the Bank of Japan's stimulus package lowered funding costs for the shipping company. The company's bond yields fell to a record 22 basis points, helping it avoid a downgrade from Moody's Investors Service. Mitsui OSK Lines took advantage of the low borrowing costs to finance its liquefied natural gas business expansion. The company has maintained its profit forecast despite a 30% reduction in its annual net income. Moody's cited increased leverage as the main concern, but the company's efforts to boost its fleet and invest in LNG vessels may mitigate this risk.

site_title: CSE's Q2 profit down 35.5%
summary: CSE Global reported a 35.5% year-over-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$8.03 million. Revenue rose 16.3% to S$108.07 million, driven by growth in Asia-Pacific and the Americas. Gross profit increased 9.5% to S$31.5 million, with a 1.8 percentage point drop in gross profit margin. An interim dividend of 1.25 cents per share has been declared, down from 1.5 cents a year ago.

site_title: July private home resale volume flat
summary: Resale volume in Singapore's private residential market remained flat in July, with 431 units sold, down 20.5% from last year. Resale prices fell 1.3% to a 21-month low, with the high-end condo segment being the hardest hit. The city area saw a 4% decline, while city fringe and suburbs saw 1.1% and 0.6% declines, respectively. Analysts attribute the slowdown to cooling measures, weak leasing demand, and competitive pricing by developers. Rental volume rose 5.3%, but prices fell 0.8% to their lowest since May 2011, with city homes expected to decrease by up to 8% for the year.

site_title: Looking to frequent flyer plans for revenue
summary: Airlines are exploring ways to monetize their frequent flyer programs (FFPs) due to declining profits. FFPs, originally used to encourage customers to spend with one airline, now offer rich customer data to credit card providers, hire car companies, and hotels. Airlines are selling stakes in their FFPs, such as Air Berlin's 70% stake to Etihad, or spinning them off as separate units. Industry analysts expect more deals, spin-offs, and stock market listings as airlines unlock value from FFPs. The value of FFPs is estimated to be billions of dollars, with some programs valued up to 10 times their annual profit.

site_title: I always sought professional advice, says CHC founder Kong
summary: City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee testified in court, saying he always sought professional advice from church auditor Foong Daw Ching before making decisions. Kong claimed he trusted Foong's assurance that the church's finances were in good hands, and that he was hesitant to proceed without the auditor's approval. Kong also testified that the church retained Senior Counsel Jimmy Yim for corporate governance and that the church's building fund was used for legitimate purposes, including the Crossover Project. The trial continues with the prosecution raising concerns of a possible satellite litigation.

site_title: Russia seen tapping gold reserves to fight sanctions
summary: Russia has built up substantial gold reserves, increasing its holdings by 55 tonnes this year, worth around $46 billion. The Bank of Russia has amassed 1,095 tonnes of gold in the past 10 years, positioning itself to counter sanctions. The country has also negotiated currency swaps with China, which may utilize its gold reserves as collateral for loans. This move suggests Russia is diversifying its economy and seeking to reduce its dependence on the US and Europe, potentially drawing closer to other BRICS nations.

site_title: Ho Bee Q2 earnings down 53% on absence of disposal gain
summary: Ho Bee Land's Q2 net profit dropped 53.5% to S$12.20 million due to a one-time gain on disposal of Hotel Windsor in 2013. However, the company reported solid rental income from its industrial and commercial properties, including office buildings in London and Singapore, totaling S$25.7 million. The group's chairman and CEO attributed the earnings drop to the absence of disposal gain and a challenging Singapore residential property market.

site_title: SIA-Tata airline to take flight in October
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and India's Tata Group are set to launch Vistara, a joint airline, in October, marking a 20-year-long effort by SIA to operate an India-based carrier. The airline, which will be headquartered in Delhi, plans to expand its fleet to 20 aircraft by the end of the fifth year of operation. However, analysts expect Vistara to contribute little to SIA's bottomline in the near term due to restrictions on domestic flights. The airline's launch is expected to intensify competition in India's aviation sector, where carriers are struggling to eke out a profit.

site_title: RBS confirms it's mulling over sale of Coutts Int'l
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) is considering selling its international arm, Coutts International, which manages nearly $36 billion in client assets. The sale, which could net RBS $720-1.1 billion, comes as the bank focuses on domestic lending due to British government pressure. Coutts International, founded in the 18th century, could be split into two businesses, with one based in Britain and the other in Zurich, serving markets in Hong Kong, Singapore, Abu Dhabi, and Dubai.

site_title: Rise in London home prices seen slowing to 3%
summary: London house-price growth is expected to slow to 3% in 2015, down from a previous forecast of 6%, according to Hamptons International. This follows a slowdown in London's residential property values, which rose at their slowest pace in 15 months in June. Despite this, home prices across England and Wales are expected to gain 8% this year and 5.5% in 2015. The Bank of England's introduction of tougher affordability regulations has contributed to the change in sentiment, with fewer people saying it's a good time to buy a UK home.

site_title: Some China developers likely to default
summary: China's property market is experiencing a shakeout as small developers face difficulty raising funds to pay off debt due to declining credit and a cooling market. Yield premiums on Chinese real estate bonds have jumped 27 basis points, and Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's warn of potential defaults by smaller developers. The industry's near-term risk to growth poses a significant threat to China's second-largest economy, with home prices dropping in 55 of 70 cities in June. Defaults may spread, with bigger developers expanding market share while smaller unlisted companies struggle to survive.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund buys another London property
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has acquired a 57.8% stake in a £343m London property, the Pollen Estate, in Mayfair. The fund's real estate group, formed to speed up investments, aims to invest nearly $10 billion annually over the next three years. This purchase expands Norway's holdings in London, following its 2010 agreement to buy a stake in Regent Street. The fund now owns properties globally, including in New York, Paris, Boston, San Francisco, and Zurich.

site_title: Airlines weigh options on Siberia flight ban
summary: United Airlines and Delta Air Lines are evaluating re-routing flights if Russia closes Siberian airspace to North American and European carriers. The ban, which is "on the table," would affect hundreds of weekly trips, primarily impacting European carriers. Airlines are making contingency plans, with some flights potentially being redirected around closed airspace. The move is in response to sanctions over the Ukraine standoff and the downing of a Malaysia Airlines plane.

site_title: Chinese military causing commercial flights' delay
summary: China's military has caused thousands of flight delays at Shanghai's Pudong International Airport and Beijing's Capital International Airport, with over 900 flights canceled due to exercises in the East China Sea. The delays have affected thousands of travelers, including retired professor Shen Zhihong, who was forced to wait indefinitely for his flight. The issue highlights tensions between the military's need for airspace and the growing demand for commercial aviation in China, where the number of outbound tourists is expected to double by 2020.

site_title: Little risk of home loans hitting local banks, says Maybank
summary: A Maybank report suggests that the risk of a fallout from local banks' mortgage portfolios due to housing non-performing loans (NPL) is low. Despite UOB's sharp rise in housing NPL in Q2, the report notes that the market has probably overreacted. OCBC Bank is expected to be hit the most, with a 14% profit impact, while DBS and UOB are not expected to face significant stress. The report also highlights the diversified nature of household assets and the lack of systemic risk in the housing market.

site_title: Strong operational profits at Frasers Centrepoint
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited reported strong operational performance in Q3, with revenue and profit before interest and tax jumping 41% and 56% year-over-year, respectively. Despite a 59.7% slump in net profit to S$109.2 million, the company's net profit would have surged 77.2% excluding fair-value gains and exceptional loss. The group is reviewing its portfolio for capital recycling and land-banking opportunities in Singapore and overseas, with a takeover offer for Australand expected to increase asset and profit contribution.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore Airlines and Tata Group to launch new airline in October, dubbed SIA-Tata. MAS managing director Ravi Menon warns against quantitative easing becoming the "new normal". Russia builds up gold reserves to counter sanctions, while local banks Maybank see low risk of mortgage fallout. Frasers Centrepoint reports strong operational profits, despite a slump in net profit. Super Group and CSE Global also report declining earnings due to weaker demand. Thomas Chua Kee Seng becomes one of nine Nominated MPs, and Indonesia maintains ban on nickel ore exports.

site_title: Struggling Bulgaria pins hopes on IT outsourcing boom
summary: Bulgaria's IT outsourcing sector has experienced a significant boom, with annual growth of up to 25% in recent years, contributing to the country's economy rebounding to 0.9% growth in 2013. The industry now employs 22,000 people, generating 3% of the country's GDP and turning over $685 million. Bulgaria's excellent IT specialists, language skills, and favorable business environment have attracted foreign companies, with giants like IBM, Adecco, and Coca Cola HBC setting up operations. However, the sector faces challenges, including a severe personnel shortage and a "very low profile" as an outsourcing destination.

site_title: Easy money cannot be new norm: MAS' Menon
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon warns that easy monetary conditions, sparked by the US Federal Reserve's quantitative-easing policies, are not a new normal. He urges a global normalization of monetary conditions to avoid distorting investment decisions and to mitigate volatility in capital flows. Menon also notes that China is at a "major inflection point" and faces significant challenges in its restructuring and reform efforts, particularly in deflating its real estate bubble. Normalizing interest rates should occur in an orderly fashion to give economies time to adjust.

site_title: Read all about it: news you can wear
summary: News companies are exploring wearable technology to deliver news notifications and articles to people who want to stay updated. Some news apps already use smartwatches and eyewear, such as Google Glass, to share headlines and full articles. This trend is expected to increase as wearables gain traction.

site_title: A US frontline against Ebola runs through Newark airport
summary: US frontline officer Erica Sison, who handles quarantine at Newark Liberty International Airport, is on high alert for Ebola, despite no specific targeting of passengers from West Africa. She deals with a range of exotic diseases, including Ebola, MERS, and Chikungunya, and has seen three false alarms in the past two weeks. Sison, a CDC officer, operates a secure office at the airport, where she trains border protection officers and provides health consultations to sick travelers.

site_title: Taking retail display to a new level
summary: Samsung Electronics launched B2B display solutions in Singapore, incorporating new technology to offer smarter and customized solutions for businesses. Four technology solutions were unveiled, taking retail display to a new level. The solutions aim to attract eyeballs and cater to discerning consumers, making them a crucial tool for businesses to stand out in the market.

site_title: How can IP insurers deal with soaring healthcare claims?
summary: Singapore's five integrated shield plan (IP) insurers are working to establish standardized guidelines for handling soaring healthcare claims. The insurers aim to improve transparency in hospital bills and doctor's fees, following a government call to review the industry's regulatory framework. Industry players suggest sharing claims data to scrutinize unusually high bills, but confidentiality issues hinder this effort. Publishing a list of doctors who consistently submit suspiciously high claims could be a solution, pending Health Ministry and medical council approval. Greater transparency is crucial for the healthcare and insurance industries' social responsibilities.

site_title: Are foreigners losing faith in Abenomics?
summary: Foreign investors are losing faith in Abenomics, Japan's economic recovery plan, amid a 3% drop in Tokyo stocks last Friday. The Bank of Japan acknowledged that export prospects are not looking bright, sparking concerns about the economy's future. This comes as domestic demand remains affected by a consumption tax hike. The drop in Tokyo prices may signal a shift in risk-off attitudes, influenced by the escalation of fighting in Iraq and Ukraine, as well as US President Obama's authorization of air strikes in Iraq.

site_title: M'sia output growth hits 11-month high
summary: Malaysia's industrial production growth surged 7% in June, the highest in 11 months, indicating robust GDP growth in the second quarter. Barclays Bank reaffirmed its forecast of 6% year-on-year GDP growth in Q2 and 5.7% for 2014, citing the strong industrial production data. The robust growth is expected to remain unchanged, suggesting a positive outlook for Malaysia's economy.

site_title: CNMC upbeat and out to contain costs
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings, Singapore's first listed gold miner, reported a net profit of US$4.44 million for the second quarter, up from US$26,180 a year ago, driven by record production volume of 6,470.24 ounces of fine gold. The company aims to contain costs, with a slower pace of growth in expenses boosting its net profit. Revenue jumped three times to US$8.27 million, but was partly offset by a lower average gold price. The company's all-in costs fell 41% to US$649 per ounce of gold sold.

site_title: Prevent next market debacle, not just fix it
summary: Singapore's regulators are implementing sweeping changes to the securities trading landscape, including collateral requirements for contra trading, independent rules committees, and minimum share prices. While these changes aim to diffuse the impact of future market debacles, they primarily treat symptoms rather than prevent incidents. Regulators need to address the issue of prevention, including improving surveillance and enforcement, and disincentivizing questionable behavior. The proposed rules, including independent committees that can impose fines, are a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done to truly prevent market debacles.

site_title: Social media's role in online buying: creating awareness
summary: Social media platforms, particularly Facebook, play a crucial role in creating awareness for online products, with 63% of visits to Shopify stores coming from the platform. However, research shows that social media is not a significant factor in the final purchasing decision, with conversion rates ranging from 1% to 1.85% across various social networks. According to Forrester Research, word of mouth drives 80% of purchasing actions, with social media serving as a first point of reach. Online stores are shifting their focus towards creating personalized marketing experiences to improve conversion rates.

site_title: Women that rock
summary: In Singapore, the fashion jewelry market is thriving, with at least 20 new brands emerging in the past four years, mostly created by female designers. These local labels have gained recognition for their unique, rocker-chic aesthetics and are now supported by the local media and social media platforms. The market has evolved due to women buying jewelry for themselves, seeking alternatives to traditional designs. Despite challenges such as sourcing gems and craftsmen, local jewelry designers are finding success, with some brands expanding globally and partnering with other designers and businesses.

site_title: Roxy sitting pretty as it casts its net wide
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings, a Singapore-based developer and hotel operator, is not in a hurry to slash prices at its Trilive and Sunnyvale Residences projects despite tepid sales. The company has pre-sale revenues of S$955.4 million and is exploring deals overseas, including office and residential projects in Australia and under-utilised hotels in Japan. Roxy aims to add hospitality assets to its portfolio to generate recurring income, targeting development yields of 15% in Singapore. The company may refresh the showflat for Trilive and re-look pricing, but is not inclined to slash prices due to the current market dynamics.

site_title: Vicom's Q2 net gain up 5.5% at S$7.23m
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspecting and testing services provider, reported a 5.5% increase in net profit to S$7.23 million for the second quarter of 2014, driven by a 2.4% rise in revenue to S$27.26 million. Net profit for the six months ended June rose 6.5% to S$15.24 million, with revenue increasing 2.9% to S$54.16 million. The company also declared an 8.75 Singapore cents per ordinary share tax-exempt interim dividend.

site_title: Work, parts piling up at B787 assembly sites
summary: Boeing is accelerating 787 Dreamliner production, pushing some factory work to the uncovered tarmac outside its assembly plant in Washington state to meet a three-day target. Unfinished jobs, known as "travelled work," have piled up, and fuselage sections are being stored in Wichita, Kansas, rather than being shipped directly to the factory. The company aims to streamline production and cut costs to deliver a record 110 Dreamliners this year, despite concerns about global demand and production speed. Boeing shares rose 0.13% on the news, following a 12% decline this year.

site_title: Board diversity: the international perspective
summary: Foreign directors on boards offer a geographical perspective beyond a company's home base, bringing diverse skills and perspectives. According to Spencer Stuart's Board Index 2013, the Netherlands leads with 42% foreign directors, while the US lags with 7%. Benefits include smoother business expansion, diverse mindset, and signal of international outlook. However, obstacles include communication, distance, and costs, which can be mitigated with open-mindedness, technology, and effective planning. Companies with global ambitions are expected to increase demand for international directors, as demonstrated by Singapore's high percentage of foreign directors on its top 30 STI companies.

site_title: Buybacks surge, buying stays flat
summary: Singapore Exchange data shows flat buying activity by directors and investors for the second consecutive week, with 24 purchases worth S$2.86 million and four disposals worth S$4.6 million. However, buyback activity surged with seven companies posting 36 repurchases worth S$13.1 million. Notable buyback activity was seen in Pacific Century Regional Developments, Singapore Airlines, and OCBC Bank. Other companies with significant buyback and director trades include Vallianz Holdings, Roxy-Pacific Holdings, First Reit, and Mencast Holdings.

site_title: At a glance
summary: Asean nations have agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, according to Malaysia. Meanwhile, China urged South-east Asian countries to support openness amidst US tariffs looming. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, backed by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, and a low-profile property trust is exploring a data centre gambit.

site_title: RBS said to be giving up half its space in HK's Central district
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) is reducing its office space in Hong Kong's Central district by half, with half of 60,000 square feet allocated to its private banking unit Coutts & Co. The remaining employees will move to Lincoln House in Quarry Bay by the end of the year. This move is part of the bank's efforts to cut costs as office rents in Central continue to fall due to foreign financial firms downsizing or relocating.

site_title: Enjoying the organisation
summary: DBS Vickers, a Singapore-based company, has participated in the BT Corporate Golf League since 2010, citing the event's great organization and social opportunities. The team, led by captain Leonard Lui, has consistently performed well, finishing 15th in 2010, 10th in 2011, and 9th in 2012. Despite not winning the league, they aim to finish in the top half of the table this year. The team is looking forward to the upcoming third round at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden Course.

site_title: National issues
summary: Key issues to be addressed in the National Day Rally on Aug 17 include the social fabric of Singapore, healthcare, housing, cost of living, and the ageing population. The rally should focus on the future, not just on past achievements, with a comprehensive plan to build a Singapore Community and simplify policies. The government should also address the attitudes of the younger generation, provide a blueprint for Singapore's growth story, and ensure social cohesion and a unified Singaporean identity. Additionally, the rally should discuss solutions to the rapidly ageing population, including affordable housing, healthcare, and retirement, as well as civil and political freedom.

site_title: Listed firms see 13.6% rise in total Q2 profit
summary: Singapore-listed firms saw a 13.6% increase in combined profits to S$6.91 billion in Q2 2014, with 129 firms turning a profit and only 32 in the red. Market heavyweights OCBC Bank, CapitaLand, and Keppel Land reported strong earnings, while UOL Group saw a 50.9% drop in net profit due to lower fair value gains. The offshore sector also saw robust results, with Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine reporting increases in net profit.

site_title: California vessels getting paid to save the whales
summary: A four-month pilot program in California's Santa Barbara Channel pays vessels $2,500 to slow down, reducing offshore air pollution and collisions with whales. The program, backed by NOAA, aims to cut exhaust emissions from ships, which account for half of ozone pollution in the area, and protect endangered blue whales. Six shipping companies participate, with the goal of saving lives among the estimated 2,500 blue whales in the Pacific. The program targets ships traveling at 14-18 knots, slowing them to 12 knots during the trip.

site_title: Stop over at Osaka too
summary: The article recommends visiting Osaka, Japan, and suggests pairing it with a trip to Kyoto due to their contrasting charms. The Ritz-Carlton Osaka hotel is highlighted as a luxurious option, offering classic Japanese cuisine and unique experiences like a chocolate boutique. The hotel's location in Umeda, walking distance to shopping districts, makes it an ideal base for exploring Osaka.

site_title: Luxury hotels do fine despite fewer tourists
summary: Luxury hotels in Singapore continue to perform well despite a decline in tourist arrivals from China, a major source market. Visitor arrivals from China dropped 27% in the first half of 2014, while overall arrivals declined 1.7%. Luxury hotels saw a 7.8% rise in average room rate and 8.5% growth in revenue per available room, while economy hotels also edged up. The industry-wide average room rate rose 1.2% year-on-year, but average occupancy fell 1.2 percentage points. Experts expect continued growth in luxury hotels and a flat or slightly decreasing industry-wide occupancy.

site_title: Goodpack clears final hurdle with bondholders
summary: Goodpack, a Singaporean logistics packaging firm, has secured consent from all but one of its bondholders to waive conditions related to its acquisition by private equity firm KKR. The deal values Goodpack at S$1.4 billion. The firm had offered a 100% redemption price and raised the early consent fee to persuade bondholders. Goodpack's executive chairman and a holding company controlling 32% of the company have already committed to voting in favor of the deal, which requires a majority of shareholders to pass.

site_title: Antitrust immunity for Scoot and Tigerair
summary: Singapore's Competition Commission of Singapore granted antitrust immunity to Scoot and Tigerair, allowing the two budget carriers to coordinate schedules, routes, and sales on parallel routes. This cooperation will provide customers with more flight options and greater connectivity. The move is seen as a way to create net economic benefit for Singaporeans, as previously found in similar antitrust immunity cases. The approval paves the way for the airlines to strengthen their alliance and deliver greater flexibility and value to customers, with Scoot being wholly owned by Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Hole-in-one prize: Royal Oak Chronograph
summary: AUDEMARS Piguet has partnered with the BT Corporate Golf League as a Hole-In-One sponsor, providing the Royal Oak Chronograph timepiece worth S$31,700 for a prize. This is the company's third consecutive year of sponsorship, focusing on contemporary art and golf. The brand recently hosted the 2014 Audemars Piguet Golf Invitational in New Jersey, featuring golf ambassadors such as Henrik Stenson and Ian Poulter. The partnership aims to provide prestigious exposure for the company through its association with golf tournaments and events.

site_title: Fellowship and happy golfing
summary: Zyfas Medical Company, competing in the BT Corporate Golf League for the first time, sits in 11th position after two rounds with scores of 91 and 99. Team captain Adrian Chew attributed the team's participation to "fellowship and happy golfing," citing enjoyable experiences with other players and the overall organization of the League. The team is looking to capitalize on the strengths of their members, including Mohamed Tahir, who boasts a 280-meter drive, to move up the rankings.

site_title: Singapore's intestacy rules
summary:
Singapore's Intestate Succession Act determines how a deceased person's estate will be distributed to successors in the absence of a valid will. Key points include: 
- A surviving spouse takes precedence over parents, with children and spouse splitting assets.
- Children receive equal portions, with grandchildren inheriting deceased child's share.
- If no spouse, children, or parents, parents or grandparents take the estate.
- Unmarried children of deceased parents or grandparents receive the estate.
- If no relatives, the government takes the estate.
- A special provision allows multiple surviving wives to share assets equally.
- A child's distributive share excludes gifts or payments made by the deceased during their lifetime.

site_title: Beyond the typical Merlion
summary: Singaporean indie retailer The Little Drom Store has launched a new line of badges called Strangely Singaporean & Proud Of It, featuring quirky personality descriptions such as "Yaya Papaya" and "Blur Like Sotong". The badges aim to showcase the country's unique culture and challenge negative connotations associated with certain traits. The store's co-founder Antoinette Wong hopes the badges will promote self-acceptance and pride in Singapore's diverse personalities.

site_title: Lost and found
summary: Violet Oon has introduced six "lost" Peranakan, Cantonese, and Hainanese dishes in her latest menu update for the National Day season. The dishes include keledek masak lemak (sweet potato leaves in rich gravy), stir-fried beef with pineapple, yi bua (Hainanese cakes), lo kai yik (braised chicken wings), ayam lodeh (chicken in coconut gravy), and ayam bali (Indonesian-style chicken dish). These traditional dishes are often overlooked in restaurants due to their labor-intensive preparation processes, but Oon aims to revive them and showcase their unique flavors and textures.

site_title: China trade surplus hits a record in July
summary: China's trade surplus reached a record $47.3 billion in July, tripling from a year ago, driven by a 14.5% jump in exports to $212.9 billion. Imports unexpectedly fell 1.6% to $165.6 billion, exceeding forecasts. The data suggests China's economic growth is accelerating, with GDP rising 7.5% in the second quarter, beating expectations. However, concerns remain about the impact of the vast and opaque property sector on growth.

site_title: On the right track
summary: Ristorante Takada, a new Japanese-Italian restaurant in Alexandra, has received mixed reviews after its soft launch. Chef Masahiro Takada's dishes, such as creamy burrata cheese and roasted pigeon, show promise, but some elements, like the icy cold temperature of the burrata and overly soft noodles, fall short. The restaurant's prix fixe concept limits its clientele, and the pricing may deter non-Japanese diners. However, the servers are refreshingly honest and unpretentious. With fine-tuning, Ristorante Takada may hit on the formula for success, earning a rating of 6.5.

site_title: Efficiency drive
summary: Volvo introduces the XC60 T5 Drive-E, featuring a new 2.0-litre turbocharged engine and an 8-speed automatic transmission. The Drive-E engine is 21% more fuel-efficient than the previous model, producing 245 hp and 350 Nm, with lower CO2 emissions of 157 g/km. The XC60 T5 Drive-E also boasts improved ride comfort and acceleration, making it a revelation on the road. The new engine is available for the rest of the T5 range, including the S60 and S80 sedans, with a starting price of S$209,999.

site_title: International factors to blame for Tokyo's stock-price plunge: BOJ
summary: Tokyo's stock prices plummeted 3% due to international factors, including the US authorization of air strikes in Iraq and rising tensions in Europe over the Ukraine crisis. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) attributed the drop to foreign investors and blamed the "sluggishness in Asean markets" for the downward assessment of exports. Despite this, BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda remains upbeat about Japan's overall economic outlook, citing improvements in job and income conditions and a positive economic cycle.

site_title: SunMoon and Sultans lead after 2 rounds
summary: The 2014 Business Times Corporate Golf League is underway, with SPH Sultans of Swing and defending champions Team SunMoon leading the ladder after two rounds with 208 points each. DBS Vickers is in third place, while The Crane Boomers and Team Emerio follow in fourth and fifth respectively. The third round will take place on August 12 at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden Course.

site_title: On course for a good cause
summary: The Singapore Indian Education Trust's (SIET) annual charity golf tournament will take place on August 29 at Sembawang Country Club, with all proceeds going to the Trust's financial assistance programs for needy students. Established in 1967, SIET aims to provide bursaries and interest-free study loans to deserving students.

site_title: Tastes for a new age
summary: Debbie Yong, a 29-year-old health coach, has launched her own line of locally-made almond nut milks, "The Mlk Co", which are unpasteurised, preservative-free, and have a 25% nut content. The milks come in three flavors and are made to order for maximum freshness. Yong's sisters are involved in branding and marketing efforts, and they plan to expand their product line to include chocolate specialty cafe by year-end.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Venture Corp reported an 11.6% increase in net profit to S$33.5 million for Q2 2014, driven by its operations. F&N posted a 25% rise in net profit to S$44.5 million for Q3, mainly from strong beverage sales. ASL Marine Holdings warned of a net loss for Q4 due to lower shiprepair and conversion revenue. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia upbeat on outlook; Q2 DPU down
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) posted a 26.9% year-on-year drop in second-quarter distributable profit to 0.68 Singapore cents due to higher expenses and currency weakness. Despite this, the trust remains upbeat on the outlook for retail malls in Indonesia, citing limited new retail space and favourable conditions for existing mall owners. Gross rents grew 4.8% to S$28.4 million, but fell 11.6% when translated to Singapore dollars.

site_title: China game makers see S-E Asia as a springboard
summary: Chinese game developers are expanding into Southeast Asia as a testing ground for new games and monetization models before entering the Western market. The saturated Chinese games scene, with over 100 games published daily, has prompted developers to seek new audiences. Chinese developers are keen to test Western-style casual games and monetization models in Southeast Asia, where users are more tolerant of ads and have different gaming preferences. The region's relatively smaller market and long history of business with China make it an attractive "springboard" for expansion.

images.alt_text: Mr De Wit: The Chinese market is too big for developers globally to ignore. But finding the right games publisher is critical to a game's visibility and success.

site_title: Nam Cheong Q2 net up 55% at RM63.3m
summary: Nam Cheong reported a 55% increase in Q2 net profit to RM63.3 million, driven by better performance in its shipbuilding and vessel-chartering businesses. Revenue rose 38% to RM378.8 million, with the shipbuilding segment contributing 94% of the top line. The company has a strong order book of RM1.7 billion and is optimistic about its prospects, particularly in Malaysia's oil-and-gas industry. Analysts are positive, with OCBC reaffirming its buy rating and fair value estimate.

site_title: OCBC picks Ong Eng Bin to helm Malaysian operations
summary: OCBC Bank appointed Ong Eng Bin as CEO of OCBC Bank (Malaysia) Berhad, effective immediately. Ong, 51, takes over from Jeffrey Chew, who left the bank to join Paramount Corp Bhd as group CEO. Chew led the bank's business banking division, accounting for 55% of revenue and 65% of pre-tax profits. OCBC's counter fell 7 Singapore cents to S$10.10 after the appointment.

site_title: UOL seeks land with 'strong growth story'
summary: UOL Group, a Singapore property and hotel group, posted a 51% year-on-year drop in Q2 net earnings due to lower fair-value gains from investment properties. Despite this, the company remains keen on selectively acquiring Singapore residential development land, focusing on locations with good connectivity and strong growth stories. UOL plans to launch several new projects, including Seventy St Patrick's and a condo in Upper Paya Lebar, with the majority of units expected to be sold in the first half of next year. The company expects the residential property market to remain subdued for a while.

site_title: Renault for road and track
summary: Renault has unveiled a facelifted version of its Clio RS, a hot hatch that boasts a new brand identity. The updated model features an almond-shaped headlamp, a sleek black grille, and slim tail lights. The Clio RS now comes with five doors, a 1.6-litre engine, and a dual clutch gearbox. The car's styling is more distinctive, especially in the Liquid Yellow pearlescent paintwork. This iteration marks a significant departure from the quirky design of Renault hatchbacks, showcasing a more refined and sporty aesthetic.

site_title: Healthier in-between drink
summary: Infuusa, a cold-brewed fruit infusion drink, was created by product designer Ng Wei Lieh to provide a healthier alternative to plain water and energy drinks for spin class workouts. Each sachet contains only 5 calories and is steeped in 500ml of water for 3-10 minutes. The drink is caffeine-free, except for upcoming tea-based flavors, and is made with dehydrated and milled fruits. The product aims to provide a smoother and sweeter taste, while retaining antioxidants, and is set to be launched in gyms and cafes.

site_title: Charged up sponsorship
summary: Red Monster, a portable charger manufacturer, has signed up as a sponsor for the BT Corporate Golf League, marking its first year of sponsorship. The company's managing director, Axmund Phuah, hopes to increase awareness of its products among executives and potentially secure deals. The sponsorship includes product placement in goodie bags and lucky draws, with a value of S$30,000. Red Monster aims to gain branding, market share, and awareness through the partnership.

site_title: Food culture comes to life
summary: Wang Shijia, a 38-year-old Singaporean, has created a range of food-related characters, including Ang Ku Kueh Girl, Png Kueh Girl, and Kueh Lapis Girl, to showcase the cultural significance of local food. The characters, which take about two weeks to six months to develop, are designed with interesting shapes and colors that reflect their meanings. Wang's merchandise, including tote bags and notebooks, has gained popularity among locals and tourists, with some companies using the characters as corporate gifts. She plans to expand the brand globally, including a Chinese version of the website.

site_title: More Chinese cities relax property curbs
summary: More than half of China's 46 local governments have relaxed property controls, allowing residents to buy more homes. This move, seen as a signal from Beijing to ease its grip on the sector, comes as the cooling housing market poses a threat to the economy. Analysts predict further easing of controls in smaller cities, but warn that home prices may not recover soon. Fitch Ratings has expressed concerns that the loosening of property curbs could stoke property speculation.

site_title: Tune Insurance eyes JV with UAE aviation firm
summary: Tune Insurance Holdings Bhd (TIH) has entered a memorandum of understanding with UAE aviation firm Al Hai LLC to explore a joint-venture company for insurance-related business activities. The proposed tie-up is expected to provide Tune with its next growth catalyst, with TIH's stock rising 30% year-to-date. The deal may diversify TIH away from its major partner AirAsia, controlled by aviation tycoon Tony Fernandes. TIH's second-quarter performance is expected to be impacted by weak regional travel demand, but the company forecasts a better second half driven by AirAsia and improved margins.

site_title: Around Town
summary:
Here is a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

This week, Singaporean entertainment and arts scene features a hit Broadway musical "Rock of Ages" at Resorts World Sentosa, playing until Aug 24. The musical showcases classic rock hits from the 80s. A new film "Sayang Disayang" is released, exploring the relationship between domestic caregivers and elderly charges. Meanwhile, exhibitions "Art of Celebration" and "The Launch of Kwerkee Art" are on display, celebrating National Day and showcasing local artists' works. Additionally, "Chosen to Die" by Ivan Sagita is on display at Equator Art Projects, featuring a new body of work exploring themes of life and society.

site_title: Straight from the heart
summary: Singapore designer Edwin Low has launched "Aspects," a collection of five handcrafted drinking glasses featuring designs by five local designers. The collection, like his previous "Singapore Icons" porcelain ware, aims to represent different aspects of Singaporean society. Each glass is individually handcrafted and etched with a unique design, such as the alphabet for altruism or Singapore's iconic trees. The collection is priced at S$49 for two glasses and aims to break into the international market, with designs representing arts, youth, education, sports, and garden.

site_title: Khazanah offers 27 sen a share for remaining 30% stake in MAS
summary: Khazanah Nasional, a Malaysian state investment agency, has offered 27 sen per share to acquire the remaining 30% stake in national carrier Malaysian Airlines (MAS) for RM1.4 billion. This move is part of a plan to privatize the airline, which has been struggling with losses of over RM4 billion between 2011 and 2023. The agency plans to unveil its "full proposal" by the end of August, which will include a restructuring plan that may involve significant cost cuts and changes to the airline's operations and management.

site_title: PM Lee reveals tighter forecast
summary: Singapore's full-year economic growth forecast has been narrowed to 2.5-3.5%, down from 2-4%, with no expectation of exceeding 3.5% in the second half of the year. This follows a 3.5% growth rate in the first half, with economists attributing the slowdown to domestic headwinds, geopolitical risks, and weaker growth in key emerging economies. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for continued economic growth to improve lives, particularly for the elderly and young Singaporeans.

site_title: Forgot the keys again?
summary: Forgetfulness can be caused by preventable factors such as statin medications, invasive diagnostic procedures, poor medical condition control, and poor sleep quality. As the population ages, medical advances to prolong longevity and preserve memory power become increasingly significant. While dementia is more common among older people, it is not always inevitable and can be prevented with proactive measures. Understanding the mechanisms of memory loss can help individuals take steps to prevent deterioration, such as avoiding medications and procedures that can harm memory.

site_title: BoA offers over US$16 billion in federal deal
summary: Bank of America has agreed to a $16 billion federal settlement with the Justice Department and various state attorneys general, marking the largest single federal settlement in corporate US history. The deal settles investigations into the bank's sale of toxic mortgage securities before the financial crisis. Despite the large penalty, critics argue that the government crackdown has been too lenient, and the settlement details, such as investor losses and executive names, are not being made public. The deal brings closure to Bank of America's largest remaining legal issue from the financial crisis, allowing the bank to return to normal operations.

site_title: Escalating geo-political worries hit stocks
summary: The Singapore stock market fell 25.33 points or 0.8% to 3,288.89 on August 7, 2014, due to an overnight sell-off on Wall Street amid geo-political uncertainties. The Straits Times Index has lost 56 points or 1.7% for the week. Key drivers of the decline included Russian troop buildup in Ukraine, US air strikes in Iraq, and worsening trouble in Gaza, which led to a surge in "geopolitical risk." Bank stocks, particularly DBS and OCBC, were among the biggest losers.

site_title: Cargo weakness continues as a drag on Asia-Pacific carriers
summary: European airline shares fell 9% in July, the largest decline among global peers, due to weak financial performance and overall market weakness. In contrast, worldwide airline shares were down only 2% month-on-month. The Asia-Pacific region saw a decline in operating profits to $150 million, attributed to cargo revenue weakness and increasing cost pressures for Chinese carriers. Despite this, air travel volumes are expected to experience solid growth globally, driven by an improving demand environment.

site_title: Kyoto charm, Ritz flair
summary: The Ritz-Carlton Kyoto, a luxurious hotel in Japan, seamlessly blends traditional Kyoto style with modern elegance. The hotel features Japanese sugi wood, art works, and a private dining room from a century-old villa. Guests can enjoy a range of dining options, including Italian and Japanese cuisine, and relax in the hotel's natural courtyards. The hotel's staff are trained to provide exceptional service, and its Pierre Herme pastry shop offers a touch of French flair. Located on the banks of the Kamogawa river, the hotel is a tranquil oasis in the heart of the ancient city.

site_title: Income inequality narrowing in Singapore: MOF report
summary: Singapore's income inequality has narrowed over the last five years, with lower- and middle-income groups experiencing steady increases in real incomes. The government's social safety net measures and curbs on foreign worker supply have contributed to this trend. However, productivity growth remains a concern, with economists warning that rising wages may not be sustainable if productivity doesn't catch up. The Gini coefficient, a measure of income inequality, fell to 0.412 last year, down from 0.434 in 2012.

site_title: Squaring the roots of a nation
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, amid growing demand for environmentally friendly air travel. The country is also promoting advanced chip packaging, with a study suggesting it has the potential to become a global hub for the industry. Additionally, the government has announced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs, and a visit by Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Khong to the US for trade talks. Experts are advising graduates to future-proof their careers, with better employment rates reported in early data.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC narrows Q2 loss to US$4.18m
summary: STATS ChipPAC narrowed its Q2 loss to US$4.18m, compared to a US$52.2m loss in the same period last year. The company expects Q3 revenue to rise 2-8% due to strong demand for emerging market wireless chipsets and next-generation LTE processors. Net revenue was up 3.4% at US$409.9m, driven by demand for these products, but margins dipped due to higher production ramp-up costs. The company guides for US$175-205m in capital expenditure in Q3, including US$75-95m for a new factory in South Korea.

site_title: Tracing the journey of immigrants
summary: A play titled "Amid The Clouds" by Iranian theatre figure Amir Reza Koohestani explores the journey of two illegal immigrants, a man and a woman, who travel to the UK in search of a better life. The play delves into the complexities of human migration, questioning whether happiness and stability can be found in a new country. Koohestani's work is influenced by Persian poetry and Iranian sensibility, highlighting the psychological conflicts faced by immigrants. The play premiered in the UK and will be featured at the Singapore International Festival of Arts.

site_title: Flying the flag
summary: Singapore's culinary scene continues to shine, with the country's chefs and bartenders making waves globally. Chef Yew Eng Tong of Ocean Restaurant came in second at the Bocuse d'Or Asian finals and will represent Singapore at the global finals in Lyon next January. Bartender Peter Chua of 28 Hong Kong Street topped the Diageo Reserve World Class Competition in the South-east Asia finals and made it to the top six in the global finals. 28 Hong Kong Street was also named the Best International Bar at the Tales of the Cocktail awards. These achievements highlight Singapore's growing reputation as a hub for culinary talent and innovation.

site_title: Glorious toasty aroma
summary: A Singaporean woman, Janine Campbell, discovered she was intolerant to peanuts after a protein shake without peanut butter caused no discomfort. She began making her own almond butter, slow-roasting and blending almonds to create a toasty aroma. Campbell's homemade almond butters are sold through direct email orders and come in two flavors. The butters have a nut-flecked appearance and a more viscous texture compared to commercial peanut butter. Campbell plans to launch a dark chocolate hazelnut spread soon.

site_title: Scoot not keen on Changi's T4 'folly', says CEO
summary: Scoot, a budget carrier of Singapore Airlines, has expressed dissatisfaction with Changi Airport's new Terminal Four (T4), calling it a "folly". CEO Campbell Wilson stated that the terminal lacks sufficient connections to the rest of the airport, making it unsuitable for wide-body aircraft. Despite Cathay Pacific Airways being the first airline to move to T4, Scoot is unlikely to follow, instead opting to remain in the main terminals.

site_title: Love for peanut butter
summary: A Singaporean couple, Ezra Nicholas and Tannie Tang, make their own preservative-free peanut butter using natural ingredients like peanuts, olive oil, and honey. Their "beenut" butters come in three variants and have gained an overwhelming response at pop-up markets and retail stalls. The couple plans to expand to a permanent kitchen and takeaway space, and hopes to open a full-fledged eatery to provide work and training opportunities. Their business has allowed Tannie to leave her job as a civil servant and grow the business full-time.

site_title: MAS plans to suspend its share trading today
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) plans to suspend its share trading today, paving the way for state investor Khazanah Nasional to take the airline private. The halt is due to a pending corporate announcement. Khazanah Nasional is expected to submit a plan to take the airline private to Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, marking the first step in a major restructuring.

site_title: Telcos' biggest enemy is themselves
summary: Telcos face significant challenges as new services like Nanu, a mobile call app that offers free calls in exchange for listening to ads, gain traction. Despite operators' claims of better reliability and quality, consumers increasingly prioritize free services over premium features. This shift is driven by a growing preference for non-voice communication and a decrease in voice minute usage. As a result, telcos may need to adapt by collaborating with or acquiring successful services, rather than seeing them as competitors. The industry's failure to innovate and evolve is putting telcos at risk of losing market share.

site_title: Indonesian meat, dairy producer launches Singapore IPO
summary: Indonesian meat and dairy producer Japfa Ltd has launched a public offering in Singapore, selling 248 million shares at 80 Sing cents apiece. The company expects to list on the mainboard of Singapore Exchange next Friday. Japfa plans to use the S$187.3 million net proceeds to develop its China dairy business and expand its operations in the region. The firm has received robust demand from institutional investors, with Marubeni Corp serving as an anchor investor. Japfa's CEO Tan Yong Nang expressed confidence in the company's long-term prospects, despite potential volatility in the market.

site_title: Cantopop kings are a perfect match both on and offstage
summary: Cantopop kings Alan Tam and Hacken Lee have been performing together for over a decade, despite being 17 years apart in age. Their double act has become commercially successful, selling out 135,000 tickets to their Hong Kong shows last year. The duo has also expanded their partnership offstage, owning noodle and congee restaurants, and will perform their 10th anniversary tour in Singapore next month. Their shows feature 50 of their greatest hits, a stand-up comedy segment, and highlight the strong bond between the two artists.

site_title: FCL on track to acquire Australand
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd (FCL) is on track to acquire Australand Property Group after more than half of its shareholders accepted the Singapore company's A$4.48 cents per share bid. This deal gives FCL control of Australand's A$2.4 billion office and industrial properties and A$9.3 billion developments in Australia. The acquisition is FCL's largest and aims to boost its operations in faster-growing overseas markets, including Australia and China. The deal has received enough acceptances from Australian equity investors to make the bid unconditional.

site_title: Russia threatens to block Europe-Asia overflights
summary: Russia's Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev has threatened to block overflights between Europe and Asia in retaliation for Western sanctions. Medvedev warned that Russia could ban European and US airlines from using its airspace for transit flights in the Asia-Pacific region. This move could affect European airlines such as Lufthansa, British Airways, and Air France that operate long-haul routes to Asia, potentially leading to higher fuel and operating costs. The ban could also harm Russia's top airline Aeroflot, which relies on fees gathered from European airlines for overflight rights.

site_title: Brit-pop survivors prove solid local favourites
summary: Travis, a Scottish Brit-pop band, celebrated almost 25 years together with a sold-out show at The Star Performing Arts Centre. The band, consisting of the same lineup since its formation, has managed to maintain their camaraderie and down-to-earth reputation despite commercial success. Their 2-hour setlist featured a mix of old and new songs, showcasing their maturity in songwriting, particularly in tracks about parenthood. The show concluded with their signature hit, Why Does It Always Rain on Me, leaving the audience with smiles.

site_title: Fernvale tenders reflect drop in market confidence
summary: A state land tender in Singapore's Fernvale Road area saw a decline in tender participation rates and land prices, reflecting reduced market confidence. The top bids for adjacent private housing sites, Parcel A and Parcel B, were significantly lower than last year's winning bids, with a Chip Eng Seng-led consortium topping the bids at S$438.17 and S$448.35 per square foot per plot ratio. The tender results indicate a cautious approach from developers amid weaker market conditions and the introduction of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework in 2013.

site_title: Uncovering the beauty of the oceans
summary: Underwater photographer David Doubilet will share his passion for the ocean at a National Geographic Live talk in Singapore on August 25. Doubilet, who has worked for National Geographic for 45 years, emphasizes the importance of having a specific interest in a unique topic to succeed in the field. He will showcase his stunning images of icebergs, sturgeons, and other underwater subjects, highlighting the beauty and importance of the ocean. Doubilet's talk aims to inspire audiences to care more about the earth and its natural wonders.

site_title: Why Malaysia Airlines can and will survive
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) is expected to recover from recent catastrophic events, including the disappearance of MH370 and the shooting down of MH17, due to national support and backing from Khazanah, the country's sovereign wealth fund. An overwhelming number of Malaysians expressed confidence in flying with MAS, considering it their duty to support the company. AirAsia, another Malaysian airline, may also play a role in MAS's recovery, potentially providing assistance or support.

site_title: Peranakan recipes in residence
summary: Ascott Limited has released a Peranakan cookbook, "30 Years, 30 Recipes: A Gastronomic Journey", to celebrate its 30th anniversary. The 30 recipes, created by local chef Malcolm Lee, are a mix of traditional and modern dishes, showcasing Lee's style of cooking. The cookbook aims to promote Singaporean chefs abroad and highlight the versatility of serviced apartments, which can be used for cooking and hosting. 4,000 copies have been printed, and 50 copies are available at Singapore libraries.

site_title: Finance costs drag Gallant into the red in Q2
summary: Gallant Venture posted a net loss of S$12.1 million in the April-June quarter, reversing from a net profit of S$8.5 million a year ago, due to a more than doubling of finance costs to S$36.8 million. Revenue dipped 1% to S$554.3 million, mainly affected by Imas' contribution drop. The group's industrial and utilities businesses are recovering but face increasing labour costs and foreign currency volatilities.

site_title: Sanctions over Russia-Ukraine clash take their toll
summary: Economic sanctions imposed over the Russia-Ukraine conflict are taking a toll on markets, despite continued easy money in the US and Europe. The European Central Bank and Bank of England kept interest rates unchanged, but market participants fear it won't counter the negative impact of sanctions, troop build-ups, and concerns over the Middle East conflicts. The 10-year German sovereign bond yield has tumbled, reflecting a flight to safety and fears of an economic downturn in Germany due to trade disruptions.

site_title: Asset recycling strategy a fillip for Hyflux
summary: Hyflux's net profit for the second quarter ended June jumped to S$61.4 million, driven by a surge in "other income" from S$85.3 million, largely due to the sale and leaseback of the Hyflux Innovation Centre. The water solutions group posted a net profit of S$99.3 million for the six months ended June, with total revenue dropping 36% to S$169 million. The company's asset recycling strategy is expected to drive growth, with opportunities in Oman, Qatar, Kuwait, and Saudi Arabia, and a cash position of S$481 million.

site_title: Noble's Q2 profit up 5% as volumes rise
summary: Noble Group's second-quarter net profit rose 5% to US$65.8 million, driven by increased volumes of 72.3 million tonnes of goods. The company's asset-light strategy is yielding results, with revenue reaching US$23.6 billion and CEO Yusuf Alireza attributing the growth to Noble's competence in moving commodities. The firm is forming partnerships to invest in assets and secure raw materials without owning and operating producing assets, aiming to establish itself as a partner of choice for suppliers and customers.

site_title: Injecting new life into an old quarter
summary: The George Town Festival in Penang, Malaysia, is a month-long celebration of the city's architecture and arts scene. The festival, now in its fifth edition, features 147 events at 20 venues, drawing an expected 200,000 people. It has revitalized old buildings, including coffeeshops, mansions, and a former bus depot, with contemporary art installations and performances. The festival has fostered a new generation of artists, with many relocating to Penang to contribute to the city's burgeoning arts scene. Local arts groups have collaborated with international artists, and the festival has helped establish Penang as a cultural hub in Malaysia.

site_title: Design Studio Q2 profit soars on stronger margins
summary: Design Studio Group, a furniture maker, reported a 50% increase in net profit for the second quarter, driven by stronger profit margins despite lower sales. Revenue fell 26.6% to S$32.6 million, but cost of sales dropped 35.2% due to improved efficiency. The company declared an interim dividend and expects the operating environment to remain challenging in the second half of the year due to property cooling measures and increased labor costs.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The global economic recovery is evident in the latest BT-UniSIM Business Climate Survey, with companies feeling the effects. However, Russia sanctions and ongoing conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East continue to weigh on markets. In Singapore, income inequality is narrowing, while banks are expected to rely more on wholesale funding due to shrinking deposits. The NOL Group posted a Q2 loss, and Japfa is set to launch an IPO. China is delaying plans to free up the yuan, while Australia's jobless rate reached a 12-year high, and the US saw a drop in weekly jobless claims.

site_title: Sunset Boulevard getting 21st century makeover
summary: California's Sunset Strip is undergoing a 21st-century makeover, with ageing landmarks like the House of Blues and Larry Flynt's Hustler Hollywood being demolished to make way for luxury hotels and developments. Investors such as Ian Schrager and CIM Group are planning projects worth over $600 million, including a luxury hotel with 190 rooms and a hotel-condo complex. Hotel occupancies in West Hollywood have risen 6.5 percentage points to 82%, making it one of the hottest entertainment spots in the country. The development is expected to bring in significant revenue through outdoor advertising and potentially alleviate traffic congestion.

site_title: Baxter unveils biologics facility
summary: American healthcare company Baxter has officially opened its first biologics facility in Singapore, marking a significant expansion in the country. The 14,000 sqm plant will manufacture products created through biologics, and the company plans to add a second production suite in Singapore, aiming to employ 450 staff by 2015. This move underscores Baxter's commitment to the region and its growing presence in the biologics industry.

site_title: Global recovery filtering through to S'pore firms
summary: Singapore businesses are becoming more optimistic about the second half of 2014, according to the latest BT-UniSIM Business Climate Survey. Despite a global economic recovery that is still uneven, businesses reported better sales and profits in Q2, and are expecting improved prospects in H2. The survey found that companies achieved better performance overseas than in Singapore, with the US economy's recovery and improvements in China and India contributing to the positive outlook. Experts predict 4.4-5% growth in Q3 GDP, although some economists are more cautious with estimates of 3.8-4%.

site_title: Arts groups strike a chord in CBD
summary: Arts groups in Singapore's CBD brought together 20 Chinese classical musicians for a unique concert. Passersby took turns conducting the orchestra from a podium, with 300 onlookers gathering to watch. The impromptu performance featured six songs and ended with a heartfelt send-off. The event was organized by the Ding Yi Music Company, and it showcased the beauty of music and community interaction.

site_title: Revenue surge swells CWT's Q2 earnings
summary: CWT Ltd, a mainboard-listed logistics group, reported a 67% surge in net profit to S$30.3 million in Q2 2014, driven by a 114% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$3.69 billion. The company also unveiled plans to build a mega logistics facility. This marked a significant improvement from the same period last year, with earnings per share increasing by 66%. The strong performance was attributed to the company's robust business operations.

site_title: An ambitious but subtle facelift for a French beauty
summary: The Hotel Plaza Athénée in Paris has reopened after a 200 million euro expansion and renovation, marking a significant upgrade to the 101-year-old luxury hotel. The hotel, which was full on its first night, offers 14 new guest rooms and three event spaces, including a ballroom, while maintaining its classic French interior design. The renovation aims to attract a younger, well-heeled crowd without alienating loyal customers. The hotel's nightly rate starts at 695 euros, with presidential suites priced at up to 7,500 euros per night.

site_title: Disclosure of use of IPO proceeds - better rules needed
summary: Investors in initial public offerings (IPOs) often lack clear information on how their money will be used, according to a recent article. The article suggests that disclosure should be made in easy-to-understand terms, such as $1 invested, and printed on the front of the offer document. This would enable investors to easily locate the information. Currently, offer documents are lengthy, making it difficult for investors to find the necessary information.

site_title: Banks seen relying more on wholesale funding
summary: Singapore's three homegrown banks, UOB, DBS, and OCBC, are shifting towards more wholesale funding due to shrinking retail deposits, with loan-deposit ratios reaching 100% at UOB. This makes them more vulnerable to liquidity shocks, as seen in the global financial crisis. Analysts warn that banks may struggle with loan growth targets, particularly DBS and OCBC, which saw their Chinese loan book contract in the second quarter. The banks' reliance on wholesale funding increases their risk when liquidity dries up.

site_title: Port Hedland union cancels strike plan
summary: Tugboat engineers at Australia's Port Hedland canceled an intended strike that threatened exports of a quarter of the world's seaborne iron ore cargoes. The strike was called off after the Australian Institute of Marine & Power Engineers failed to serve the required action notice within the required period. The union will continue talks with Teekay Shipping and may ballot to strike again, posing a risk to exports by companies including BHP and Fortescue Metals Group, which could cost suppliers about A$100 million a day.

site_title: Poor showing by NOL's liner business hits Q2
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) posted a Q2 net loss of US$53.7 million, 55% worse than last year, due to poor performance from its liner business. Despite the loss, the group's core Ebit loss decreased by 52% to US$15 million, and core Ebitda doubled to US$78 million. APL's liner business achieved a high utilisation rate of over 90% through strict capacity management, while APL Logistics saw revenue and core Ebit increase. NOL's focus on cost management and operational efficiency has returned US$200 million in cost savings so far this year.

site_title: Samudra Energy pulls IPO, reasons clouded
summary: Samudra Energy, a South-east Asian energy group, has pulled its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, citing market volatility as the reason. The decision comes despite a strong demand for IPOs in the market, which had seen a surge in listings in recent weeks. The company's CEO attributed the decision to timing, citing a need to ensure a strong after-market performance. Analysts suggest that company-specific factors, such as the lack of understanding in the sector, may have also played a role.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Singapore hotel properties reported a 81% plunge in Q2 net profit to S$7 million, mainly due to lower profits from The Interlace condominium development. Property developer Hiap Hoe warned of a net loss in Q2, citing stamp duty expenses and lower sales revenue. YHS posted an 82% drop in Q2 net profit to S$5.19 million due to lower revenue and smaller gains from asset disposal. China XLX Fertiliser will be delisted on Aug 12 after a privatisation exercise.

site_title: Creating poetry in the prose of life
summary: A wine writer shares his thoughts on the beauty of sharing wine with friends, stating that it doubles the enjoyment and reinforces friendships. He reviews two Barolo wines, Ceretto's 1985 "Zonchera" and Elio Altare's 1996 Barolo Brunate, finding both to be well-balanced and complex. The writer notes that these wines are not expensive, but may require 10-20 years to reach their full potential. He also reviews a 1993 Domaine Joseph Drouhin Beaune Blanc 1er Cru Clos des Mouches, praising its elegance and smoothness. The writer concludes that sharing wine with friends is a key part of the poetry in life.

site_title: Drawing asserts its place in art
summary: A new art show, "A Drawing Show," at Yeo's Workshop in Singapore aims to dispel the notion that drawings are inferior to paintings. The exhibition features four talented artists, including Singaporean and Thai artists, showcasing their drawings on paper. The show includes works by abstract artist Ian Woo, who creates intricate and chaotic drawings using black pencil on paper. The exhibition runs until September 14, offering fans an opportunity to acquire Woo's works at lower prices than his paintings, with pieces ranging from S$3,200 to S$12,000.

site_title: Self-storage trusts are the hottest Reits in US
summary: US self-storage trusts, a type of real estate investment trust (REIT), are experiencing a surge in popularity as investors seek yield in a frothy equities market and low-yielding bonds. The top-performing self-storage REIT, Extra Space Storage Inc, has an annualized return of 36.7% over the past three years. With an estimated 25 million storage units in the US, the industry is expected to continue growing, driven by robust demand and a steady stream of customers. Self-storage is particularly attractive to investors due to its high dividend yields and low overhead costs.

site_title: Swiss property market inching closer to bubble, says UBS
summary: The Swiss property market is nearing a bubble, according to the UBS Swiss Real Estate Bubble Index, which rose to 1.24 points in the second quarter. Risks to the Swiss economy remain high, driven by strong residential property price growth and mortgage expansion outpacing income growth. The Swiss National Bank has urged banks to allot credit prudently to prevent a real estate market crisis similar to the 1990s, which saw bank failures and a recession. The government has also required banks to build up capital to make them more resilient to writedowns.

site_title: Another strong quarter for Rotary
summary: Rotary Engineering's second-quarter net profit more than doubled to S$13.1 million, from S$5.1 million a year ago, driven by a 51% surge in revenue to S$190.8 million. Profit margins increased to 17% in the first half, attributed to productivity gains and innovative construction methods. The company expects growing demand in Singapore and the Middle East, particularly in LNG transport and storage infrastructure.

site_title: Saudi operations lift Vallianz Q2 bottom line
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a significant surge in its second-quarter net profit to US$5.3 million, driven by higher revenue from its Saudi Arabian operations. The company's revenue soared to US$38.6 million, compared to US$4.7 million last year, thanks to charter revenue from its offshore support vessels in the Middle East. CEO Darren Yeo expressed optimism about the company's prospects in the Middle East and other emerging markets, citing increasing offshore exploration activity and energy reforms in Mexico.

site_title: 'Cakes' to mark National Day
summary: Local artist Angela Chong creates a kueh-inspired mixed media installation titled "The Art of Celebration" for Singapore's National Day. The installation, featuring over 60 hand-folded paper sculptures, showcases 14 local kuehs and aims to preserve traditional desserts that may be easily forgotten. Chong hopes the work will bring back memories and remind people of special events or occasions. The exhibition is free and open at Scotts Square atrium until Aug 31, with a kueh-making workshop also available.

site_title: Egypt in ambitious Suez Canal makeover
summary: Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi announced plans to build a new Suez Canal expansion, aiming to complete it within a year. The $4 billion project, led by the military, will create jobs and revenue for the government. The new waterway will expand the existing canal's capacity, linking the Red Sea to the Mediterranean. The plan is seen as a symbol of national pride and a bid to distance the current regime from corruption and mismanagement under former President Hosni Mubarak.

site_title: US real estate website Zillow's Q2 sales rise 68% to US$78.7m
summary: Zillow Inc reported a 68% increase in Q2 sales to $78.7 million, beating analyst estimates. The company's traffic increased, with 81.1 million average monthly unique users, and its Premier Agent advertising programme revenue rose 82%. Zillow raised its annual sales forecast and is set to acquire Trulia Inc for $3.5 billion, positioning itself for a larger share of the US $12 billion real estate advertising market. The company expects Q3 sales to rise to $87-88 million and full-year revenue to be $321-323 million.

site_title: Russia hackers loot 1.2 billion passwords, says US security firm
summary: A US security firm, Hold Security LLC, claims that a Russian hacking gang has amassed 1.2 billion stolen user names and passwords, linked to 500 million unique e-mail addresses. The records were discovered after seven months of research and are believed to have been gathered from 420,000 websites, including Fortune 500 companies. The hackers operated from central Russia and used a botnet to extract data. The breach is considered significant, with cybercrime costs estimated at US$575 billion annually, and highlights the threat of elite hackers in the Eastern European shadow economy.

site_title: Medical drama that requires a strong stomach
summary: The Knick, a new Cinemax original series, premiered on August 8, 2014, and is a medical drama directed by Oscar winner Steven Soderbergh. Set in a fictional New York hospital during the early 20th century, the show features Clive Owen as Dr. John Thackery, a gifted surgeon struggling to save patients amidst racial prejudice and corruption. With exceptional production values and rich storytelling, The Knick redefines cable-produced shows, but may not be suitable for viewers with weak stomachs due to its graphic content.

site_title: Demand from China to stay strong: Aussie realty
summary: Australian real estate company Ausin Group expects to sell A$1.5 billion in new homes and arrange A$500 million in loans for Chinese buyers, a 66% increase in sales and 100% increase in loans, due to strong demand from China. The company attributes this growth to Chinese purchasers overtaking Americans as the biggest buyers of real estate in Australia, with A$5.9 billion invested in commercial and residential properties in 2013. This trend is seen as a risk to the Chinese economy, with authorities trying to prevent a collapse of the real estate market.

site_title: Gross rental yields in uptick for first-half 2014
summary: Gross rental yields in Singapore's private condo market increased in the first half of 2014, with suburban areas experiencing the largest rebound, particularly in the north-east region. The median gross rental yield rose to 4.03% in the north-east region, up from 3.73% last year. However, market watchers predict this trend may be short-lived, citing the impending supply of condo units and softening leasing market, which could lead to a decline in yields.

site_title: Blackstone's Hilton LBO hits sweet spot
summary: Blackstone's Hilton Worldwide Holdings has reduced its long-term debt by over 40% to $12.2 billion since the private equity firm took control in 2007. The company has achieved this through cost cuts and franchising agreements outside the US, boosting revenue. Hilton's debt-to-earnings ratio has decreased from over 12 times to about five times, and yields on its bonds have fallen more than half a percentage point. The company is on track to achieve an investment-grade rating by the end of 2015, with some analysts predicting it may win such a rating by the end of next year.

site_title: Creative restructures, narrows Q4 loss
summary: Creative Technology narrowed its net loss for the fiscal fourth quarter to $3.39 million, a 48% decrease from the previous year, thanks to higher tax credits and a restructuring exercise that reduced worldwide headcount. The company also reported a 24% decrease in net sales to $23 million due to market conditions. Creative incurred a $2.2 million employee severance charge and a full-year net loss of $21.8 million, reversing from a net profit of $16.7 million.

site_title: COE premiums rise across the board
summary: COE premiums have risen across the board in Singapore as dealers rush to secure certificates of entitlement following a smaller-than-expected new quota. Category A COEs increased by 13.1% to 1,143, while Category B COEs rose 4.6% to 1,010. Category E COEs, however, decreased by 18.4% to 478, and Category C and D COEs also fell. Dealers are concerned that the reduction in Cat E COEs could lead to further price increases, with some predicting a potential hike of $3,000 for Cat B COEs in the coming weeks.

site_title: Car distributors close ranks for stronger voice
summary: The Singapore motor industry, comprising top brands such as Audi, BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Toyota, met in a confidential meeting to discuss forming a stronger voice when dealing with the government. The meeting, initiated by Volkswagen, aimed to address recent rapid policy changes and dwindling membership in the existing Motor Traders Association of Singapore (MTA). Industry representatives sought to revamp the MTA and engage the government directly, with the goal of creating a smoother path for the industry's product planning and sales forecasts.

site_title: China and housing loans in focus at banks' Q2 results
summary: China and mortgage loans took center stage for three local banks, OCBC, UOB, and DBS, as they reported Q2 results. Concerns over China arose from a fake commodity financing scam in Qingdao, but banks pared down their exposure to the country. UOB boosted its China presence, while OCBC and DBS reduced their exposure due to risk assessment and reduced lending opportunities. Despite this, banks reported weaker-than-expected interest margins, with OCBC guiding for a decline in the quarters to come.

site_title: OCBC eyeing new home loan customers via video contest
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a video contest to attract new home loan customers amid a dismal home loan market in Singapore. The contest, which runs until August, offers the lowest home loan rates in town, including a fixed rate of 0.49% for the first year. Top five winners will receive interest-free first year or S$1,000 of vouchers if they don't take a loan. The promotion aims to boost sales and entice existing customers to refinance with OCBC.
