site_title: Yongnam sinks into the red in Q2
summary: Yongnam Holdings, a Singapore-based structural steel contractor, reported a net loss of S$5.26 million in its fiscal second quarter, down from a net profit of S$8.63 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 46.5% to S$61.6 million, primarily due to the completion of major projects and increasing competitive pressure. The company has an order book of S$275 million and is pursuing S$1.1 billion worth of new projects, with a positive outlook for the second half of the fiscal year.

site_title: Haze pollution law is a positive first step
summary: Singapore's Transboundary Haze Pollution Act, passed on August 6, 2014, aims to combat haze pollution from Indonesian deforestation. The law allows for fines of up to S$2 million per company, with penalties increasing over time. While it's a positive step, its effectiveness relies on cooperation from Indonesia and regional governments. The Act's detection capabilities are limited, relying on circumstantial evidence and satellite maps. Singapore hopes Indonesia's new president-elect, Joko "Jokowi" Widodo, will cooperate to enforce the law and address the root cause of the haze issue.

site_title: M-Reits unfazed by quarter-point rate hike
summary: Malaysian Reits remain a defensive choice for investors, as the recent 25 basis point interest rate hike is expected to have minimal impact due to the bulk of their loans being fixed. Examples include Axis and CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust, where 70-95% of loans are fixed. Economists are divided on whether the central bank will implement another rate hike before the year is out or give borrowers a reprieve. Reits are expected to yield steady returns, making them a sound investment choice.

site_title: Malaysia facing a towering problem
summary: Malaysia is facing a building glut, with excessive construction in the Klang Valley and Johor, according to property tycoon Chua Ma Yu. This has led to concerns of a substantial surplus, as seen before in the 1990s. The construction boom is driven by a constant influx of new developments, including townships, apartments, malls, and towers. Experts warn that this glut may lead to a market correction, impacting property prices and the overall real estate market.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Samudra Energy has pulled its IPO due to market uncertainty and concerns over a potential share price drop. The motor industry has met to discuss unifying their voice when dealing with the government. OCBC Bank launched a home loan video contest offering the lowest rates. Hackers in Russia have looted 1.2 billion user names and passwords. Sembcorp Industries' Q2 earnings rose 8.3% due to higher marine business profits. Singapore Reits have tempered, and the government will improve nursing salaries and career development. Malaysia's exports growth slowed to 8% year-on-year in June.

site_title: Sembcorp Q2 profit up 8.3% at S$179m
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 8.3% increase in Q2 net profit to S$179 million, driven by higher operating profit from its marine business and contributions from its urban development project in China. Revenue rose 1.4% to S$2.53 billion, while utilities net profit declined 17% due to competition in the Singapore power market. The marine business saw a 5% increase in Q2 net profit, while the urban development business increased 136% to S$24.3 million. Sembcorp declared a tax-exempt interim dividend of 5 cents per share.

site_title: Leng Beng's elder son buys Jervois Rd GCB for S$18.8m
summary: Sherman Kwek, the 30-something son of City Developments and Singapore Hong Leong Group executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng, purchased a two-storey Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore for S$18.8 million, or about S$1,247 per square foot. The 7,600 sq ft property has six en suite bedrooms and a small swimming pool. This marks the fourth time the property has changed hands in the past 11 years, with similar transactions occurring in 2003, 2006, and 2007.

site_title: June passenger traffic growth slows to 4.7%
summary: Global passenger traffic grew 4.7% in June, down from May's 6.2%, according to the International Air Transport Association (Iata). Capacity increased 5% in June, resulting in a 81.5% passenger load factor. For the first six months, air traffic volumes rose 5.9%, exceeding last year's 5.2% growth.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Group breaks into aircraft leasing industry
summary: Indonesia's Lion Group has inked its first deal for its leasing subsidiary, Transportation Partners, with China's 9 Air to lease three Boeing 737-800 planes. The deal is significant as China needs nearly 6,000 new jets over the next 20 years, and many will be leased rather than bought. Lion Group aims to diversify its business with a strong leasing operation, offering flexibility in a market with regional oversupply of aircraft.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Heeton Holdings reported a 29.8% decline in Q2 net profit to S$4.44 million, as revenue more than tripled to S$22.8 million while costs increased five times to S$17.6 million. The company's figures were restated from the year-ago quarter.

site_title: Transformation reaping results for Rowsley
summary: Rowsley, a MAINBOARD-listed real estate company, posted a net profit of S$6.1 million in the second quarter ended June, up from a net loss of S$975,000 in the same period last year. The firm's Ebitda stood at S$9.9 million and revenue reached S$22.1 million for the quarter. CEO Lock Wai Han attributed the transformation to the acquisition of RSP Architects Planners & Engineers, which contributed S$6.1 million in net profit. The company expects Vantage Bay, a waterfront residential development, to contribute significantly to its bottom line due to Iskandar's attractions.

site_title: Biosensors posts 18% Q1 profit fall, sees more competition ahead
summary: Biosensors International Group reported an 18% fall in its first-quarter net profit due to higher costs and expenses. Revenue rose 5% despite the decline. The company warned of increased competition and price erosion in the global DES market, where its devices are used to prevent artery reclogging. This challenges the management's expectations for the company's future performance.

site_title: Fox drops US$75b takeover bid for Time Warner
summary: Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox withdrew its $75 billion takeover bid for Time Warner after the media company's board refused to engage in talks and Fox's stock price declined 11% since the offer became public. Time Warner rejected the offer, citing that it undervalued Fox's stock and wouldn't create more value than its growth plan. Fox instead authorized a $6 billion repurchase of its shares, and CEO Jeff Bewkes stated the company's growth plan would create more value than any proposal Fox could offer.

site_title: Start-up uses Web to help towns market their property
summary: Two Harvard University graduates, Cristina Garmendia and Alexander Kapur, are launching a start-up called OpportunitySpace to help municipalities market their publicly owned real estate. The platform creates an online database with essential property information, such as square footage and delinquent taxes, making it easier for developers to find and invest in these assets. The start-up has completed a pilot program with four Rhode Island municipalities, including Providence, and plans to charge cities a subscription fee, generating revenue through more sophisticated data sales to the private sector.

site_title: Airbus has 705 net orders in Jan-July period
summary: Airbus secured 705 net aircraft orders between January and July, surpassing Boeing's unadjusted orders for the year. The company's Farnborough Airshow performance marked its best ever, with 980 orders won. Boeing reported 837 gross orders and 783 net sales, with some cancellations and conversions included. Airbus attributed the cancellations to model conversions, which will be replaced by revamped versions. The company aims to deliver more than 626 aircraft in 2014, exceeding previous deliveries.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q2 profit soars
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a net profit of S$18.6 million for the second quarter, a 173% leap from the same period last year. Revenue rose 13.4% to S$123.6 million, driven by strong contributions from its construction and property divisions. This marks a significant improvement from the S$109.1 million in Q2 2013.

site_title: SingPost Q1 profit up 5% at S$39.2m
summary: SingPost's Q1 net profit rose 5.1% to S$39.24 million, driven by growth in its e-commerce business. However, its underlying net profit was marginally down 0.2% due to a one-off gain on property disposal. The company's mail business declined, with operating profit falling 4.8% and revenue growing 4.8%. Despite cost pressures, SingPost maintained its interim dividend and plans to invest in its core mail business and e-commerce logistics network. The company's shares gained 1 cent to S$1.76.

site_title: India's fixed income sector evolving
summary: India's fixed income sector is expected to evolve with the new government's reforms and market liberalization, potentially leading to a near 7% GDP growth rate over the coming decade. Foreign investment is expected to drive this growth, with FDI rising to an average of 2.5% of GDP. India's credit markets are projected to triple in size by 2019, with the Indian US$/G3 bond market expected to reach $160 billion by 2018. The sovereign rating is expected to remain unchanged in the near term, with potential upgrades requiring improvement in inflation, fiscal balance, and current account.

site_title: Tough market prompts more property agency tie-ups
summary: JLL Singapore has acquired a 20% stake in PropNex International, a project marketing arm of PropNex, to access the mass market home segment. The partnership allows JLL to leverage PropNex's network and expertise, while PropNex gains global reach through JLL's international presence. This move is part of a consolidation trend in the Singapore property market, with other agencies forming alliances to share resources and expand their networks. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to counter the shrinking residential market.

site_title: Singapore Reits' winning streak appears to have faded
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have underperformed the market this quarter, with the FTSE ST Reit Index falling 0.5% compared to a 6.4% surge in Q2. This contrasts with May, when S-Reits outperformed developer stocks and the Straits Times Index. The sector's underperformance is attributed to a reversal in investors' "flight to safety" and aversion to China, as well as concerns over macro-economic headwinds. As interest rates are expected to rise late next year, S-Reit managers are taking steps to refinance expiring debt, which may mitigate the impact of higher borrowing costs.

site_title: Firms get extra S$10m boost from Spring
summary: Spring Singapore has set aside an additional S$10 million to support companies in developing and adopting new standards. This funding complements the existing S$20 million set aside in 2011. The Manufacturing Standards Committee will focus on emerging technologies and processes in Singapore, while also exploring new standards in sectors such as the silver industry and medical technology. The move aims to enhance the adoption of standards and boost growth in key sectors.

site_title: China developers sit tight as land prices stay high
summary: Chinese property developers are rejecting high-priced government land auctions amid the country's industry downturn, with plots in Beijing going unsold for the first time since 2011. Developers are seeking lower prices, while local governments are refusing to budge due to land sales accounting for a bulk of their revenues. This mismatch highlights the persistent issue of price expectations between developers and local authorities, as the real estate industry continues to correct following the central government's efforts to cool the market.

site_title: StarHub earnings fall 6.3% in Q2
summary: StarHub's Q2 earnings fell 6.3% to S$94.3 million due to stiffer competition in the broadband market, with revenue dropping 1.8% to S$576.4 million. Broadband revenue declined 17.2% and mobile revenue shrunk 1.4%. However, the postpaid segment added 14,800 subscribers, and pay-TV revenue grew 3% to S$98.4 million. The company now expects service revenue to be maintained at last year's level for 2014.

site_title: Dutch firm to head MH370 search off Australia
summary: A Dutch firm, Fugro, will lead the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in the Indian Ocean off Australia's coast, starting a new phase within a month. The search area spans 60,000 sq km, focusing on the jetliner's last known location. Fugro will use two vessels equipped with sonar and video cameras to scour the seafloor, which is up to 5,000 m deep. The search is expected to take up to a year and cost around A$52 million, with Australia providing A$90 million and Malaysia contributing four vessels and gear.

site_title: Dealing with fallout from social media
summary: A shipboard training firm had implemented a policy of confiscating mobile phones to prevent the spread of unverified reports about a fatal accident, highlighting the risks of social media in the shipping industry. This incident occurred after a young cadet's friends used their phones to inform others about the accident, leading to confusion and misinformation. The firm's decision was seen as a wise move to prevent further harm.

site_title: Emirates scraps West African route in response to Ebola
summary: Emirates has suspended flights to Conakry, Guinea, citing guidance from health authorities due to the Ebola outbreak. The airline, which was the only one to halt services, plans to reassess its West African routes in light of feedback from the WHO and CDC. Rival carriers such as Air France, British Airways, and Brussels Airlines continue to operate flights with heightened medical checks, including temperature screenings and questionnaires for passengers. The Ebola outbreak has infected over 1,440 people and killed 826.

site_title: China's anti-corruption drive looks sincere
summary: China's anti-corruption drive, launched by Xi Jinping in 2012, has reached a high level with the investigation of former Politburo member Zhou Yongkang, a close associate of Bo Xilai, who was jailed for corruption. The investigation, which has implicated over 60,000 officials, including senior-ranking party members, is seen as sincere and real by many, as it targets corruption across all levels, not just political enemies. Public opinion in China supports the drive, which aims to address the pervasive corruption and its economic consequences, such as local government debt and over-investment.

site_title: June airfreight volume up 4.9% for Asia-Pacific
summary: Asia-Pacific airlines' airfreight volume increased 4.9% year-over-year in June, surpassing the global 2.3% growth, driven by a significant pickup in demand. The region's carriers have benefited from improved market conditions, with the Middle East experiencing the strongest growth rate of 7% in June. The Asia-Pacific region's freight load factor rose to 56.6%, while freight volumes for the first half of 2014 expanded 4.1% year-over-year.

site_title: GLP sees longer-term benefit from Chinese investment
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 12% drop in net profit to US$179.4 million for its first quarter due to factors such as the contribution of assets to its Japanese Reit and absence of foreign-exchange gains. Revenue rose 18% to US$169.3 million, driven by higher rents and lease-ups in China. The company's Chinese investors, including Bank of China and China Life, now own about a quarter of its Chinese subsidiary, leading to dilution and reduced profit for shareholders. CEO Ming Z Mei expects longer-term benefits from the investment, citing growth opportunities and increased access to land.

site_title: One-off gain for Rickmers doubles Q2 net to US$16m
summary: Rickmers Maritime's Q2 net profit more than doubled to US$16 million, driven by a one-off gain of US$11.4 million from the early settlement of a convertible loan. Charter revenue dropped 10% year-on-year to US$31.5 million, but the company maintained a distribution per unit of 0.60 US cent. Rickmers expects good earnings visibility for its fleet, which is fully chartered, and secured US$280.2 million in revenue through 2019.

site_title: July SGX securities trading up 2% over previous month
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) securities trading saw a 2% increase in July, reversing a downward trend since the penny stock saga in October. Total securities traded valued S$21 billion, down 24% from last year. Market observers consider the uptick a potential sign of recovery, but caution that it may be a blip. Analysts attribute the increase to investors' better market prospects, but warn that the Singapore market still lags behind other economies.

site_title: PCRT's DPU remains at 0.95 cent
summary: PCRT announced a 2Q DPU of 0.95 Singapore cents, bringing H1 DPU to 1.90 cents. Distributable income for 2Q was similar to that for 2Q 2013, at S$10.9 million. The trust's earn-out fund had S$26.4 million left for H2 2014, but DPU is likely to decline after income support expires at year-end.

site_title: China plans to build more LNG tankers
summary: China plans to build 50 LNG tankers over the next decade, aiming to secure its energy supply chain and boost its high-tech shipbuilding capabilities. The move will pose a challenge to South Korean and Japanese shipyards, which have dominated the market for 30 years. China's goal is to double its gas supply by 2020 and increase LNG imports to 60 million tonnes, as it transitions away from coal to cleaner fuels to reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: About 1% productivity growth likely this year
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Lim Hng Kiang announced that Singapore's overall productivity growth for this year is expected at about 1%, falling short of the 2-3% target. Despite weak recent productivity growth, labor productivity has grown by 2.9% annually from 2009 to last year, with some sectors such as transport engineering and precision engineering showing sustained good growth. The government aims to meet its 2-4% GDP growth target for this year, barring downside risks.

site_title: Impact of commission-free life insurance policies on earnings unclear: Fitch
summary: Singapore's introduction of a commission-free life insurance scheme may boost access to life insurance for lower and middle-income consumers, who appear underinsured. The scheme, requiring insurers to sell protection up to S$400,000, is a "credit positive" for the industry, eliminating commission costs and reducing premium rates. However, Fitch Ratings notes that this could hit profitability, with insurers needing to adapt their sales strategies. The move is expected to boost penetration rates and prompt a re-evaluation of distribution channels.

site_title: White Paper highlights Japan's increasing defence expenditures
summary: Japan's defence expenditures are rising after a decade of decline, according to the country's annual White Paper. The paper singles out China, North Korea, and Russia as security threats, warning of potential escalations in military provocations by North Korea and unilateral changes in the status quo by China and Russia. Defence expenditures have increased since Prime Minister Abe's assumption of power, while the number of military personnel has stopped declining. The paper also notes Japan's need to adapt to a more complex security environment, citing the country's growing economic ties with Russia despite differences in systems.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Pressure mounts on Singapore's Integrated Shield Plan sector to find ways to stay profitable amid 1% productivity growth expected this year. The sector faces challenges due to low claims and increasing competition. Meanwhile, global news includes China urging South-east Asia to support openness as US tariffs loom, and Chinese property shares surging on unverified reports of meeting to revive the sector. US weekly jobless claims fall unexpectedly, while China unveils new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Golden times for equity investors
summary: The US economy is experiencing a "Goldilocks" recovery, characterized by steady growth, low interest rates, and a booming stock market. This environment is reminiscent of the 1990s, but the Federal Reserve's dominant presence has overshadowed other factors. Experts attribute the current bull market to a combination of factors, including productivity gains and dollar asset diversification. As the economy continues to grow, many expect the bull market to persist, with retail investors driving growth in the ETF market in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Release of nanu app becomes a talking point
summary: Singapore-based startup Gentay Communications unveiled its free call app, nanu, generating buzz due to its potential to capture the huge Android market share. The app, developed in 8 months, allows free voice calls to non-nanu numbers and landlines, including overseas calls. Gentay aims to reach 100,000 users within the first 24 hours of its launch.

site_title: S$246.8m valuation loss hits Forterra Trust's Q2 results
summary: Forterra Trust reported a Q2 net loss of S$138.2 million, with a S$246.8 million loss in valuation of its investment properties. The trust's revenue dropped to S$13.4 million, primarily due to the sale of Central Plaza and Beijing Logistics Park. The management has reassessed its development and operational assumptions, adopting a "more prudent and realistic approach" for The Place, with an expected annualized gross revenue of over 500 million yuan.

site_title: Packer makes another try in Las Vegas
summary: Crown Resorts Ltd, controlled by billionaire James Packer, plans to open a casino on the Las Vegas Strip in 2018 after purchasing a 14-hectare site for US$280 million. This is the company's third attempt in Las Vegas, following previous failed ventures by Fontainebleau Resorts and Cannery Casino Resorts. The resort will diversify Crown's earnings from casinos in Melbourne, Perth, and London, and will be built in partnership with Andrew Pascal, former president of Wynn Las Vegas.

site_title: US west coast ports headed for possible strike, shutdown
summary: US West Coast ports face a potential strike by 7,000 longshore workers joining a picket line by 120 disgruntled truck drivers, who walked off the job last month. The longshoremen, who have worked without a contract since July 11, are now free to join picket lines and could shut down the ports, affecting $435 billion in annual trade. Talks between the union and employers resumed on Monday, with the union's concerns including workers' safety, health, and pension benefits. A strike could have significant economic impacts, including a loss of $2.1 billion per day to the US economy.

site_title: Businessman to fund, build, operate int'l-standard track
summary: Richard Tan, managing director of Arina International Holding, has invested S$2 million to build a 960-metre-long international-standard karting circuit in Singapore, with a total rental of S$500,000 and the fee of a renowned F1 track designer, Hermann Tilke. Despite the costs, Tan believes in letting the product "do the talking" and aims to make the circuit world-class. The facility is expected to be completed by end-October, with Tan already losing money due to rent payments since July 1.

site_title: Dhaka's fight for green spaces
summary: Residents in Dhaka, Bangladesh staged a sit-in protest against a private sports club that seized a children's park for development, demanding its return. The park, a rare green oasis in the densely populated city, is just one of many public spaces that have been snatched by property developers, clubs, and politicians for profit. Officials estimate two-thirds of public spaces have disappeared, leaving residents without access to parks, playgrounds, and open spaces, exacerbating the city's pollution, urbanization, and social issues.

site_title: KL's rate-hike outlook makes ringgit best carry-trade bet
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to boost borrowing costs to 3.5% by year-end, according to economists. This increase in interest rates is providing the best carry-trade returns in the ringgit, with trades in the past three months rising 2.8%. Barclays and Bank of America Merrill Lynch predict one more rate rise of 25 basis points this year. The move is seen as a response to the country's economic outlook, with the ringgit benefiting from the higher interest rates.

site_title: CapitaLand Q2 sales slide
summary: CapitaLand's second quarter sales dropped 13.2% to S$875.3 million due to slower development sales in Singapore and China. However, the group's net profit rose 14.5% to S$438.7 million driven by stronger operating profits, higher revaluation gains, and a write-back of impairments. The company's portfolio rebalancing has yielded results, with 75% of total assets now in investment properties. CapitaLand aims to achieve an 8-12% return on equity in the next three to five years.

site_title: Compliance costs boost loan outsourcing
summary: Banks are exiting the mortgage business due to increased compliance costs, which have pushed up costs to a record $6,253 per loan. PHH Corp, the largest US outsourcer of home loans, is capitalizing on this trend, planning to invest $821 million from the sale of its fleet management unit in mortgage operations. PHH expects to increase lending to $80 billion a year, a 57% increase from 2013, and is seeking to renegotiate existing outsourcing contracts as compliance costs rise.

site_title: Dealers cite car loan curbs for rise in sales of cheaper cars
summary: Dealers in Singapore attribute the rise in sales of cheaper cars to tightened car loan curbs, not just the re-classification of Category A Certificates of Entitlement. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) credits the power cap, along with engine-displacement, for the shift. However, dealers say the loan curbs have a greater impact, as they make premium cars less affordable. The re-classification of Category A has a smaller impact, according to the LTA. This shift may indicate a change in consumer preferences towards more affordable vehicles.

site_title: High claims, costs hit integrated shield plans
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plan (IP) sector is facing pressure to remain profitable due to rising claims and management and distribution costs. The underwriting profit margin has shrunk from 17.9% in 2009 to 3.5% last year, with claims increasing by 68.6% and distribution costs by 16.6%. Insurers attribute the rise in claims to a "liberal mentality" among patients, while others point to medical inflation and lack of transparency in healthcare costs. The sector's sustainability is uncertain, but insurers are working to improve cost management and transparency to remain competitive.

site_title: SIA will operate flights to Sapporo in December, January
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will operate 14 flights to Sapporo, Japan, in December and January, catering to the peak winter travel season. The flights will be operated on Mondays and Fridays, using 285-seater Airbus A330-300s, and will depart from Singapore's Changi Airport. This expansion is part of SIA's efforts to capitalize on the growing demand for winter sports travel.

site_title: Global financial system ripe for change
summary: Argentina's sovereign debt default may not have significant global financial implications, given the country's long history of capital market exclusion. The dispute with US hedge funds could lead to Argentina devaluing its currency, triggering inflation, but the impact is expected to be contained within the country's economy. However, the IMF warns that without an international treaty on sovereign debt defaults, the global financial system could face uncertainty and challenges in restructuring debt for other countries. The IMF proposes an international debt restructuring mechanism, but its proposal has been met with resistance from major stakeholders.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q2 DPU lower
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 4.9% dip in distributable income to S$22.1 million for Q2, driven by lower hotel occupancies and average room rates. Distribution per unit fell 13.3% to 1.24 Singapore cents due to an enlarged stapled security base. Net property income edged down 1.3% to S$26.6 million, while gross revenue grew 1% to S$29.6 million. The trust manager expects a challenging operating environment for hospitality players, but believes property renovations will improve its position.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's July PMI rose 51.5, boosted by new orders and production and inventory levels. A mobile call app, NANU, is set to launch worldwide, offering free calls. Japan and China are in talks over the Senkaku Islands. DBS Group introduced yuan forex options for Chinese clients. SembCorp Marine's Q2 profit increased 5.4% due to rig building and fixed platforms. Malaysian banks compete for low-cost funds, while a Chinese central bank loan may be a form of monetary easing.

site_title: Free calls from today: thanks to app by S'pore startup
summary: Singapore-based startup Gentay Communications has launched Nanu, the world's first free mobile call app, available for download worldwide. The app provides free calls to non-Nanu users and landlines, aiming to end telco dominance and eliminate phone bills. CEO Martin Nygate hopes to make mobile calls free anytime, anywhere, revolutionizing the industry.

site_title: Thumbs up for Singapore Reits
summary: Moody's forecasts Singapore's Reits sector to grow 4% in 2014, driven by a healthy operating environment and manageable refinancing risk. The majority of Reits' debt is tied to fixed interest rates, reducing refinancing risk. The office sector is expected to perform well, while the retail sector faces challenges due to weaker tenant sales. The hotel segment's growth is capped by moderating tourist arrivals, and the warehousing segment faces pressure from new supply. 17 Singapore-based Reits have a stable outlook, with 16 carrying stable outlooks.

site_title: Moscow curbs likely on EU's trans-Siberia flights
summary: Russia may impose restrictions or a ban on European airlines using trans-Siberian routes in response to EU sanctions over Ukraine, raising flight costs to Asia. The move could affect airlines like Lufthansa, British Airways, and Air France, potentially leading to one billion euros in losses over three months. The restrictions would increase flight times, fuel use, and costs, giving Asian rivals a competitive advantage. The Russian Transport Ministry and civil aviation authority have declined to comment on the report, but Aeroflot, a state-controlled airline, could also be impacted by the potential ban.

site_title: Cheung Kong makes bid to buy planes from Awas
summary: Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong-based conglomerate led by billionaire Li Ka-shing, has made a bid to buy a portfolio of planes from lessor Awas, valued at about US$11 billion. This acquisition would be Cheung Kong's first major investment in aircraft leasing, as the company diversifies its investments into infrastructure. Awas plans to break up its fleet of 280 planes and sell about 100 newer aircraft for up to US$5 billion.

site_title: SembMarine Q2 profit up 5.4% at S$131.6m
summary: SembMarine, a Singapore-based rig builder, reported a 5.4% increase in Q2 net profit to S$131.6 million, driven by stronger rig building and fixed platform results. Revenue rose 19% to S$1.34 billion, with rig building segment contributing 39.1% to the increase. The company delivered six jack-up rigs and secured new contracts worth S$2.5 billion. Despite stable long-term market fundamentals, SembMarine is concerned about the slowdown in capital expenditure and intense competition.

site_title: DBS among first to offer yuan forex options in China
summary: DBS Group Holdings' China unit has completed a series of yuan-denominated foreign currency derivative transactions for corporate clients, marking one of the first moves by banks to execute such transactions following China's new regulations. The transactions include European-style options and a yuan cross-currency swap, allowing clients to hedge against currency translation risks. The regulations, which expanded the suite of hedging products available to Chinese companies, aim to allow greater two-way fluctuation of the yuan within a broader trading band. Other banks, including Deutsche Bank and HSBC, have also executed similar transactions.

site_title: HK banks hiring traders to tap Dim Sum market
summary: Hong Kong-based banks are hiring traders to capitalize on the growing Dim Sum market, which saw a significant increase in offshore renminbi bond sales in the first half of 2014. Several firms, including National Australia Bank and Deutsche Bank, are allocating additional resources to tap into the promising secondary market for Dim Sum securities. Despite global fixed-income trading being weak, HSBC expects sales of new bonds and certificates of deposit to reach 520-570 billion yuan, up from 371 billion yuan in 2013. The Dim Sum market is attracting more investor interest, both domestically and internationally.

site_title: Transboundary haze: Onus on suspected culprits to prove innocence
summary: Singapore is introducing a new law to hold companies accountable for haze pollution, with severe penalties for those found guilty. The Transboundary Haze Pollution Bill, if passed, will allow the government to establish a "casual link" between haze pollution and companies using technology such as satellite images. Companies could face fines of up to S$2 million and S$50,000 per day if they fail to comply with preventive measures. The law aims to deter companies from adopting cheap methods of clearing land, while providing a legal resource for affected individuals to seek redress from responsible parties.

site_title: PLife Reit scouring region for new opportunities
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 10.2% increase in quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to a record 2.9 Singapore cents, driven by acquisitions and rental growth in its properties. The Reit aims to consolidate its Japanese assets to achieve operating synergies and cost savings. Net property income rose 12% to S$23.6 million, and gross revenue grew 12.2% to S$25.3 million. The Reit's gearing ratio rose to 35.3% as it drew down more loans for acquisitions. Despite a positive outlook for the healthcare industry, the Reit remains mindful of macroeconomic headwinds.

site_title: GLP takes 15% stake in China state-owned firm
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has invested 2 billion yuan (S$403 million) for a 15% stake in China's largest state-owned warehouse logistics provider, China Materials Storage and Transportation Development Company (CMSTD). The investment is part of a strategic tie-up, and a joint venture will be set up to develop logistics facilities in China. GLP will hold a 49% equity stake, with the option to increase its ownership to 50%. The partnership aims to develop up to 1.3 million square meters of buildable area across China, leveraging CMSTD's land sourcing capabilities and GLP's expertise in modern logistics facilities.

site_title: Computers still vulnerable to hackers of start-up codes
summary: Intel's security designs to prevent hackers from altering computers while booting up have largely failed due to lax application by customers. Researchers at MITRE lab found many customers still haven't adopted revised security designs, leaving newer Windows computers exposed to vulnerabilities. Despite Intel's efforts, 55% of 10,000 computers with sensors deployed to test boot-up security remain vulnerable, with the actual percentage likely higher due to recent issues with Intel's UEFI guidelines.

site_title: Slide in assets value not a draw on reserves: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam clarified that a decline in investment returns or a drop in asset value due to market cycles does not constitute a draw on reserves, as long as the strategy aims for long-term returns and involves investment risk. The Constitution safeguards against "systemic erosion" of reserves, not the investment of reserves for returns. Taking investment risk is necessary for long-term returns, but it may result in fluctuations in market value, which can be managed through calculated investment decisions.

site_title: Japan, China in informal talks to resolve island spat: reports
summary: Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda reportedly met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing, fueling speculation about a potential compromise on the disputed Senkaku Islands in the East China Sea. The meeting, facilitated by Fukuda, aims to arrange a possible two-way talk between Japanese and Chinese leaders during the APEC summit in November. Analysts see the move as a step towards easing tensions between Japan and China, which have been strained over the islands since Japan's nationalization in 2012.

site_title: Pritzker plans US$104m hotel project in Seattle
summary: Billionaire John Pritzker's Commune Hotels & Resorts plans a $104 million hotel and residential project in Seattle's downtown area, featuring two 12-storey towers with 159 guest rooms and 97 rental apartments. The project, set to open in 2016, is part of a surge in development in the city, driven by growing tourism and employment. Seattle's downtown area is attracting major developments, including Amazon's expansion and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation's new headquarters, leading to concerns over density and affordability.

site_title: JP Morgan downgrades UOB to 'underweight', cuts target price
summary: JP Morgan downgraded United Overseas Bank (UOB) to 'underweight' from 'neutral', citing tighter regional liquidity, poor asset quality, and lack of deposit growth. The bank's Q2 results showed a 7.3% year-on-year rise in non-performing loans, but a 3.2% increase in net profit. JP Morgan cut its price target to S$22 from S$25, citing limited pricing power and a likely increase in the bank's loan-to-deposit ratio.

site_title: Aeroflot grounds low-cost carrier on EU sanctions
summary: Aeroflot has suspended flights of its low-cost unit OOO Dobrolet due to European Union sanctions imposed in response to the Ukraine crisis. The carrier, which was set to carry one million passengers this year, will stop flights and selling tickets due to "unprecedented pressure" from European counterparties. The EU has barred Russia's biggest lenders from selling bonds or shares within the bloc, and US restrictions have also impacted Russia's state-backed banks and companies, including billionaire Gennady Timchenko's private plane.

site_title: Hijacked S'porean ship released
summary: A hijacked Singaporean oil tanker carrying 21 sailors was released a week after being seized by pirates off Ghana in west Africa. The 3,200-tonne tanker, carrying a South Korean captain and chief engineer, was hijacked on July 26 and was released in waters off Nigeria. All sailors are unhurt, but some fuel has been stolen. The hijacking appears to have been aimed at stealing fuel, and it's unclear if a ransom was paid. Piracy off the western coast of Africa has been rising in recent years, with Nigerian pirates accounting for 31 of the region's 51 attacks last year.

site_title: Dancing for a charitable cause
summary: Aranus Bizokas and Katusha Demidova, international ballroom champions, performed at The Business Times Dream Ball charity event in Singapore, raising funds for ChildAid and supporting arts education. The event, held at Marina Bay Sands, also featured Stefano Di Filippo and Daria Chesnokova, who placed fourth in last year's Professional Latin world championships. The charity aims to raise $300,000 for the causes.

site_title: Blumont shares take another hard knock after profit warning
summary: Blumont shares dropped 12.5% to 4.2 Singapore cents after the investment holding company issued a profit warning, citing "fair value readjustments" due to market volatility. The company expects net losses for the second quarter and first-half ended June 30. This is the latest in a series of setbacks for Blumont, which has seen its shares slide in recent months.

site_title: USB devices can be used by hackers: researcher
summary: A top computer researcher has discovered that malicious software can be loaded onto tiny computer chips in USB devices, such as keyboards and thumb-drives, evading known security protections. These chips control functions of USB devices but have no built-in shields against tampering with their code. Hackers can use this technique to log keystrokes, spy on communications, destroy data, and even infect other USB devices, making it a potential new class of attacks.

site_title: Govt shortchanged NY airports: study
summary: A study by the Global Gateway Alliance found that New York's three major airports - Newark Liberty International, LaGuardia, and John F. Kennedy International - received the lowest amount of federal Airport Improvement Program grants among 369 airports surveyed by the FAA. LaGuardia, which handled 13 million departures in 2012, received just $3.8 million, comparable to a smaller Arizona airport. The study criticizes the government for underinvesting in the airports.

site_title: Premature to lift property cooling measures, says Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore's property cooling measures, introduced to curb market speculation and maintain stable prices, will not be relaxed, Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan said in parliament. Lifting the measures could lead to an upswing in demand, raising transactions and housing prices. The measures, including the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty, were introduced to prevent overbuying and maintain financial prudence. Market watchers believe the government is comfortable with a 10-15% decline in residential property prices over the next two years, which is currently being maintained.

site_title: Lui Tuck Yew: Not possible for S'pore carriers to avoid every hotspot
summary: Singapore carriers cannot avoid every conflict area due to route limitations. Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew stated that airlines must make judgment calls after considering national and global advisories, as well as information from partner airlines. This includes the July 17 flight of Malaysia Airlines' MH17 jet, which flew through the same Ukrainian airspace. Lui emphasized that each airline assesses risks independently, and Singapore carriers take necessary precautions.

site_title: ARA Asset's Q2 earnings up 36% as revenue rises 17%
summary: ARA Asset Management's Q2 earnings rose 36% to S$20.8 million, driven by higher revenue from recurrent management fees and finance income. The company's revenue climbed 17% to S$40.4 million. ARA plans to launch a billion-dollar fund, ARA Summit Development Fund I, before year's end, targeting office, retail, and logistics assets in Asia. CEO John Lim expects opportunities in the next 12-18 months, despite tightening credit in Asia.

site_title: The data-driven boardroom
summary: Singaporean boardrooms are shifting towards data-driven decision-making as the importance of business analytics becomes increasingly evident. Directors are recognizing the need for actionable data and analytics tools to forecast future trends and shape business strategies. Only 14% of Singapore corporations have well-defined analytics capabilities, leaving most companies at risk of falling behind in a data-driven landscape. Boards must prioritize analytics in risk management and growth strategies to avoid decision traps caused by lack of information and cognitive biases. By incorporating business analytics into their deliberations, directors can make more informed decisions and fulfill their governance role.

site_title: China tech firms thrive on US funds despite curbs
summary: China's tech companies are receiving significant funding from US investors, despite government curbs. In the first half of 2014, foreign currency funds poured $5 billion into venture capital, three times more than local funds. US investors account for 75% of the total amount raised, attracted by lucrative exits abroad and the lack of deep funding pools in China. China's internet giants, including Baidu, Tencent, and Alibaba, use variable interest entities to circumvent foreign investment restrictions, benefiting the country's economy while potentially undermining the rules.

site_title: Getting the hang of accruals
summary: CAI HAOXIANG, a CAI expert, emphasizes the importance of accruals in accounting, as they provide a more accurate reflection of a company's financial performance. Under accrual accounting, revenues are recorded when earned, regardless of when cash is received, and expenses are recorded when incurred, regardless of when payment is made. This approach is particularly useful for seasonal businesses like Lotus Limited, which sells mooncakes only in September. However, accrual accounting also allows companies to manipulate their earnings, potentially creating an inaccurate picture of their financial health.

site_title: July PMI uptick raises hopes for a better H2
summary: Singapore's July Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose 1.0 to 51.5, surpassing expectations and marking a one-year high. The better-than-expected reading, driven by increased new orders and production and inventory levels, has sparked hopes for a better second half. However, economists have expressed reservations about the actual outcomes, citing the sector's gloomy second quarter performance. The reading above 50 indicates growth in the manufacturing sector, but concerns remain about the sector's overall health.

site_title: S&P 500 suffers worst week since June 2012
summary: The S&P 500 Index fell 0.3% to 1,925.15, marking its worst week since June 2012, as concerns over Argentina and Portugal overshadowed positive US economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.4% to 16,493.37. Despite a jobs report showing employers added 200,000 jobs for a sixth straight month, geopolitical issues are driving investors to become more risk-averse. The Federal Reserve may have leeway to keep rates low, with Chairman Janet Yellen citing wage growth as a concern.

site_title: New Turf City operator got into property accidentally
summary: Cogent Holdings, a logistics management company, unexpectedly entered the property management business after acquiring the former Turf City site, which included two Grandstand buildings, in 2013. Despite initial challenges, the company successfully turned around the dilapidated mall, increasing revenue from its property management segment to S$22.3 million in 2013. The Grandstand now boasts 1 million square feet of retail shops, diners, and kids' activities, and Cogent plans to expand its property management business by acquiring "neglected or disused" properties to revamp and increase income.

site_title: Lufthansa to resume flights to northern Iraq
summary: German airline Lufthansa will resume flights to Arbil in northern Iraq starting Saturday, avoiding airspace controlled by the Islamic State militant group. Flights to Asia and the Middle East will also detour around Iraq. This decision comes after Royal Jordanian suspended flights to Baghdad for 24 hours for security reasons, following the suspension of flights over Iraq by several major airlines in the wake of the MH-17 downing in Ukraine. Lufthansa's new routes will not significantly lengthen flight times.

site_title: Pamper your locks
summary: A trichological treatment, focusing on scalp health, has become a necessity for working professionals due to stress. Former SIA stewardess Anita Wong opened her salon PHS, offering a three-step programme to detoxify, stabilize, and regrow hair. The treatment involves a 150-minute session with a shoulder massage, oxygen treatment, and a serum massage. Wong emphasizes the importance of regular scalp care, starting early, and having realistic expectations, as hair growth cycles are three months long. PHS has launched a men's range, retail products, and an online store, and Wong believes hair spas are the next big thing in beauty and wellness.

site_title: Internet tycoon's bet turns sour on superjumbos
summary: Internet entrepreneur Shinichi Nishikubo's plan to buy Airbus A380 jets for Japanese budget carrier Skymark Airlines has turned sour. Airbus cancelled the order for six planes, which Skymark had paid 26.5 billion yen (S$322 million) for, putting the airline at risk of losing payments. Skymark's shares lost a quarter of their value, and the airline may face penalties of up to 70 billion yen. Analysts question the airline's financial viability due to concerns over profitability and future viability.

site_title: ARA eyes investments in Australia and Korea
summary: ARA Asset Management plans to deploy dry powder in development projects in Australia and South Korea, further diversifying from its saturated Chinese market. The private equity arm aims to create more fund products, including the Summit Development Fund, which has a committed capital of US$80 million. ARA's interest in Australia follows its recent acquisition of land and property in North Sydney, while in South Korea, it acquired Macquarie Real Estate Korea Limited, managing two privately held Korean Reits. The move seeks to ride on development profits and capitalize on lower development risks in Australia.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: ARA Asset Management plans to invest in development projects in Australia and raise its presence in South Korea by creating more fund products. The move is part of a strategy to deploy its dry powder. A buyer's market for property insurance exists in Asia, according to the company.

site_title: It's a-ccrual world
summary: A Singaporean writer reflects on the introduction to accrual accounting, a method of recording expenses as incurred, rather than when payment is made. Accruals, which "build up over time," can be manipulated to influence income statements and balance sheets, affecting investors' perceptions of a company's health. Understanding accruals is crucial, as they can be used to forecast revenue and identify potential issues, such as unearned revenue and accrued expenses. A landmark study found that companies with low accruals outperformed those with large accruals, sparking a wave of research and hedge fund trading on this strategy.

site_title: Next crisis will be worse: Rogers
summary: Investment guru Jim Rogers warns of a potential worse global financial crisis, citing high global debts "up to the ceiling." He cautions against investing in anything unless it's cheap, and advises being prepared for a bad bear market. However, Rogers remains cautiously upbeat about China and identifies depressed markets such as Russia and North Korea as potential investment opportunities, particularly in agriculture. He emphasizes the importance of research and self-thought for young investors.

site_title: Flat movements in shortened week
summary: Singapore's Director Market activity was flat during the holiday-shortened week of July 29 to Aug 1, with 11 purchases worth S$2.6 million and 8 disposals worth S$5.8 million. Notable transactions included insider buys in Singapore Windsor Holdings and substantial shareholder acquisitions in Innovalues Ltd, ISDN Holdings, and Civmec Ltd. The buys were made on the back of share price rebounds, with some increases of up to 44% since May. The number of companies and trades on the buying side decreased, while the sell value increased sharply.

site_title: An int'l curriculum with Singapore flavour on M'sian soil
summary: Excelsior International School, managed by Raffles Campus, in Malaysia, offers an international curriculum with a Singaporean flavor, without restrictions on local students. The school, located in Bandar Seri Alam, features state-of-the-art facilities and infuses elements of the Singapore curriculum into its Cambridge and International Baccalaureate curricula. With a diverse student body of 200, comprising 65% Malaysians and 35% international students, Excelsior aims to provide holistic education in academics, sports, and arts.

site_title: Controversial toll hikes: what's in it for builder MRCB?
summary: The Malaysian government has introduced higher toll rates on the Eastern Dispersal Link expressway in Johor, with rates increasing by 300-500% starting this month. The toll hikes aim to maintain the expressway's 8.6km elevated section and fund its RM1.4 billion construction costs. However, it remains unclear whether the toll hikes will benefit concessionaire Malaysian Resources Corp Bhd (MRCB) or if the Malaysian government will continue to pay MRCB compensation of nearly RM12 million per month. MRCB has reaffirmed its "buy" call due to its property prospects, despite the controversy surrounding the toll hikes.

site_title: Job growth cools in July, unemployment rate rises unexpectedly to 6.2%
summary: US job growth slowed in July, with nonfarm payrolls increasing 209,000, down from June's 298,000. The unemployment rate unexpectedly rose to 6.2%, indicating some slack in the labor market. This could give the Federal Reserve room to keep interest rates low for a while. The data suggests the labor market is not as strong as previously thought, which may impact future monetary policy decisions.

site_title: SIA, conflict zones get Parliament's attention
summary: Singaporean MPs will question Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew about Singapore Airlines' flight paths over conflict zones, specifically Ukraine, following the MH17 tragedy. Six MPs have filed questions, including Yee Jenn Jong and Nicholas Fang, about the regulations governing Singapore flag carriers and the Civil Aviation Authority's review of flight routes. The queries come amidst the Auditor-General's report revealing government procurement lapses and other issues, which will also be discussed in Parliament.

site_title: Panamax rates plunge on weak China coal demand
summary: Panamax shipping rates have plummeted by as much as 76% this year due to weak China coal demand, with the country producing record hydropower. The increased power generation has reduced the need for coal imports, leading to lower freight rates. Morgan Stanley estimates that China's hydroelectric plants can replace 26 million tonnes of coal, equivalent to about 370 Panamax cargoes. This shift is expected to continue, further depressing shipping rates.

site_title: Mixing work with pleasure
summary: Devices are merging work and personal life through new products and services, offering users more choices and enhancing their computing experience. Three trends are at play: the continued growth of tablets and 2-in-1s, the rise of AI and digital innovation, and the increasing adoption of integrated enterprise solutions. This shift is expected to improve work and personal life by providing users with more flexibility and access to technology. As a result, users can seamlessly access work and personal information across various devices, blurring the lines between work and personal life.

site_title: Buyer's market in Asia for property insurance
summary: Asian property insurance rates continue to ease due to growing competition and insurers' higher capacity for underwriting. This trend is attributed to rising competition and insurers' ability to absorb losses, creating a challenge for insurers with low interest income. The premium pool in Asia is not growing as fast as insurers' investments, according to Zurich Insurance Company's Singapore CEO, Jonathan Rake. This downward pressure on rates is a concern for insurers in a world with low interest rates.

site_title: Li Ka-shing may bid for Irish firm's planes
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing is considering a bid for Awas Aviation Capital Ltd's portfolio of 280 planes, valued at up to $5 billion, marking his first major foray into aircraft leasing. The acquisition would be the plane leasing industry's third multibillion-dollar deal in the past 2.5 years. Li's Cheung Kong Holdings, which has a 59% increase in first-half profit, is also boosting investments in the infrastructure sector. The deal would be Li's biggest since 2010 and follows a series of significant acquisitions by his companies this year.

site_title: STI's window-dressing gains wiped out
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) saw its gains wiped out after a month, falling 29.64 points to 3,344.42, as the market shifted back to a "good-economic-news-is-bad-for-stocks" mode. The drop was attributed to the US economy's rebound in the second quarter, which may lead to interest rate hikes, and the minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Despite UOB's "outperform" rating, Citi Research called for a "sell" on the stock, citing its 14% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Nippon Steel seeking assets for growth outside Japan
summary: Nippon Steel, the world's second-largest steelmaker, is seeking to expand its assets outside Japan to tap into stronger overseas demand. The company is partnering with ArcelorMittal to acquire a US steel plant and is expanding into Latin America, particularly Brazil, where it co-controls a steelmaker. Nippon Steel's president, Kosei Shindo, stated that the company must follow the increase in steel demand in overseas markets, rather than focusing on its home market. This move is part of the company's globalization strategy, led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policy.

site_title: BA's owner boosts profit, adds 16 jets at Iberia
summary: IAG SA, the parent company of British Airways, reported a 55% increase in second-quarter operating profit to 380 million euros, driven by cost-cutting measures at Iberia. The company also ordered 16 new wide-body jets for Iberia, replacing ageing planes. IAG aims to lift annual earnings by at least 500 million euros by 2015, despite rivals cutting targets. CEO Willie Walsh targets a 1.8 billion-euro operating profit by 2015.

site_title: Sino Construction to buy another coal firm
summary: Sino Construction Group announced the acquisition of Australia-listed Guildford Coal Ltd's coal assets for US$25 million plus additional royalty. The deal includes 227 million tonnes of coal and an upper exploration target of 7.17 billion tonnes. Guildford will issue convertible promissory notes to Sino and have the option to redeem them if the volume-weighted average price of Sino shares meets a certain threshold. The deal is subject to due diligence, restructuring, and shareholder approval, and must be completed within four months.

site_title: Skill and luck playing out in ARA's private funds
summary: ARA Private Funds' investments in Singapore have yielded varying results. A 2009 club deal on the Suntec convention centre generated a 65% internal rate of return. However, the bulk purchase of condo units at Grange Infinite in 2008 resulted in a legal dispute and poor resales due to the introduction of the total debt servicing ratio. Other properties, such as ADF I, have performed well. The article highlights the interplay of skill and luck in private equity investing, suggesting that ARA's success is not solely due to their expertise.

site_title: Taking local designs global
summary: Singaporean makers are gaining international recognition for their unique designs and handmade products through online platforms like Etsy and Naiise. Local sellers such as bamboo bicycle maker Sunny Chuah, ceramic cup designer Jahan Loh, and typography artist Chen Zhi Liang are finding success with their products, which range from functional items like bicycles and soap to decorative pieces like posters and tote bags. Their designs often reflect Singapore's rich history and culture, with nostalgic illustrations of old Singapore and kitschy references to local slang. Online retailers are taking notice, with overseas customers from the US, Europe, and Asia purchasing these unique products.

site_title: Na Wu Beng is new Wing Hang CEO
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Na Wu Beng as the new CEO of Wing Hang Bank, replacing Patrick Fung, who will remain as non-executive chairman. Na, a 58-year-old banking veteran, previously served as deputy president director of OCBC's Indonesian unit. Following the close of OCBC's S$6.2 billion offer for Wing Hang, several Wing Hang directors have resigned, citing the change in control. The appointment comes after OCBC's S$6.2 billion offer for Wing Hang was completed.

site_title: 2 firms backed by Temasek weigh US IPOs
summary: Two Singapore-based technology firms, Reebonz Pte and Razer Inc, are considering US initial public offerings (IPOs). Reebonz, an online luxury goods retailer, is receiving proposals for a Nasdaq listing in the first half of 2025, while Razer is working with Credit Suisse on an IPO that could raise around $150 million. These companies join Asian Internet and technology firms like Alibaba and Line Corp in seeking US IPOs, which have raised over $3.3 billion this year.

site_title: Relaxing the curbs - a question of timing
summary: Singapore's property cooling measures, introduced in 2009, have helped curb the excesses of the property market, reducing prices by 2.8% and slowing sales. Experts agree that the measures have been effective in preventing a bubble, but debate the timing of relaxing the curbs. Some argue that the measures are too restrictive, causing investors to look overseas, while others believe the market is not yet ready for a relaxation. The government must carefully consider the impact of any changes, as a premature relaxation could drive prices up and lead to a market correction.

site_title: Commonwealth Games' uncertain future
summary: The Commonwealth Games' uncertain future raises questions about its significance in the modern sporting world. The 2018 edition was won by Australia, with Durban and Edmonton expressing interest in bidding for the 2022 Games. However, concerns over cost and investment in athletes' participation remain. The event's attendance and viewership have also been questioned, with some countries opting out of the "Commonwealth" aspect and major corporates staying away due to a lack of a global audience. The future of the Games hangs in the balance, with the Commonwealth Games Federation seeking to attract top athletes and ensure the event's continued relevance.

site_title: Living the dream
summary: Chef Dan Hunter of Brae restaurant believes good food starts with the soil, not just the seed. At his 50-seat restaurant in Birregurra, near Melbourne, Hunter sources ingredients from his 30-acre property and trusted organic growers. He uses distinctly Australian ingredients, such as wallaby, quandong, and native pepperberries, and forages for edible seaweeds and coastal plants. Hunter's goal is to create a fully immersive back-to-the-roots experience, with plans to build luxury apartments and a retail store for his farm-fresh produce. He emphasizes the importance of working with the land to achieve flavorsome food.

site_title: Vigorous push to mod-Sin cuisine
summary: Singaporean chef Willin Low's modern Sin cuisine has gained maturity, reflecting a clearer narrative. His dishes showcase a refined thought process. This trend is also seen in other restaurants like Wild Rocket and Thevar 2.0, which offer modern Indian and mod-Indian cuisine, respectively. The Social Kitchen has also set up shop at Bank of Singapore. Additionally, various initiatives focus on corporate purpose, financial literacy, and sustainability, such as NCSS rallying partners for volunteers and CMC Markets partnering with Sophia Women. These developments highlight the evolving culinary and social landscape in Singapore.

site_title: Regulators take aim at contra trading, errant listed firms
summary: Singapore regulators have introduced new rules to curb contra and speculative trading, with penalties of up to S$1 million for companies that breach listing rules. Retail investors' access to securities will be improved with a board lot size reduction to 100 shares from 1,000 shares by next year. The minimum trading price for mainboard listings will be set at 20 Singapore cents, and more than 200 listed companies will have 18 months to meet this criterion through share consolidation.

site_title: SIIC Environment's Q2 profit up 20%
summary: SIIC Environment reported a 19.9% increase in Q2 net profit to 66 million yuan, driven by a 34.8% rise in revenue to 381.8 million yuan. The company's first-half net profit rose 60.9% to 129.6 million yuan, thanks to contributions from newly acquired entities, higher construction earnings, and foreign exchange gains. Revenue climbed 41.3% to 679.6 million yuan in the first half.

site_title: Click for lunch @ CBD
summary: Two new tech start-ups, Lunchbox and Grain, are addressing the issue of queuing for food in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD). Lunchbox, founded by former Citibank banker Han Jiang, partners with CBD restaurants to provide packed lunches within 45 minutes of ordering. Grain, a food-on-demand service, cooks and packages its own food, offering healthy options and nutritional information. Meanwhile, Feedex, a hybrid business model, combines online ordering with a physical pick-up point, offering a range of local hawker fare and partnering with famous hawkers.

site_title: High art & craft
summary: Louis Vuitton's CEO, Michael Burke, attributes the brand's astronomical sales to its strategy of hyper-exclusivity and craftsmanship. The company's high-end products, such as the Capucines bag and high jewelry, are limited in production and require painstaking attention to detail, making them unique and desirable. Burke emphasizes the importance of artisans, artists, and the creative process in luxury, and notes that the company supports young talent and small industries to maintain its position in the market. With a focus on innovation and exclusivity, Louis Vuitton aims to remain relevant and enticing to an increasingly sophisticated consumer.

site_title: Cosco expected to return to substantial profitability in 2015
summary: China Cosco Holdings Co Ltd, the country's top shipping line, is expected to return to substantial profitability in 2015 after five lean years. The company reported a first-half loss of 2.28 billion yuan, but analysts predict net income of 1.02 billion yuan in 2015 and 2.36 billion yuan in 2016. A slowdown in new vessel deliveries and an uptick in global trade are seen as key factors contributing to the industry's recovery, with freight rates and demand for shipping services expected to improve.

site_title: Cosco reports 19% rise in Q2 earnings
summary: Cosco Corporation reported a 19% increase in Q2 earnings to S$14.3 million, with revenue rising 29% to S$1.15 billion, driven by higher shipyard revenue and interest income. The company's order book stands at US$8.1 billion, and despite caution about the 2014 outlook, it plans to intensify efforts to improve capabilities and productivity.

site_title: Electric city
summary: Singapore is set to experience electric mobility with the introduction of the BMW i3, an electric vehicle that goes on sale for S$228,800. The i3 features a unique design, with an aluminium frame and lithium-ion batteries packed within, providing instant torque and low centre of gravity. The vehicle also comes with a range extender, a 650cc petrol engine, to extend its driving range. Despite its shorter range, the i3 is an enjoyable and fun car with advanced safety features, making it a pioneer in electric mobility in Singapore.

site_title: Sands for Singapore Festival kicks off
summary: The Sands for Singapore Festival 2014 kicked off yesterday and will run through this weekend, featuring interactive events and activities such as Tangle and the Sands for Singapore Inspiration Centre. The festival's proceeds will go towards Community Chest.

site_title: China exposure: MAS seeks data from banks
summary: MAS has asked banks in Singapore to submit information on their exposure to Chinese companies by Aug 6, amid concerns over commodity financing fraud. The questionnaire, sent in mid-July, seeks details on trade finance, commodity finance, and import/export commodities exposure. The move follows recent adverse news and developments concerning trade financing into China, particularly the suspected fraud in Qingdao. Several banks, including DBS, OCBC, and Citi, have been asked to submit the information, with a deadline extended from July 29.

site_title: Pinnacle of luxury
summary: Bulgari CEO Jean-Christophe Babin aims to make his company the most desired luxury brand in the world by emphasizing extraordinary jewelry and watches. He believes that jewelry and watches share similar expertise and cater to similar consumers, despite differences in materials. Babin plans to develop Bulgari's image and make it a pinnacle of luxury by elevating beauty and preciousness in all aspects of the brand, including boutiques and hospitality experiences. He also plans to integrate jewelry lines into other product categories, such as watches and accessories.

site_title: Lacklustre property sentiment hits OUE's Q2
summary: OUE Limited reported a 69.6% drop in net profit to S$4.4 million for its Q2, with revenue falling 10.6% to S$100.2 million due to a lacklustre Singapore residential property market. The company cited the absence of China hotel contributions and challenges in the high-end residential market. Despite this, it proposed an interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share and plans to drive the sale of its Leonie Hill development project.

site_title: It's Just a S$1,000 Lunch
summary: A Singapore-based matchmaking firm, It's Just Lunch Asia, has launched the Men's Elite Club, charging S$10,000 for 10 guaranteed dates with high-net-worth individuals seeking Asian women, specifically Korean women. The club's clients are high-net-worth individuals, including CEOs and business owners, who want to meet women with desirable attributes such as intelligence, confidence, and physical appearance. The firm claims a success rate of 60% in leading to second dates, and one client has reportedly gotten engaged after a single date. The Men's Elite Club is part of the company's premium dating services, which also offer pre-date questions and photos of female candidates for an additional fee.

site_title: Kim Heng Offshore warns of Q2 profit fall
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has warned of a potential profit fall in the second quarter due to higher-margin projects and delayed rig arrivals. The company expects lower earnings compared to the same period last year. This is the first profit snag for the company since its listing on Catalist in January 2014.

site_title: Breathtakingly stylish Oedipus
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts has seen a standout production with "The Chorus; Oedipus," a stylish update of the 2,500-year-old Greek tragedy. Directed by Seo Jae-Hyung, the show retains classic hallmarks while incorporating contemporary touches, featuring a powerful lead performance by Hae Soo Park as Oedipus and Keng Hee Yim as Jocasta. The production's use of a dynamic chorus and haunting piano music creates a strong sense of existential dread, culminating in a shocking and devastating conclusion that has left audiences stunned.

site_title: GIC's 20-year returns beat global inflation
summary: Singapore's GIC has achieved annualised real returns of 4.1% over the past 20 years, surpassing global inflation. The fund's strong recovery in global financial markets drove this performance. Despite a gloomy outlook for fund managers, GIC remains focused on sustainable returns, while major asset classes face high prices and rising interest rates. GIC managing director Lim Chow Kiat noted that the outlook is clouded, but the fund is gunning for assets that can deliver long-term returns.

site_title: China PMI rises sharply, exceeds estimate
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded at the fastest pace in over two years in July, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.7, exceeding expectations. The data signals a strengthening economic growth amid government support policies, including infrastructure investments in railways and subways. The PMI readings above 50 indicate expansion, and a gauge of smaller manufacturers also rose above 50 for the first time since March 2012. The data suggests the government's targeted stimulus measures are reaching their targets, and growth is expected to stabilize, allowing the government to focus on economic reform.

site_title: Tussle for WBL: what was it all for?
summary: United Engineers (UE) acquired WBL Corp in 2013, paying through its nose to take control of the luxury auto distribution business, Wearnes Automotive. However, just a year later, UE sold parts of WBL, including Wearnes, for a combined S$900 million. UE's debt was significantly reduced by the sale, but the company's assets are now being sold off again, including MFS Technology and Multi-Fineline Electronix. OCBC, UE's parent company, is exploring the sale of its stakes in UE and WBL to Thai tycoon Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, which could trigger a mandatory takeover offer. The move is part of OCBC's strategy to sell non-banking assets and expand into China.

site_title: Classier C
summary: The new Mercedes-Benz C-Class has moved upmarket, building on the success of the CLA-Class, which attracted new buyers to the brand. The fourth-generation C-Class is more luxurious, well-appointed, and stylish, with a harmonious design that rivals the S-Class. The interior features a flowing leather dashboard, organic lines, and premium materials, while the exterior boasts a sleek front end, sculpted flanks, and a curvaceous rear. Three turbocharged engine options are available, including a C250 with 211 hp and a 0-100 km/h time of 6.6 seconds.

site_title: Singapore's wealthy lured to risky bonds
summary: Singapore's wealthy individuals are investing in high-yield bonds from smaller companies, driving yields to a 13-year high. Companies such as Pacific Andes Resources Development Ltd and Halcyon Agri Corp issued Singapore dollar-denominated bonds with coupons above 5% last month. This has pushed corporate note rates in the city-state to 4.3%, one percentage point higher than all of 2013, and junk yields in Asia to 7.3%, 58 basis points higher than last year.

site_title: DBS Q2 earnings up 9% at S$969m
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 9% jump in net profit to S$969 million in the second quarter, driven by improved lending margins and lower allowance charges. CEO Piyush Gupta assured that the bank has no exposure to China's commodity financing scandal and has zero exposure to Qingdao port. Despite concerns over China's economy, DBS sees growth opportunities in India and Indonesia. The bank's shares rose 0.5% to S$18.31 after the earnings release. Net interest income rose 13% and non-interest income fell 18% due to weaker trading income.

site_title: Full speed ahead every day
summary: DHL Express Singapore's senior vice-president Herbert Vongpusanachai is dedicated to making customers successful in their endeavors. Over the past 11 years, he has grown the company's active account customers to over 22,000 and doubled the number of retail service points to over 120. Vongpusanachai's approach involves hands-on involvement with employees, customers, and business partners to ensure seamless delivery and forge strong partnerships. He sees Singapore as a key business location due to its infrastructure and business-friendly environment, and is eager for the Asean Economic Community's implementation to increase regional economic integration and investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Mr Vongpusanachai: 'The guidelines behind our choice of partners are that the brands must share similar values with us, and they must have logistics relevance.'

site_title: Conveniently available
summary: A Singaporean couple, Kelvin Ngian and Jun Hew, have launched Cocoloco, a locally bottled fresh Thai coconut juice brand. The coconut water is directly imported from Thailand, filtered but not pasteurized, and contains no added sugar or artificial sweeteners. The bottles are available on-demand and delivered on the same day, with lab-tested shelf life of up to a week. The brand aims to make the trendy health drink more conveniently available to the masses, capitalizing on the growing interest in coconut water.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Ezra Holdings' shareholders approved the consolidation of its offshore support services division with its associated company, EOC Ltd, and the proposed listing of EOC on SGX. Figtree Real Estate acquired a Melbourne property for A$13.998m to develop into a high-rise mixed development. SIIC Environment Holdings' Weifang subsidiary won a BOT wastewater treatment project in Dalian, China.

site_title: Healthy and bubbly
summary: Citizen Pop, a maker of healthy carbonated drinks, was founded by 26-year-old Imelda Mo, who initially disliked fizzy drinks due to their sweetness and lack of nutritional value. Inspired by a refreshing soda taste in Bangkok's Chatuchak market, Mo created a range of handpressed fruit juices blended with herbs and spices, then carbonated and bottled. The company now offers two flavors and plans to launch cordials and bottled alcoholic sodas, also using the sodas as mixers for spirits. Mo's goal is to offer a unique and refreshing alternative to traditional soda brands.

site_title: Acra raises the bar for public accountants
summary: Acra, Singapore's accounting regulator, will raise the bar for public accountants starting February 2015. To qualify, practitioners will need 2,500 hours of audit management experience, in addition to 3 years of audit experience. This new requirement aims to ensure high-quality audits and uphold the profession's integrity. The 2,500 hours will be gained at a senior level after completing professional accountancy training, and will be counted towards the Singapore Qualification Programme or equivalent qualifications. The revised process will take at least 5 years to complete.

site_title: Stocks likely to continue last Friday's rebound
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their rebound from last Friday, with analysts citing improving economic fundamentals and a lack of major shocks from the Ukrainian conflict. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is almost flat for 2014, and a reading of eurozone economic growth due on Thursday may reveal the impact of the conflict on Europe's economy. US consumers appear to be shaking off the recession, with second-quarter GDP growth of 4% and aggregate earnings rate for Standard & Poor's 500 corporations at 10%. Contrarian analysts say the market's focus on geopolitical risks is misplaced, and investors will realize the improving outlook for US economic and corporate growth.

site_title: German office Reit with Chinese backer to raise S$369m in IPO
summary: IReit Global Group, Singapore's first listed real estate investment trust (Reit) with German office assets, is set to raise S$369m through an IPO.
